Horton Heat at I Love This Bar & Grill on Thursday, and while the music was good, the prices were highway robbery. Five bucks for a can of PBR? Eight dollars for a rum and diet? No way, Jose. The grub looked like something outta Applebee's, and the bartender was clueless. Prices kept changin' all night too. Bad service, bad drink prices, good entertainment, but overall, it's a rip-off."

"Wanted to like this joint, went there twice. First time, ordered water, waitress gives me the hairy eyeball, 'You sure you don't want a lemon in that?' Like, what's up with the water? Tastes like crap. Second time, saw Kreplach soup, got excited. But no, they're mass-produced, skinny, not handmade. Don't waste your time. Half sandwich, tiny cole slaw, like they're trying to save money. Corned beef sandwiches, okay, but small for the price. Entrance is a mess, lots of different areas crammed together. Seating area, plain. Not impressed. If this is Tempe's idea of a Jewish deli, it's lacking."
"Terrible service. Great food, though. Ordered, waited 50 minutes, then didn't see the waitress again for 30 more. She finally brought the check."

"Fear not, dear friends, this theatre doth seem
A relic of the past, a remnant of the dream
That Mills malls once were, in days of yore
When crowds did throng, and laughter did pour

But now, alas, 'tis naught but a shell
A hollow husk, a shadow of its former spell
The comedy, a mind-numbing jest
Didst play to empty seats, a lonely guest

My friends, I pray thee, heed my words of woe
For I didst lose those precious hours, oh so
In vain, I searched the box office, high and low
For refunds, a solace, but nay, none didst show

Melinda's card, it would not swipe, alack
And so we moved, to another machine, in haste
But lo, the tickets printed not, nor didst the receipt
And thus, we stood, before the box office, meek

The manager, a kindly soul, didst let us in
With nary a fuss, or query, or din
Perhaps, my friends, we shall essay again
To test the bounds of fate, and fortune's spin"

"This joint used to be my go-to spot back when it was at von's. Moved to Food4Less, still decent. Closed up shop for a bit, no idea why. Now it's back and I'm stoked. Came in today for my usual, pad thai. Doesn't quite taste the same, and they scrapped the lunch special. Bummer."

"Site's got some issues, pal. Stock levels ain't accurate, and they don't give a damn 'bout lettin' folks know when they're outta stock. You try to get 'em to fix things, they just talk over ya and hang up. That's their way of sayin' they don't want your business. Well, I'm happy to oblige 'em. Screw 'em."
"Went downhill, fast. Been here a couple years, near Chinese place. Not going back."
"Waitress, nice. Open on Xmas eve, good. But, waitress no good at job. Beer, skunked. Fries, slow and cold."

"You wanna die soon? Cover charge, shouldn't be charged, girlfriend gets raped on the dance floor. Two stars 'cause I used to like it. Pool, good music, dancing, reasonable drinks. But after some rough times, fights every week, and a shooting in the parking lot...no thanks. Don't do karaoke, so that part might be alright."
"Tacos? Yeah, they got 'em. Service? Meh. Drunk and hungry? That's their jam."

"Hark! A tale of woe and hunger doth unfold,
In South Phoenix, where the sun doth shine bright and bold.
A quest for breakfast burritos, a noble pursuit,
Didst lead me to Fili B's, with naught but doubt.

Their breakfast, served all day, a wonder to behold,
Yet my heart did yearn for something more, a tale to be told.
My stomach, empty and weary, did protest and cry,
For a familiar drive-thru, where I could buy.

Alas, fate didst guide me to this place,
Where the food didst fall short of grace.
Too much cheese, the bacon undercooked,
My friends' chorizo burritos, bland and overlooked.

I do confess, my friends, I do avoid,
Fili B's, and seek out its sisters, a better choice, I avow.
Rollbertos, Eribertos, Armandos, their names doth ring,
A better option, for a hungry soul to cling."
"Good spot, nice joint. Grub's alright, not great. Drinks, now those were something else. Creative, I'll give 'em that."

"Alack, I ordered lasagna, soup, and salad,
But found the Italian wedding soup quite bad.
It tasted like Italian dressing, oh so sweet,
And left me in such disappointment, I did retreat.

I saved it for a week, hoping for a refund,
But the manager seemed hesitant, I did find.
All the herby flavor, gone, alas!
And sweet, sweet, sweet, took over the taste.

Oh, lasagna, thou art good, but too sweet,
The portion, small, the price, quite steep.
I'll make my own, and freeze some, 'tis my creed.

The dinner salad, fantastic, crisp, and fresh,
But drained lettuce, and sugary dressing, alack!
If not for that, I'd have it twice a week,
But now, I'll bring my own, and that's no trick.

So, farewell, dear restaurant, I'll return no more,
Unless 'tis for the salad, and my own dressing galore."

"Hark! I had my pants hemmed at this place,
And though the tailor did his best with haste,
They still were too long, despite his care,
And cost me dearly, with a week to spare.

Oh, come now! Is it not a foolish thing,
To pay so much for such a simple task?
A week, good sir! 'Tis far too long, I say,
For pants that should be done in a day's play."

"Food was decent, nothing special. Service was top-notch, though. Friendly folks. Celebrating our one-year anniversary, my husband and I. Would've preferred a place where they let you finish your meal without taking your plate. Busy Sunday, but still felt rushed. Won't be back."

"Hark! A mozzarella and tomato sandwich, with pasta salad small,
And drink, didst total thirteen pieces of silver.
A paltry sum, indeed, for such a meal,
When restaurants nearby do serve a greater feast.

But wait, good sir! For in this place,
They do bake cookies of paradise, most fair and bright.
So, though the food may be a trifle dear,
The sweetness of their confections doth make all right."
"Good beer, bad grub. Cheap eats, though. Nice screens."
"Went there, real disappointment. Hubby had veggie skillet, cold veggies, sad cheese. I got pancakes, Bisquick does 'em better. Never going back, too bad since we're neighbors."

"Twas Tuesday eve, and I didst venture forth
To get mine nails done, as oft I doth.
The nail lady, skilled in her craft, didst tend
To mine digits with great care and speed.
But lo! The ambiance of the place didst grate
Upon mine ears, like fingernails upon a slate.
For there, within the hair salon's walls,
Didst Barbara, hairdresser, let her brats
Run wild and free, their shrieks and laughter calls
Didst pierce the air, and made it hard to bear.
And not just that, but on her phone, she didst
Scream at some wretch, her voice didst ring out clear.
My nail lady said 'twas usual, and the brood
Didst roam the salon, loud and unrestrained,
As Barbara, loud herself, didst make no move
To check their noise, or keep them contained.
I sought to relax, and find some peace,
But couldst not, in that chaotic, rowdy place.
So I shall not return, for I do not wish
To be annoyed by children's shouting face."

"Smoke-filled casino with too much repetition."

I stepped into the casino, and the smoke hit me like a heavy fog. It was everywhere, and it seemed to cling to everything. Even the air felt thick with it. I made my way through the haze, trying to find a place to sit down and play some slots. But every machine I approached was occupied, and the people sitting at them didn't look like they were planning on leaving anytime soon.

I signed up for their rewards program, hoping to get some free play out of it. But all I got was $10, and it could only be used on a handful of machines that were scattered throughout the casino. And of course, those machines were always busy. It was like they were taunting me, dangling the possibility of free play just out of reach.

Overall, this casino was a disappointment. It was my least favorite in the area, and I won't be rushing back anytime soon. The smoke was overwhelming, and the lack of available machines made it hard to enjoy myself. I'll stick to other casinos from now on.
"Brunch was good, service was bad. Steak knife on the can, glad no little girls found it. Disappointed, need a new spot. This place needs to get its act together."

"2.5 stars. Rounding down.

Hype said this Vegas buffet was top-notch. Decent, but not worth raving about.

World buffet theme with Chinese, American, Mexican, Mediterranean, and maybe Japanese stations. Creative, but limited options at each station.

Hubby said crab legs were undercooked. Not impressed by seafood selection, but this ain't no seafood buffet.

Had a juicy roast pork, but nothing special.

Skip it. Go to a real restaurant instead."

"Lunch buffet’s mediocre, best to avoid. I only go for the chaat, but today they said no, kitchen’s too busy. Waitress took our order first, then told us no chaat. Others got takeout, must have called ahead."

"Disappointment stung like a slap in the face. Heard tales of this joint, expected more. Walked in, greeted promptly. Service was top-notch. Place was empty, though. After 9 pm, drinks weren't on special. Eight bucks for a Corona? Pass."

"Sandwich joint in Bryant Park. Good memories. Fresh, hot sammies. Can't beat it. Vegas version? Not so much. Mediocre at best. Line to the door on a Saturday afternoon. Shouldn't be surprised. Time means nothing in a casino. Ordered ham, cheddar, apple on pumpernickel. Took a bit. Ripped it open in the car. Messy. Soggy. Cheddar killed the flavor. Subway does it better."

"Disappointment reigned. Questionable night at a four-star joint, according to Yelp. Quality control? Nonexistent. Freshness lacking, presentation decent. Meat? Dried out, tough. Prime rib, turkey, ribs - all dry, all tough. Asian cuisine? Nauseating. Pizza and ice cream, edible. Won't return."

"Brunch was a bust. Sign said 11-3:30, but that was BS. Downstairs restaurant, maybe. Not up here. We were hungry, so we ate anyway. Appetizer, good. Veggie burger, crap. Frozen patty job. Waited forever for the bill. Corner table, forgotten. Waiter apologized, but too little, too late. Won't be back."

"A bar most crowded, my dear friends, on a Sunday e'en,
My visit there did leave me in a state of woeful dismay.
We began with margaritas at Hefe on Mill, I do declare,
And thence did Uber our way to Old Town Scottsdale's lair.

Alas, the bar was full, my friends, beyond all measure,
A smaller town, perchance, it would have been a treasure.
Or mayhap, management should consider, ere they do implore,
A limit on the crowd, lest it become a chaotic roar.

Indeed, 'twas madness, pure and simple, a scene most dire,
I pray, my friends, thou shalt not suffer such a fate anon.
For in such crush of humanity, there's naught but woe and despair,
And little joy or mirth, to ease the heavy burden of our care."

"O, woe is me, to suffer thus, at DMV's hand! Methinks 'tis torture, to endure their scornful eye, And forced attendance, at their beck and call. But lo, a kiosk, outside, doth save the day! At two o'clock, this morn, I went, and with great ease, Renewed my car's registration, in but two brief minutes' space. O, blessed machine, how thou dost save me from their wrath! And now, with kiosks sprouting, all o'er the town, Mayhap, I shall ne'er need, to enter their domain. Forsooth, the employees, do bear a grudge, Against us poor souls, who dare to darken their door. And, verily, the crowds, they swarm, like bees in spring, A snack bar, too! O, what a wondrous thing! Yet, naught but woe, doth DMV bring."

"A dire omen, indeed, when we didst step inside yon vast eatery, and found it void of patrons. The next signal of woe, a menu of gargantuan proportions, rivalling the very excess of Cheesecake Factory's offerings. In utter dismay, I chose the chicken tender plate, a safe and familiar path. My fair maiden opted for a Thai-inspired dish, while her mother, a salad. The wait, an interminable duration of nigh forty-five minutes. My fowl, a middling fare, surpassing not the standards of Bojangles. Alas, the beverage list, a pitiful sight, didst leave much to be desired."

"Went to this joint on a night when they had some bands playin'. Had a helluva time gettin' the attention of the waitstaff. Finally walked up to the bar and ordered two draft beers, which set me back close to ten bucks. Took 'em a while to notice us, but after 'bout forty minutes, our orders were ready. The appetizer, some kinda Italian burrito, was still frozen solid in the middle. Soups were just okay. Ribs were pretty good, but Jesus, they drowned 'em in sauce. If you don't like a lotta sauce, best to ask for it on the side. Bands were damn good that night, though. Only had three drinks, 'cause that's all they seemed to want to sell me. Couldn't get anyone's attention for more. Seemed like if they're gonna pay a band, they should try a little harder to sell the grub and drinks, y'know?"

In we stepped, for happy hour's delight,
And cast our eyes about the room with speed.
But lo, the scent of death did strike our senses,
Like to a funeral home, in sadness and grief.

We walked forthwith out, with haste and speed,
For this place did not seem fit for our youthful deeds.
Perhaps, my friends, 'tis good for those who rest,
Retired from life's labors, and seeking quiet nest.
"Staff, friendly. Accommodating, too. Flower arrangement, nice. But pricey. Roses, some dead. Not worth it."

"First-time at this joint. Been to other spots, pizza was great, service was crap. Friends in town, wanted good pizza, not some chain dump. Ordered two pies, they were just okay. Staff wasn't too bad, but drinks sat empty for too long. Waitress disappeared for a bit. Won't be coming back. Other location's better. Proximity to UNLV must be what keeps this place going."

"Place looks like shit. Service slow, grub mediocre, quality down the drain. Dining area? Filthy. Used to be a cheap alternative to PF Chang's. Now it's just a step up from Denny's. You've lost your touch, big time."

In this day's tight economy, I do detest
To speak ill of a restaurant, save it be just.
But, alas, this place doth not deserve my praise,
For service poor, and food but mediocre, doth raise.

A solitary patron, I, in this domain,
Must fetch my own salt, pepper, and drink, forsooth.
And, as I dined, my water glass did stay
Unfilled, until my meal was nigh complete, alack.

The baba ganoush, a fair dish, at a good price,
The salad, fresh, crisp, a delight to my eyes.
But, oh, the kafta kabob, how dry it was!
A shame, for tazeki, it did lack, to soothe my taste.

The waitress, pleasant, yet not overly concerned,
With ensuring that my needs were well-served.
Three stars, a generous rating, methinks,
For would I return? We shall see, their lunch deals links.

"Terrible value, overpriced tourist trap. Went with friends, server was creepy, snarky. Food was mediocre, eggplant parm was greasy, ravioli was flat and lacking filling, Caprese was fresh and nice. Asked to see car collection, they wanted a cover charge. Skip this place."

"Tight parking lot at this Walgreens. Keep an eye out when walking to your car. Recommend using the drive-through. Had a great experience with the clerk. She earned a star. Otherwise, it would've been a one-star visit."

"Awaiting my steaming cup of brew,
I find myself in quite a stew.
The chocolate, black as night's despair,
Limits my drink, and with powdered flair.
An error in the command, alas, doth lay,
My cassolette, not good enough to stay.
My disappointment doth know no bounds,
For all my hopes, now but empty sounds."

"Upon this fair square, Market Square, didst I venture with mine coworkers, seeking mirth and merriment in the form of happy hour. Alas, the service and victuals didst not impress me, despite the pleasant location of the establishment. We partook in the margarita special, and found it to be decent, though the drinks were large and potent. 

In the spirit of thriftiness, we didst order diverse appetizers to share, taking advantage of the half-price offer during happy hour. Verily, I didst sample the sopecitos, four corn tortillas topped with various meats - chicken, steak, carnitas, and chorizo. Alas, the tortillas didst not taste fresh, and the dish was served lukewarm. 

Furthermore, I didst try the empanadas, filled with beef. They were unremarkable, lacking in flavor and leaving me unimpressed. Other dishes didst fail to leave a lasting impression, save for the flautas, which we all didst enjoy immensely. 

Alas, the service didst falter, with a prolonged wait for our appetizers, and an error in the preparation of one dish. Alack, the experience was tarnished by these missteps."

"Twas naught but mediocrity that didst greet mine eyes and taste buds, fair friends. Alack, the al pastor, once a sweet and savory delight, didst fail to impress, its juiciness lost to the sands of time, it seemed. And as for the lengua, tender indeed it was, but devoid of flavor, a blandness that didst leave mine mouth in disarray. Fie upon this place, I say, for it didst not stir within me the passions of yore."

"Staff was decent, except one. Went during lunch, prepping my bowl. This staffer yells at me, attitude dripping, 'You can't be back here!' She means the space between the two self-serve stations. One's closed, but it's tough to reach the far items. So, I go to the other side, making it easier. She yells from afar, instead of walking over, warning me it's off-limits. Rude! What's the goal here? Go big or go home! Won't be back."

"My friend, in fervent zeal, didst sing the praises of this place,
But I, alas, found it wanting in taste and grace.
The burger, once a proud dish, now doth pale and wane,
With flavors sour and sweet, like a sickly bane.
I couldst not finish it, nor didst I desire,
For it didst leave my stomach in dismal ire.
A rarity, indeed, for one who doth devour,
But thus, my friends, didst this dish didst bore."
"Omelette, overcooked and rubbery. Not good. Disappointing, considering past visits. Companion's omelette, same issue. Advice? Avoid the omelette, especially for that price."

"Methinks I be a Mexican food aficionado,
A connoisseur of humble, unassuming abodes.
The mini chimichangas, five in total, didst I devour,
With beans and rice, a feast most hearty and enduring.

The price, ten dollars, didst seem a mite steep,
Yet the flavors, oh so sweet and rich, didst keep
My taste buds dancing with delight.
Cream cheese and beef within, a savory blend,
The pastry, flaky and light, a true delight.

The refried beans, a culinary dream,
Didst complement the rice, a simple, plain scheme.
Chicken chimis, alack, not an option,
Yet the salsa bar, a medley of flavors, didst entice.

Avocado and salsa verde, a unique blend,
Didst tantalize my taste buds, a true friend.
The restaurant, clean and neat,
A smile, a greeting, a welcome treat.

But four times, good sirs, doth seem a bit much,
Overkill, methinks, a tad too push.
A fried ice cream milkshake, a treat most rare,
Doth tempt me still, a reason to return, perchance.

Yet, alas, this place doth not compare,
To Carolina's, los dos melinos, so fair and rare."

"Vegas, baby! Arrive pumped, ready to roll. Lose all your dough gambling, can't swing a meal, clubs turn you away, feel like crap. Time to bail. 

Airport's a zoo. Line snakes 'round the room, hundreds strong. Hour or two, finally through security. Phew! 

Gotta hit the D gates. Tram's busted?! Start trekkin' a mile with a hundred pounds of luggage. Checked bag limit's fifty, but you packed way too much junk. 

Finally at the gate. Two-hour delay?! Dammit! 

Recap: Security line's a nightmare, tram's down, gotta hike a mile, two-hour delay. Only perk's the free Wi-Fi. That's how I wrote this review."
"Veggie burger, good. Fries, crispy. Service, bad. Twice now, we've had to chase down a waitress for refills. Takeout next time, no tip needed."

"A fair abode, with servitors kind and true,
Yet, shall I say, my expectations flew
Into the realm of disappointment, alack!
For though the masseuse was skilled, her touch did lack
That certain je ne sais quoi, which doth make
The difference 'twixt a good massage and a great.

The place itself, a haven of serenity,
With front desk staff, most courteous and sweet.
But, prithee, tell me, why the cost so steep?
For equal quality, at lower price, doth sleep
In other establishments, wherefore I say,
I shall not return, despite the referral's sway."

"Airline staff need better training, that's the truth. Southwest gives two passes max, per customer, per day. Like this: Phoenix to Spokane, connection in Oklahoma City. Two passes, no problem. But then, Spokane to Las Vegas, no change of plane. They give me another pass. Now I'm stuck on a full flight, overbooked. Frustrating, that's what it is."

"Cochinito pibil, a $20 slow-cooked pork dish, was nothing special. Too salty, a bit dry. Spices overpowered the flavor. Sauce drips on the plate, half-wiped off, made it look dirty. But the $7 Modelo beer, now that was something else. Crisp, refreshing, a perfect complement to the mediocre meal."

"Alas, my dearest Haymaker, how art thou fallen!
In days of yore, thy halls didst shine with grace,
And I, a humble patron, didst sing thy praise.
But now, alack! thy glory doth depart,
And in its stead, doth mediocrity reign.

My glass, once filled with nectar, doth run dry,
And though I ask, nary a drop doth come nigh.
The lettuce, once a leaf of crisp delight,
Doth now lie shredded, lost in ignominy's blight.

Thy iced coffee, once a sweet and frosty treat,
Doth vanish like a dream, leaving naught but heat.
And marinara, that tangy, savory delight,
Doth absent itself, a cruel and bitter plight.

Yet still, thy drafts of Bud Light, two dollars fine,
Do bring a smile, a fleeting joy divine.
But lo! A tomato, lopsided and misshapen,
Doth sully my burger, a sight most vexing.

An onion ring, a paltry, meager thing,
Doth mock my request, a sorry, laughable bringing.
I fear, my Haymaker, our love doth wane,
And till thou changest, I shall not come again."

"We hit this joint pretty often, so you'd think I'd give it high marks. But let's be real, it's not great. We mostly come for the chips and salsa, which are solid. Margaritas are good too. They've got a new pretzel stick appetizer that's decent. Most of the servers are friendly and attentive. But the food? Meh. I've tried a bunch of different dishes and nothing's really impressed me. Sides are usually subpar and the kids' meals are terrible. If it's just me and the hubby, we might stop by for lunch and get the endless chips and salsa with soup and salad. But even those have been lacking lately. Will I be back? Sure, for a drink and some snacks. But if I'm looking for a real meal, I'll go elsewhere."

"Been here a few times. Not impressed. Stylists are alright, nothing special. Prices are decent, but a bit steep for what you get. Biggest issue's the customer service. Called after hours, left messages. They won't call back. If they're too busy to return calls, maybe they don't need my business. Won't be coming back."

"Worst Hawaiian BBQ joint I've been to, no contest. No teriyaki or katsu sauce? Fail. Soy sauce and some glowing red crap instead? Pathetic. Mac salad? Overcooked, mushy, and drenched in low-quality mayo. Missing the carrot shavings too. Chicken? Dry as hell. Can't even taste the marinade. Veggies? Old, dry cabbage. Fake grass in an Easter basket. Menu's confused, Hawaiian BBQ or ghetto Chinese? Friendly elderly Asian couple, quick service, but that's about it. Clean, but nothing special. Won't be back."

"I went to the Milano in '90. It was the coolest bar around, but not anymore. Few customers, lazy staff, loud music, made it hard to hear and relax. They closed the windows to avoid complaints from outside, but the old AC couldn't handle it, and the door to the smoking room stayed open, so the staff could come and go quicker. You reeked of smoke when you left, just like before."

"This joint's usually solid for breakfas', but not today. Unfriendly greeter, average grub. Been around a while, good rep, but kitchen's slackin' and needs a cheerful face at the door. I'll give 'em another shot down the line."
"Friendly staff. Downhill from there. Room 1122? Don't bother. Train, ice machine, AC/heat unit. No sleep. Peeling wallpaper. Outdated decor. Cold food at lunch. No outlets."

"A thrift store aficionado, I do confess,
And this Goodwill, alas, doth leave me unimpressed.
The scent of grandam's feline friend deceased,
Doth greet mine nostrils, and my spirits depressed.
But, if thou art in search of furniture of yore,
To mend or paint, perchance, this place doth store.
Yet, if thou art in this vicinity,
Pray, visit the one on 20th and Indian School,
Newly built, 'tis clean, and treasures doth hold,
In sooth, a better choice, I doth avow."

"Hark! We dined here at noontide, my friend and I.
I chose the 'Sweet Deal', three dishes for four dollars, a bargain indeed. A humble cheeseburger, crispy onion rings, and a draught to quench my thirst.
But lo! The meal arrived with haste, too swift for my liking. Alas! The burger, a mess it was, o'er-sauced with mustard and ketchup, a sorry sight. The onion rings, a pleasant surprise, well-cooked and crispy still. Yet, the burger, a disappointment, I must confess."

"Pizza joint wasn't half bad. Reviews said their pies were decent, so we gave 'em a shot. Ordered a large thin crust with the works. Crust was more doughy than thin, but it'll do. Spent some time in Italy, know what I mean? This ain't no Palermo crust. Mushrooms tasted straight outta a can. Service was meh, kid taking our order had a face like a sourpuss. Owner seemed friendly enough on the way out, though."

"Heard good things 'bout this joint, so gave it a shot. Ordered Thai beef salad, Asian chicken salad, monster meatballs and spaghetti, grilled salmon. Big letdown. Don't even remember the meatball taste. Spaghetti and salad dressings? Bad news. Rice was rock hard. Salmon was alright, but tiny compared to other plates.

Frozen hot chocolate though? Top-notch. Loved it. Made the whole thing better.

Not sure if we just picked wrong, but not comin' back for the food. Just dessert."

"Sat in heat, waited ten minutes for menu and water. Server didn't glance our way, too busy eyeing passersby. Wine list vanished before we could blink, replaced by a curt query about drinks. Politely pointed out the oversight, but his attitude soured the air. Food followed suit - mediocre caprese, dismal calamari. No flavor, no texture. Not a single expression of gratitude or well-wishing as we departed. Unpleasant experience, won't return. Luna Grossa, indeed."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

I ate at this place and it was edible, but that's about it. They called it sushi, but it was just rice and vegetables rolled up. Not impressed. Won't be back.

"2 stars for decent service, but sushi rice is consistently mushy and falls apart. Kabuki in Cali never has this issue. Given this place multiple chances, but seems like they can't get their sushi together. Work on that Alaskan roll, sushi chefs! Maybe LA locations can help improve quality. Table booths appear dirty, walls are grimy, and glass separators are smudged. Sunshade has sauce stains, and table lights are dusty. Not a clean atmosphere. What's happening, Kabuki LV?" (487 tokens)

"Pray, good sirs and madams, hearken unto my tale,
Of woe and disappointment, at Bravo's did prevail.
A second time, I visited this establishment fair,
With hopes of savoring their culinary flair.

Alas, my first adventure didst end in dismay,
For the grilled chicken salad they served, didst play
The villain's role, with chicken pink as the day.
I sent it back, with haste, and prayed for a better way.

This time, we started with a drink, a sangria rosa,
Too sweet, it was, and more like a daiquiri, I suppose.
I ordered chicken caprese, with hope in my heart,
But alas, the chicken was thin, and tough as art.

The orzo, too, did lack all seasoning, a shame,
For a dish that should delight, did naught but bring me pain.
So here, dear friends, my tale doth end,
With disappointment great, and no chance to amend.

Two stars, I give, for service good and true,
But oh, how I wish, their cooking were anew!"

"Hark! This spot, once dearest to mine heart,
Where bargains flowed like honey from the start.
But lo! The word hath spread, and now 'tis thronged
With eBay sellers, crazed and unbridled.
They swarm, a plague upon this sacred ground,
And with their antics, have made it unsound.
Their ways, so questionable, leave naught to ponder,
For they, in league with store employees, plunder.
Aye, last I saw, they brought them lunch, a woeful sight,
And left me wondering, wherefore their shame doth flight?
I'd rather pay full price, at Nordstrom's gate,
Than suffer thus, such moral degradation's weight."

"A place of pilgrimage, a site of wonder,
This eatery doth claim, yet doth not deliver.
Mediocrity doth reign, in victuals, serve,
And ambiance, that doth leave much to desire.

I do confess, a purse of gold I do possess,
Yet, for quality, I do not hesitate to spend.
But lo, the fare here doth not merit the cost,
A pint of ale, ten silver pieces doth command.

And though the maidens fair, didst catch mine eye,
Alas, their charms, didst not the bill justify.
A steak, with fries, of thirty shillings price,
Doth make me think, of other places, twice as nice."
"Went there recently. Sushi didn't taste as fresh as I remembered. Doubtful about going back."

"Wings? No thanks. Not worth the cash. You get scraps, bones, and dry meat. No drums either. Flavor's lackin', too much salt, and tastes like Panda Express's sweet 'n' sour sauce. What's the point of bein' a chef if you can't make it taste good or fillin'? I got served bones, pretty presentation, and some sauce on the side. Offensive, really. Where's the meat go? Don't know if I'd be more pissed if they threw it away or used it elsewhere, double dippin'."

"It's a decent joint, I reckon. Been goin' there for a bit now, and the staff's always been top-notch. Food's alright, but not exactly somethin' to write home about. Place is startin' to slip, though. Bathrooms ain't exactly spotless, especially if you show up bright 'n early. Wish 'em well, but I've given 'em enough of my hard-earned cash, and it ain't gettin' any better. Sorry, fellas."

"Place used to be good, now it's not. Service still bad, like everyone says. Portions small, prices high. Food quality downhill. Wonton soup, small pot, imitation crab. Spring rolls, cooked outside, frozen inside. Used to like it here, but now it's poor service, no communication, don't care about customers. Can't recommend it no more."

Oh woeful day! A pedicure most vile and base,
Didst leave mine feet in pain and disgrace.
The man who didst mine nails, a patient soul,
Didst pry off old sets, and drilled with great control.
But alas, he cut me with the drill,
And now mine feet do smart and thrill.
Yet, I must confess, mine nails do look well,
Thin and shaped, a sight most fair and swell.
But then, the pedi, oh how it didst fail,
A zombie-like masseuse, with nary a tale.
She scrubbed and cut and filed with some grace,
But when it came to massage, she didst not place,
Her hands upon mine feet, nor didst she rub,
But squeezed and pinched and slapped, oh what a dub.
A strange and weird experience, indeed,
With polish on my cuticles, unclean and freaky deed.
I shall not return, no more, no way,
For such a pedicure, I shall not pay.

"Slammed by Mill for the ASU game, ended up here. Ordered souvlaki - beef and lamb. Lamb was underseasoned, beef had a better taste but chewy and hard to swallow. Spat out a piece, unfortunately. Didn't feel like I got my money's worth. Veg was bland too. People mostly ordered apps, maybe I missed out. Waitress was great, friendly. Extra star for her. Not sure about coming back with other options around."

"Bouchon, a joint I frequent when in Vegas. Last time I was there, in March, I left a comment on their site, haven't heard back, so I'm posting here too. Food's good, prices steep. What got me was the $7 carafe of house water. $21 for three? Come on! You're charging me for tap water at a place where we're already paying premium prices? Shame on you, Bouchon. I didn't ask for anything fancy, just tap water. They adjusted the price, but still, embarrassing in front of my business associates."
"Oil change took too long. Two hours, watched others get served first. Place was clean, staff was friendly, but management was a mess. Not going back."

"Pomo used to be in Scottsdale, serving top-notch Napoletana pizza in a snooty atmosphere. But the downtown location was different. Modern decor, hipster staff, and a disappointing pie that lacked the flavor and quality of the original. Skip it and head to La Piazza Locale instead."

"The joint was alright. Had some laughs with the girls on a birthday bash, but the bar itself wasn't anything special. It was a multi-level spot with decent drinks, but the decor was a bit much. Felt like a cheap imitation of something classy. The chandelier over the bar was nice, but the plastic one hanging from the ceiling looked tacky. Like someone tried to make it look fancy but failed. Reminded me of those Mardi Gras beads you get for showing some skin. Not my cup of tea. There are better places to grab a drink in Vegas."

"MENU CHANGE: Enjoyed the flatbread tapas at happy hour, but last night they replaced it with Matzoh Ball CRACKERS for full price dinner. Not worth it. $10 for crackers and tiny scoops of hummus, bruschetta and tapenade is too much. Friend struggled to eat the flatbread pizza because CRACKERS can't support the weight of toppings and sauce. Server said it was a permanent change. I'll go to one of the other gastro pubs in town or just walk across the street to Firefly for better food. The fresh brewed beer isn't worth it either, too heavy with a syrupy honey taste. Bleh."

"First time at the store, bought a toy chopper for my kid.  Dead battery, had to bring it back.  Manager helped us out, but he was on a call the whole time.  Waited 15, exchange took one.  Poor quality, poor service.  Not a great first impression."

"Owner's a real charmer. Bid they gave my insurance company was the highest, but it was for a full replace job. Didn't need that much work, just some repairs. Insurance company wasn't having it, so they didn't get the gig."

"Flamingo Hotel's got some issues. First, they got this "Go Room" thing. If you don't get it, you're stuck with a dirty, filthy room. Don't matter if you complain, they ain't gonna do nothing about it. We had to move thrice. First time, some other guest was checkin' in while we were still there. Nobody from the hotel gave a damn about our complaint before they stuck another poor soul with the same problem. Carpet's disgusting, it stinks and it's got stains everywhere. You step in the tub after walkin' on that carpet, you'll leave black footprints. No excuse for that kinda filth, and no excuse for ignoring it and shovin' it onto the next guy. Hotel's old and it smells like it too. They're tryin' to fix it up, but they got a long way to go. With all the nice hotels in Vegas, I can't figure out why anyone'd wanna stay here. First and last time for me. Never been treated so poorly. A kennel'd be cleaner. One good thing though, Junius Johnson, Jr. He's a server in the buffet, been there 30 years. Guy's got customer service down pat. He should teach the rest of the staff. My hat's off to him."

"Hark, what news is this? A woeful tale of woe,
A day of sorrow, and naught but grief to show.
The fifth of June, a date most foul and dark,
A day of woe, a night of endless spark.

The crowd, a motley crew of wretches, vile and base,
Did gather 'neath the sun, with naught but ill grace.
No seat, no rest, no respite from the heat,
A small dance floor, and naught but bitter defeat.

Yet, hark, a voice doth cry, a voice of cheer,
A voice of hope, a voice that doth dispel fear.
For though the day be woe, the night shall bring,
A chance to dance, a chance to sing and fling.

So let us not be down, my friends, nor lose,
Our faith in joy, our hope in love's sweet bliss.
For though the day be woe, the night shall bring,
A chance to dance, a chance to sing and fling."

"Chedda, that scoundrel, finally came to town. I tracked him down at Zia Records, eager for a taste of his wares. My husband and I both ordered dirt bags, expecting a cheesy delight. But alas, they were flavorless, lacking the very essence of what makes life worth living. I was crushed, my dreams shattered. The burgers were massive, the buns burnt to a crisp, but the tots were a disaster, tasting like plain mashed potatoes with an odd, unsettling sauce. I wouldn't wish it upon my worst enemy."

"Hark, what news is this? A chance to prove
My words of old, and test the truth anew.
A visit to the gas station, once again,
To see if progress hath been made, and all is well within.

I entered, and beheld the same fair face,
The lady who didst serve me with grace.
I asked for $120, regular, on pump two,
And she, with kindness, said it was ready, anon.

I went without, to fill my tank with cheer,
And chatted with my kin, while gas did flow.
The pump did click, at $100.10, and I didst return,
For change and receipt, and to make my query known.

The lady, with a smile, didst give me my due,
And I, with curiosity, didst ask anew.
"When doth thy car wash plan to reopen?" I said,
And she, with hope, didst answer, "In a month, 'twill be displayed."

I thanked her, and departed, with a heart full of cheer,
For this place, once shunned, doth now show promise, and dear.
Two more visits, I shall make, to test their worth,
And see if progress, indeed, doth bring forth rebirth."

"Aye, when dining at Gordon Ramsay's place,  
One expects a feast fit for a king's embrace.  
But alas, the fare at BURGR didst not impress,  
Despite the chef's renown and great success.  

The wait, a mere 45 minutes, didst seem quite fair,  
For on a Friday night, the crowds didst swarm and stare.  
Yet, when the staff didst appear, their garb didst shock,  
So ill-fitting, unflattering, and quite mock.  

The burgers, too, didst take their sweet time,  
Another 45 minutes, a wait most dire.  
And when they arrived, they were not divine,  
Just average fare, not worth the time or dime.  

My husband's truffle fries, with aioli so strong,  
Didst taste of naught but garlic, all day long.  
I, who cook for my family each night,  
Found the burgers lacking, not a delight.  

The bill, a whopping sum of $150, didst make me wail,  
For two adults, two kids, a price most frail.  
So, we shall not return to BURGR again,  
But Las Vegas holds more Ramsay eats, to gain."

"Tequila Bar, I found it on Yelp. Cheap drinks, that's what I was looking for. Blue Fishbowl, 128oz for $20, hell yeah! But, no fishbowls, just two plastic pitchers. Bummer. Not even any fish in it. Just soda. But, hey, it was fun. Novelty, you know? Nachos looked good, but I just had dinner. Ordered the southwestern corn on the cob. Curious, what makes it southwestern? Waiter says, corn, you want the corn? Yeah, sure. That's all it was, just boiled corn with a pat of butter. For $3, fail."

"Two apps, calamari and shrimp, both good. Salad, too. But main courses? Awful. Tilapia, dry. Asparagus, overcooked. Wife's pasta, a letdown. Kids' meals, just okay. Dirty atmosphere. Waitstaff, inconsistent. Our guy, neglectful. Asked neighboring waitress for refills. Bottom line? Avoid this place."

"Methinks I've visited this dental den of woe
Many a time, and witnessed much to know.
The hygienist doth push for more work,
And cleanings, too, that do but irk.

Two months past, I had the deep-cleaning done,
Yet now my gums do ache and feel undone.
I did espy the dentist but once,
She glanced at me, then quickly did dismiss.

Her smile was fleeting, her eyes did not meet mine,
And when she passed by, she did not deign to divine.
Now, I do seek another dentist, one who'll be kind,
And not treat me like some mere, forgetful mind."

"Dos Gringos, trashy vibes abound. Trailer park theme, questionable at best. Two instances: weak drinks, cheap pours, vodka or rum, no difference. Men's room, vomit stench lingers, staff unresponsive. Fun atmosphere, DJ, crowd, dog-friendly. But, puke and poor drinks kill the mood. Tacos, unappealing. Old-fashioned, perhaps. Prudish, maybe. Turned off, definitely."

"Twas naught but mediocrity that didst greet us upon our entrance,
A weekend afternoon, and games didst consume their attention.
Our service, fair, yet not with warmth or diligence,
As tips, 'twas clear, wouldst be claimed by those of masculine persuasion.

The crispy tacos, a dish of which we hadst heard great things,
Didst fail to impress, alas, our expectations.
In conclusion, 'twas naught but passable,
With other eateries nearby, a wiser choice couldst have been made."

"Crazy Mocha, a joint I wouldn't wish on my worst enemy. Convenient, sure, but that's where the positives end. Chai's too sweet, can't taste the spices, just milky tea. Coffee's weak, like they've been sittin' on it for hours. Service? Meh, not worth mentionin'. WiFi's alright, but that's not enough to save this dump."

"Subway, once a favorite haunt of mine, has since abandoned my beloved chicken pizziola sandwich. Despite my efforts to revive it, they've chosen to discontinue it altogether. In search of a new go-to, I've found myself met with indifference, save for the occasional nod of approval from those who share my taste for the finer things in life. Alas, Subway's Las Vegas locations seem to cater to their own kin, leaving me to wander the streets in search of a worthy substitute. Bring back the pizziola, I say!"
"I'll eat here if a friend insists, but I've gotten diarrhea almost every time. Not worth it. Food's bland and overpriced. Just my opinion, but I know plenty who love it."

"Hark, what's this? A chilled chicken dish, they say? Nay, 'tis but a grilled chicken salad, gone astray. And lo, the fries, they be but tepid, not hot. Yet still, the service here, it doth please me, for 'tis most friendly, and the menu, too, doth stay abreast of hipster fare, with brioche and pretzel buns, and fresh lemonade, to boot. Aye, verily, a pleasant meal, despite the mix-up, 'twas."

"Fried tofu and pork, we didst consume,
With peanut butter dumplings, a curious plume.
Eggplant, too, didst grace our table,
But alas, the fried foods, dry and tough, didst able.
In Montreal, better versions of these dishes thou shalt find,
So, good sir, do not waste thy time, nor thy mind.
For in this neighbourhood, choices are few,
But still, this place, a last resort, doth prove."

"Alack, what woe is this? In Casa Grande, a place of revelry and cheer, doth lie a tavern, once full of life and mirth, now doth resemble a tomb, devoid of joy and vitality. On a Thursday eve, when custom doth dictate a late hour, the patrons few, the waitress doth proclaim, 'Last call, good sirs!' ere the night hath reached its prime. A pox upon the management, whose lack of vision doth stifle the spirit of merriment. The ale, a paltry selection, doth leave much to be desired, save for two tapsters of note, which doth elevate the fare above the common swill. Alas, the clientele, a motley crew, doth not demand a greater variety, and thus, the tavern doth suffer, a shadow of its former self."

"By Jove, fair Monte Carlo, how art thou fallen!
A name once grand, now tarnished, and forlorn.
We sought a room without smoke's pall,
But found ourselves within a chamber foul.
The carpet, cracked, and floor, unclean,
The room, a shambles, and naught but mean.
The hotel, old, and worn with age,
Did little to improve our sour mood.
Indeed, the service, poor, did make us rage.
And so, dear friends, avoid this place,
For Monte Carlo's glory, doth but grace,
The annals of a bygone, forgotten time,
When luxury, and class, did once entwine.
Now, 'tis but a shadow of its former prime,
A pale imitation, of a once-great shrine.
So, heed my words, and seek elsewhere,
For here, doth lie, a bitter, cruel snare."
"Tried out a new groomer in Phoenix. Good reviews, decent prices. Not impressed. Asked for special attention on the dog's tail. Still had mats, face wasn't clean. Won't be back."
"Cold buffet food, can't stand it. Today, everything was cold. Got there too early, maybe. Had to bail, asked for my money back. They gave me a gift card for another time. Nice."
"Peanut butter and jelly cake, hot from the oven. Runny peanut butter, dry cake. Jelly hidden deep within. Grape jelly, warm and unimpressive. Latte, standard fare."

"Methinks 'twas not my fortunate day,
For though I oft do cherish this place,
This last visit did leave me in dismay.
I tried their eggs Benedict, alack,
And found their self-made hollandaise sauce
Did not agree with mine own taste buds.
Next time, I shall stick with my trusty pancakes,
Blueberries, that doth please mine appetite.
My love, he did enjoy his meal,
The wolf pack, it did satisfy him well.
The service, swift and most courteous,
We entered quick, on a busy morn.
Alas, fate did play a cruel trick,
For later in the day, we both did fall ill,
And thus, my mind doth now misgive,
When thinking of dining here again.
Yet still, I hold this place in high esteem,
And hope that next time, all shall be well."
"Place is getting wrecked under new ownership. Staff's overworked, service is slow. Food ain't what it used to be. Memories are all that's left."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

I walked into the joint with high hopes, but they fell short of the hype. LA's got nothing on this place, and I can't imagine how it's considered better. The hot dog casings were hard as rock, and the flavors were lackluster. This spot relies more on its reputation than the quality of its grub.

"Been here twice. First time, great service, mac and cheese, delicious. Today, ridiculous. Called at 5:54, asked about happy hour, yes until 7. Arrived ten minutes later, told no happy hour today. Giving two stars."
"Brunch at its worst. Chain joint in a plaza swarming with families and their noisy broods. Food passable, but not worth the trip."

"This joint didn't impress me much. Not enough options on the menu and my street noodles were just alright. Didn't blow my mind or anything. The only thing worth going back for is the steamed pork buns. That's it. Don't waste your time otherwise."

"Hark! I didst venture to Caramel, forsooth,
Upon the whisperings of its noble worth.
A cozy, wee lounge, neat and plain, it didst seem,
Yet, in sooth, its dimensions didst surprise, in truth.

An Oreo martini, priced at twenty crowns,
Didst tempt my taste, with crumbs of Oreo, profound.
But, alack! The drink, though fair, didst lack,
In worth, the price, which didst my senses shock.

The Bellagio, a place of beauty, doth reign,
Whilst Caramel, a spot, of middling fame.
A wager, of twenty pieces, on the screen,
Didst gain a martini, free, and most serene.

The sports bar, a haven, of cheer and glee,
Didst boast bartenders, of warmth and courtesy."

I came to this joint on a Saturday night, thinkin' I'd have me a good time, 'cause Kaskade was spinnin' his tunes. Bought my tickets online, but the line for folks with tickets was a real doozy. We waited and waited, and by the time I made it to the door, it was a whole hour and a half later. By then, the club was packed, and sure enough, the dance floor was closed. No tables to be found either. So, why keep lettin' people in, if there's nowhere to go? Security was tellin' everyone to move along, but where were they supposed to move to? The club's not exactly huge, ya know? They just kept crammin' people in, but there was nowhere to put 'em. And let me tell you, those stairs we had to go down to get inside? Looked like somethin' outta a bad dream. But hey, Kaskade was killin' it, even though I only got to see a bit of him.

"Food's good, but service is shit. Been here twice, both times service was terrible. Last time, food took an hour, and we still gave 'em their damn 18% tip. Manager said he'd give us a hundred bucks for next time, but that never happened. Pros: decent grub. Cons: shitty service, can't keep their word. Not going back."

"Hark, fair friends! I've visited this place, and also the one in Phoenix, off Ray and the 10. My comrade hath a membership here, and we've pledged to encourage each other to visit more oft. Forsooth, sometimes thou dost need a gentle nudge to reach thy goal! 

This gym, it doth provide the basics, naught flashy or grand. 'Tis but $10 a month, or $20 for all locations, with guests unlimited in number. 

Yet, I am torn betwixt a two-star and three-star rating. Forsooth, I've been a member of 24 hour, with naught but basic amenities, at a fair price. But, alas! This gym lacks a sauna, basketball court, classes, pool, and more, which mine doth possess. And, pray tell, what sorcery doth lie within that loud alarm? A judgment-free gym, they claim, yet an alarm doth sound and flash, should someone drop a weight, grunt, or strive with great effort. Pray, what witchcraft is this? Doth it truly serve a purpose?"

"Rude management, waited over an hour for our car, watched others leave left and right. Mentioned it to several people, got lots of excuses, but they lost our car. Would've been satisfied with a drink, spent over $200 on dinner, no apology. Wrote a letter. Waitstaff was friendly, meal was okay, nothing special, Charlotte has better. Relationships matter, they killed mine with this one. Bottom line, food wasn't worth returning for."

"Methinks my words of woe concerning II Vinao's management were rash and unjust. Forsooth, 'twas but a single day of woe, and lo, the owner doth seek to make amends. Verily, a noble gesture! We shall return anon, and mayhap, with luck, our visit shall be graced with a five-star review. Fear not, dear friends, for I shall keep thee informed of our venture."

"Methinks 'twould be wise to rename this place Lobster Mehhh, forsooth. Its layout doth resemble a food court in a mall, alack. More seating had been better, as at the mall, I do reckon. A lobster roll combo didst I order, with fries and drink beside. The lobster roll, alas, didst not live up to my expectations, for it lacked the customary mayo and scallion mix of a true Maine lobster roll. Instead, a vinegar-based medley didst overpower the natural flavors, to my dismay. The fries, however, didst please mine taste buds, for they were indeed most tasty. The lobster mac and cheese, alack, didst not impress, for though there were lobster chunks upon the surface, naught but a few didst penetrate throughout. Verily, not worth the price of nine dollars and ninety-five cents, I say. Nay, I shall not return, forsooth."

"Fare thee well, good sir! Tis a pity, forsooth,
That hot victuals, when they reach thy table, doth lose their heat.
And, alack! The menu, once full of tasty treats,
Hath been diminished, leaving naught but mediocrity to greet.
But, hark! The din, the clamor, doth pierce mine ears,
A cacophony of shouts and laughter, nigh unbearable, I fear.
No quiet seat, for those who seek a meal in peace,
Doth exist within these walls, where revelry doth never cease.
Alas, our server, with sorrow in his voice, did say,
'Tis thus, my friends, each eve, a tumultuous display.
And so, we leave, with heavy hearts, to find a place,
Where we may dine in calm, and savor every taste."

"I don't get the hype 'bout this place. Folks rave 'bout it, but the grub just ain't that great. Chips 'n' salsa are decent, can't mess that up too much. But my burrito's flavor's lackin', daughter's quesadilla too. 'Hot' salsa tastes like mild, somethin' ain't right. Service is good, bar's got a nice selection, atmosphere's cool. Food? Meh."

"You could easily pass by without notice. Simple tables and booths, open like a deli. Chicken parm sub, per Yelp's advice. A bit dry, but still a decent bite. Not sure I'd get it again. Crinkle-cut fries, nothing special. Good option instead of fast food, but not worth going out of your way."

"Terrible shave at Elliot & Co. Despite the Yelp discount, it wasn't worth the money. I wanted to like the place, but the shave left much to be desired. The haircut was good, but the shave was subpar. Missed spots on my neck and stubble that I could remove with a disposable razor. Nice people and environment, but the shave just wasn't there. Bottom line: not worth it."
"Sally's Beauty Supply. Decent selection, but service was lacking. Manager was friendly, but other staff seemed indifferent. A smile and some enthusiasm go a long way."

"Had lunch at this joint with the fam. Sis-in-law's a big fan, always stops by when she's in town. Place isn't big, but the line was out the door. Ordered the mixed plate - beef, chicken, fish. Beef was meh, chicken was good - tender, moist, de-boned thigh. Fish was nothing special. Portion was huge, couldn't finish it. Maybe try the Mami or Udon noodles next time. Hesitantly recommend it. Would eat there again, but wouldn't make a special trip."

"Stayed at the Excalibur in Vegas last time, met some pals there. Place wasn't cool, overpriced too - $160 a night! First room reeked, like someone poured water on the floor and let it mold for weeks. They gave us another room after an hour, but still too pricey. Casino's in a bad spot, far from the strip. Only close spots are New York New York and MGM. Food's no good either. Not happy we stayed there, won't again."

"Unimpressive joint. Dirty tables, dirty floor. Spilled my drink, and the staff just stood there, watching me clean up the mess. They left a sticky residue behind, and not a single soul bothered to wipe it down."

"Atmosphere was swell. Ordered Chicken Meatloaf, real tasty. Partner had Chicken Royale, flavorless. Side veggies had more zest. Waiter was attentive after grub arrived, but prior, he was MIA. Won't be back."

"Menu looked top-notch, got our hopes up. But what did we get? Frozen hashbrowns, low-grade ingredients. Chicken fried steak tasted like a pig took a smoke break on it. Service was good, but can't say the same for the grub."

"Methinks 'twas partly my fault, good sir,
For not perusing the menu ere I came,
But, by my troth, I was most vexed and vile,
To find such dull fare at this establishment,
Upon a friend's recommendation, I did stake
My hope on tapas, bouillabaisse, and more,
But lo, the menu didst bear naught but tame
Sandwiches, a Cuban and a chicken, alack!
In Vegas, a city that ne'er doth sleep,
I felt ashamed and woeful, my friends to keep
From such a sorry sight, and thus didst creep
Away, with sorrow in mine heart, and deep."

"Bought a house in Mesa, got an evaporative cooler with it. Previous owners said Tempe town lake construction cut into the cooler's usage by three months, thanks to the humidity. And now, the dam's busted, so no lake for us. That's a bummer."
"Place didn't impress me much. Heard good things, still gave it a shot. Long wait, like always. Food was alright, nothin' special. Crowded too. I'd pick Gilbert House down the street any day."

"Sunday brunch? Average. Nothing special. Selection? Lacking. Basic breakfast grub and flatbread pizzas. Upstream sets the bar high, but this place falls short. Food's not cold, but could be hotter. Beer? Watered down. Like their other drinks, the Bloody Mary's weak too. Atmosphere's cool, packed, but overhyped."

"Hark! Located within The Golden Nugget's walls,
On Fremont Street, in downtown Las Vegas' thralls.
I do confess, my expectations were high,
But alas, the fare did not reach the sky.

The drinks, they were good, I must admit,
The service, too, was quite fit.
But oh, the food, it left me cold,
The fish and chips, in oil they were drowned.
The 'tempura' lobster, more like funnel cake,
A mockery, a sham, a culinary fake.

In Las Vegas, there be better choices,
More affordable, with greater voices.
So live it up, and let your spirit soar,
For in this city, all things are possible, and more."

"Burgers? No love here. Like 'em, but not lovin' 'em. Food takes ages, medium burger's well done. Sauces are cool, fries too. Better burger at Serendipity, no contest. Overpriced Carl's Jr., Plymouth's pride. Don't bother, frozen turkey patty's the same. Variety of fry flavors and cuts, that's nice."

"A plague upon the menu of Buraka,
For it doth lack in variety and depth.
Though veg options there be, in fairness,
'Tis not enough to make up for the dearth.

No sampler platters for one, alas,
But a two-entree choice, at a higher cost,
And so I chose the misir wot and beans,
Both spicy, or so the menu did boast.

But lo, the spice did not live up,
Nor did the flavors, sad to say.
Injera, usually a delight, did fail,
Leaving me with naught but dismay.

Hot sauce came forth, a saving grace,
But still, I expected more from the place.
Alas, the ambiance and patio dining,
Could not make up for the lack of flavor shining."

"I ain't no Beatles fan, so I wasn't exactly pumped for this show. Our seats were decent, but the venue's huge and the 360-degree stage meant we might miss some action. Cirque tried to make up for it with stuff happening on both sides, but it was just too much for me. The soundtrack was solid, though - classic tunes, you know? The acrobats were alright, but nothing special. My buddy dug it, but I was underwhelmed. So, if you're a Beatles diehard, go for it. If you're a Cirque enthusiast, there are better options."

"Hark! A word of warning, good sirs and madams,
Concerning the meeting halls of this fair place,
Forsooth, I speak not of the guest chambers,
But of the space where conferences doth take their pace.

A two-day training didst I attend, my friends,
And, alas! The lack of power outlets didst offend.
The attendees, in number great, didst vie for few,
Their devices to charge, their work to pursue.

Moreover, on the first day, a foul stench didst fill,
The building, with a pungent smell of sewage and ill.
The property, in vain, didst try to abate,
The odor, which didst linger, causing discomfort and hate.

In conclusion, fair readers, heed my words,
When choosing this place, beware of the dearth of power.
And pray, good sirs, that the plumbing doth function well,
Lest ye be forced to suffer, as we didst, in hell."

"Methinks I was dismay'd, forsooth,
By order of kare-kare, I didst choose,
Though meat was tender, veggies didst droop,
In sogginess, they didst lose their charm.

Lechon kawali, a dish of might,
Didst come with gravy, rice in sight,
A pleasant treat, indeed, 'twas so,
And thus, my hopes didst start anew.

Yet, alack, the heat didst bear down,
Upon that day, most sweltering, frown,
The A/C, in vain, didst cease to blow,
A trial, indeed, for those who didst know.

Still, methinks I shall give them another chance,
For though the meal didst not enthrall,
Their efforts, in truth, didst merit praise,
And thus, my heart doth sing their praise."

"Hark, my dear friend, lend me thine ear,
For I have tales to tell of woe and cheer.
Of M Resort, a place of rest and play,
Where rooms are grand, and views do sway.
The architecture, a marvel to behold,
A sight to see, worth more than gold.
And prices, fair and reasonable,
A bargain, one might say, quite sensible.
But lo, a shuttle, they do claim,
From airport, free, with no delay or shame.
Check schedule, ere thou book thy flight,
Lest wait two hours, or perhaps three, in plight.
Taxi, forty dollars, without a tip,
A price, some might say, quite steep.
Complimentary, they say, with a grin,
Two for one, a deal, but not quite win.
Buffet, a waste of time, alas,
Fifteen minutes, four feet, what a task!
Pool, a beauty, but closed, alack,
Till March, a date, far off, on the attack.
Hostile Grape, a place to quench thy thirst,
Closed three days, a week, in worst.
Shop, a desire, a dream, a hope,
Rent a car, a must, a scope.
Green Valley Ranch, South Point, a choice,
Next time, a try, a voice, a rejoice."
"Good eatery. Cheap. Beer. Nice spot. Shame about the grime. Carne asada tasty. Service adequate. Dirty, though. Kitchen likely worse."

"Hark! In yonder Plaza, there doth lie  
A diner known far and wide,  
Where portions are fit for sumo wrestlers,  
And competitive eaters do delight.  

'Tis called Hash House A Go Go,  
A place where quantity doth reign supreme,  
And quality doth take a back seat,  
In this temple of culinary excess.  

We didst venture forth to try their fare,  
And sampled their Fried Chicken and Waffles rare,  
But alas! The chicken lacked juice and zest,  
And waffles failed to impress,  
For they didst not possess a bacon-like flavor,  
And left us wishing for more savory bits.  

Next, we didst attempt their Fried Chicken Benedict,  
A dish most curious and quite perplexing,  
For 'twas a towering stack of mashed potatoes,  
Beneath a bed of eggs and bacon,  
With spinach, tomato, and mozzarella cheese,  
All jumbled together in chaotic ease.  

But lo! The House Salad didst prove a disappointment,  
A mere medley of bland iceberg lettuce,  
No special touch or flair didst it possess,  
Just a humdrum mix of leaves, alas!  

So if thou art in search of a hearty meal,  
To share with friend or loved one,  
Come to Hash House A Go Go,  
And revel in its diner charm,  
But beware, lest thou be overwhelmed  
By portion sizes great and grand!"

"Terrible crepe experience. Ordered cheese and prosciutto, but it was thick and doughy, not hot enough. Prosciutto was too strong, couldn't cut it with the flimsy fork they gave me. My BF's veggie crepe was also doughy and thick. Coffee was awful. Won't return. Parking is easy and free in the Paris parking structure. Place was busy later on, don't know why. Employees' stereotypical Parisian outfits were amusing."

"Went to this place three times now. First time, a year ago, with two buddies. We hit the walk-up counter since the wait for a table was an hour. Ordered small frozen hot chocolates. Not impressed. Tasted like a chocolate shake with sprinkles. Maybe it's better inside? Don't know. 

Second time, met some pals in town. They were having dinner (I didn't eat, just had a snack). Food looked great, portions decent. 

Third time, few weeks ago, with my sis and some friends. Ordered frozen hot chocolates. My sis got a large one to share, but it was way too much. Service was meh - cashier slow, drink maker overwhelmed. Maybe I'll give it another shot, wait it out, and eat inside."

"Verily, a grave mistake was made when they didst change the recipes. Twice have I returned since new ownership didst take hold, and verily, I must confess, the service hath suffered greatly. In sooth, the workers were pleasant and kind, but alas, their efforts didst not suffice to make up for the lacking in quality. Methinks they shall require another chance to prove themselves, lest they wish to lose a loyal customer such as myself."

"Peking duck, a dish most fair,
But easy to prepare, I do declare.
Walnut prawns, a sweet delight,
A dessert, indeed, and not a bite.
Crab, a flavor strong and bold,
Like licking ashes, full of gold.
Overcooked, alas, a shame to see,
A dish that once did please, now ruined be.
Service, gentle men, with grace,
But stuck in a place, without a trace.
Of worth, their efforts did impart,
But food, a letdown, a heavy heart.
This morn, I pay the price,
For eating such, a foolish vice."

"Bountiful Baskets, a year of baskets, and the quality's slipping away. Was never great, but now it's really gone downhill. Produce goes bad fast, too much of it. Same old apples and lettuce every week, got tired of 'em. Bought a case of honeycrisps, thought they'd be sweet, but they were small and went bad quick. Maybe my fault, shoulda checked 'em out sooner. Bountiful's all about quantity, that's their thing. But I'm done with it, time to look into something else."

"A hour didst pass, ere our victuals did arrive,
In a place with a pleasant view, and atmosphere quite jolly.
But alas, the blueberry muffins, didst disappoint,
Dry and flavorless, they didst not impress.

The biscuits and gravy, were quite satisfactory,
Yet, a bit more meat, wouldst have been welcome, verily.
The Carne asada burrito, didst lack in zest,
And the sandwich, made of French toast, didst prove the best.

Yet, not the most impressive, of culinary delights,
Still, we shall return, to this place, with all its charms,
For despite its flaws, 'twas a pleasant sight,
And who knows? Mayhap next time, the food shall be divine."

This joint wasn't worth a damn. The opener was the only decent thing about it. If he hadn't been there, I might've walked out. Thirty-nine bucks for an hour show? Ridiculous. In New York, it's twenty-five bucks for two and a half hours. The service was terrible too. Couldn't even get a drink. They had a two-drink maximum, but it felt like they were trying to limit us to one drink per visit. Waitress took forever to come back and demanded payment upfront. What a joke. Wednesday night or not, that price tag is too high for such a crappy experience. My advice? Avoid this dump and wait for a weekend if you want some real comedy.

Moe's serves unremarkable grub. It doesn't hold a candle to others in its class—Qdoba, Chipotle, et al. The victuals were fresh, but lacked pizzazz. Burritos were puny, with scant fillings. My main gripe was the price. No way a burrito of that size, with that meager amount of rice, beans, and meat, should cost north of seven bucks for the regular size. I've had larger, tastier burritos for around five bucks. A small soda for two-fifty? Ridiculous (free refills, though).

You do get chips and salsa with your order. The chips were decent. Salsa, just okay. One strange thing: my wife ordered a Triple Lindy burrito in a bowl. It came in a white box. When you try to toss it, you can't fit the box in the trash can due to its odd design. Brainiac move...

Amusing names for their burritos—Homewrecker, Art Vandelay, etc. Good stuff! Moe's won't be near the top of my list for returns. Better options abound. Rating: 2.5.

"Food's good, but service is horse shit. Third time here and it's the same story. Long wait for grub, then they bring out the wrong order. You ask for a bowl, they take their sweet time, and when it finally arrives, it's still not right. Management? Don't make me laugh. They don't give a damn about customer satisfaction. Just grab your food to go and avoid the hassle."

"Sushi Crescent and Sushi St-Denis, owned by the same folks, I gotta say this one's my least favorite. Service is near nonexistent, which is a problem in an all-you-can-eat joint. Fish doesn't taste fresh and the staff couldn't care less. If you're hankerin' for sushi, walk five minutes further and fill your belly at Sushi Crescent. I know it's the same owners, but I've never had issues there."

"July 4th, we showed up early for our reservation. Place was packed, tables empty. Waited over 20 minutes to be seated. Hostess said they were still seating folks from 20 minutes before our time. Got an outside table, finally got water 10 minutes later. Dinner was mediocre. Hubby had seafood, some clams weren't open, no pasta. Daughter's pasta was okay, sauce was good. I had fatty lemon chicken. Asked for breadsticks, never got 'em. Outside, steamers were overwhelming, couldn't see, and my daughter got drenched."
"Food, barely mediocre. Beer, warm. Greasy, bland fare. Fast food, better. Half the price, too."

"Spent a weekend, didn't enjoy it. Marriott Rewards member, got better service at a Fairfield. Room wasn't cleaned, called twice. Light switches were busted, all or nothing. Elevator access was a joke, key card often failed. No bill portfolio, despite several calls. System down, left a message elsewhere. Skip this place."

"Alack, what woe is this, that e'er doth plague
Our postal services, with troubles great?
The Automated Postal Center, a boon indeed,
Doth save us time, and ease our every deed.
But lo, the hopper, where packages doth lay,
Doth oftentimes fill up, and doth bar the way.
I've rung the bell, and banged upon the door,
And tried to warn the counter folk, yet naught but silence doth ensue.
Why doth it seem, that they do not regard
Our needs, nor heed our urgent calls?
'Tis true, the APC doth break, and falter too,
Leaving us to wait, in long, tedious queues.
And when at last, my turn doth come,
The worker doth reveal, a lack of knowledge, most dire.
She knew not of the fault, that doth impede
Our progress, and doth cause such frustration and ire.
Oh, how I wish, that they would mend their ways,
And show some care, for those who doth pay.
For if they do not, alas, 'twill be the end,
Of this fine service, that doth now offend."

"Hark! I hadst heard tell of Rossario's feast,
A place where Italian cuisine didst reign supreme.
But alas, my friends, I must confess,
My visit there didst leave me in disdain.

I ordered lasagne, a dish most fine,
But what they brought me, oh how vile!
Limp noodles, drenched in sauce, didst cling
To mushrooms, lifeless, void of zest.
Not lasagne, nay, but some foul jest.

My husband, hailing from Italy's shore,
Didst choose the chicken Puttanesca, a dish once more.
Two bites he took, then cast aside,
With sorrow in his eyes, he didst abide.
Even the salad, once a simple delight,
Didst fail to please, a woeful sight.

In conclusion, dear friends, I say,
Rossario's, a place to flee away.
For in their cooking, there doth lie
A bitter taste, that doth not die."
"Busy joint, worn-out gear. Didn't dig it."

"High hopes for this place, thought it'd be like Salt River. Visited last night, didn't quite live up. Prices for swag and snacks, ridiculous. But the real issue, the scoreboard. Sitting lower level, first base side, couldn't read it. Too small, not well lit at night, third taken up by ads, no stats for batters, lineup on left side useless. Parking lot, no signs for exit, entrance blocked. Never seen a park without distance signs. Disappointing."

"Alack, my friends, I must confess,
The indoor ride, a disappointment, did possess.
A gondola we shared, with strangers, dull and grey,
Their silence, a plague, did make the journey stay.
And lo, a wart, so large and foul,
Did grace the temple of one, most uncool.
Um, verily, I say, 'twas not a sight to see.
But praise be, to the gondolier, so free,
His voice, so sweet, his spirit, full of cheer,
He made the ride, almost, quite dear.
But alas, the ride itself, a sham,
Not worth the cost, or the expected jam.
At the turnaround, a thought did cross my mind,
'Tis but a trifle, not worth the time.
Outdoor ride, they say, is better, by far,
So take my advice, and choose that, my dear.
Forget the indoor, 'tis but a waste,
Of time and gold, in haste."

"Open all night, this joint gets two stars, tops. I only hit it up when the others are closed, but even then, it's a crapshoot. Overpriced and the rent-a-cop'security' guys tail me like a bad habit. Limited pickings too."

"Methinks I do not oft frequent chain eateries,
And least of all, a steakhouse of renown.
Yet, in fair Las Vegas, I didst find myself
At Outback Steakhouse, a place of some repute.

A business trip of haste and scant duration,
Didst lead me thither, with naught but steak in mind.
My comrades, weary of the strip's hubbub,
Didst seek a meal most convenient and quick.

An Outback near the Outlet Mall, I chanced upon,
And thus, my settled weariness didst decide.
Six years had passed since last I stepped within,
And lo, the memories of yore didst abide.

The sirloin, six ounces of its finest cut,
Was cooked to perfection, as was the salad neat.
The service, too, was pleasant and most kind,
Though not of haute cuisine, yet still quite meet.

Farewell, Outback, till next we dine,
In six years' time, or perhaps sooner, who can tell?"
"Food's alright, prices ain't bad. Got a deal from Groupon, so it was a good score. Calamari was good, rest was meh. Place looked nice, good lightin' for a date. Server was top-notch."

"Airport's seen better days. Few healthy grub options, couple oxygen bars gatherin' dust. Bathrooms, not exactly spotless. Some corporate charging stations, but they're usually packed. Folks sittin' on floors, fightin' for a spot. Unless you're headed to or leavin' LV, better places to kill time."

"Food was passable, service was poor. Went for Christmas Eve dinner, reserved at 11pm through OpenTable, but waitstaff claimed they closed at midnight. Rushed our meal, which was a mistake - the staff grew increasingly impatient and rude. Most dishes didn't live up to the hype, according to other Yelp reviews. Maybe it was due to the holiday."
"Terrible joint. Ordered their famous murg tikka, chicken tasted like frozen crap. Paneer makhani? Subpar. Naan was decent, but that's about it. Avoid this dump."

"Two visits, same result: poor service. Bartender Emmanuel, friendly and personable, saved the day. He gave us more attention in eight minutes at the bar than our waiter did in 45 minutes at the table. That's not how you treat customers. You pretend to like your job, even when you don't. Our waiter didn't get that memo. His inattention bordered on neglect. He came by three times, took our orders, and brought the check. Like he wanted us to leave. The busser checked on us more often. Not worth the trip if you're coming from afar. Sit at the bar, avoid the waitstaff."
"Owner swings by, spittin' apologies. Night's a bust. Service drags, pizza's mediocre at best. Noise level's off the charts."

"Respiratory Convention brought me here, needed a place to crash that wasn't gonna eat up my whole day. Got a room, not bad, bed's alright. But man, the smoke's still sneakin' in, even though it's supposed to be a non-smokin' joint. What can you do, it's Vegas, right? And then there's the resort fees, what a joke. Thought I was gettin' a good deal, but nope, they're just pirates at Treasure Island, takin' your loot."

"Hark! What's this? A feast fit for a king,
With BBQ that doth please the palate's sing.
The sides, they do abound, a wondrous sight,
And biscuits, oh so fluffy and bright.

But alack! The prices, they do cause dismay,
For they be steep, and make one pause and pray.
Yet fear not, friends, for sharing doth make sense,
And leaves thee full, with coin still in thy purse.

Now, Lucille's, a place of note, doth earn
Two stars, for biscuits and cornbread that doth learn.
Tri-tip and peanut slaw, they doth impress,
But brisket and mac 'n' cheese, they doth depress.

In another land, a fourth star I would give,
But here, where BBQ reigns, 'tis hard to live.
Yet still, Lucille's doth stand, a worthy sight,
For those who seek a feast, both day and night."

"A place of wonder, full of games and delight,
With carousel bar, a circus in sight.
But alas, 'tis dirty, run down, and ill-planned,
No place to rest, nor safe to hand.
I warn my friends, who seek to tarry,
To avoid the cheap rates, lest they marry.
For there's a reason why they're so low,
And that, my friends, you soon shall know."

"Hark, good sirs, for thirty years and more,
I've used the irrigation services of SRP,
And found their people most dedicated, kind,
Ever willing to help, with minds inclined
To solve the issues that did oft arise,
Like dead animals in canals, diverse and wise.

But alas, dear friends, those days are gone,
For now, the SRP's become a different throng,
With guards and closets, phones and signs,
That do beset the customer, in such dire straits.
The Zanjeros, once so helpful, now
Are reduced to babysitting computers, how
The Water Master system doth prevail,
But inconsistent flows, it doth entail.

Oh, woe is me, a loyal customer,
To see the change, so drastic and severe,
In thee, SRP, once great, now fallen,
A prison-like facility, with naught but wailin.
So here I'll stay, and pay my due,
But sorrow fills my heart, for what thou art,
A faceless utility, with naught but spite,
For those who once did cherish thee, with all thy might."

"Hark, a craving for BBQ didst beset mine appetite,
And so, I sought out a place to sate my desire.
Aye, $35 worth of victuals didst I order, full of hope,
But alas, most of it didst not meet mine expectations.
The pulled pork, aye, 'twas passable, I do confess,
But the brisket, oh nay, 'twas but a mediocre mess.
The chicken, verily, 'twas but a middling fare,
And the beans, oh woe, they were undercooked, I swear.
Away, I didst throw them, with nary a qualm or care.
The sauces, aye, they were decent, I must allow,
But alack, the rest, oh nay, 'twas but a sorry show.
I didst ask mine father-in-law to make some brisket,
For none couldst I find, who couldst cook it, Southern-style, so neat.
The staff, aye, they were pleasant, full of cheer,
And the place, clean, both within and without, I do declare.
But the portions, alas, they were small, I must confess,
And so, mine appetite, it was not fully blessed."

"Hark, what news is this? A cheesteak, thou say?
In Philly's land, where such delights doth sway,
I chanced upon a place, Pop's, they call,
Whose look, to Pat's, did bear a striking pall.

A steak, with whiz, onions, and peppers, I did choose,
But, alas, the flavor, they did forget, I suppose.
All bland, it was, and not a morsel could I taste,
Betwixt the meat and onions, a difference, there was none to trace.
The bread, too, did disappoint, soft and lacking bite,
No Amoroso, it did not resemble, in the slightest plight.

Yet, the patio, fair and bright, did please mine eyes,
And sweet potato fries, a delightful surprise.
So, though the food may fail, the atmosphere doth make,
A visit, still, to Pop's, for the patio's sake, I would partake."

"Methinks 'twas my first time at Culvers, a humble abode of victuals,
No different from Wendy's or any other fodder for the masses, I reckon.
Aye, the fare was naught but common, a bit lackluster, mayhap,
Yet, for a quick bite, 'twill serve, an it please thee, good sir."

I walked into the ship to store department to grab something, but the register was closed. Next to it was layway, and there were five people in line. The gent at the register said the other lane was closed. I told him to call for help, since I wasn't there for layway. Two other ladies in line agreed, saying they were waiting too, since no one would come help him. We were near the employee back entrance, so I told someone to go call someone to help him out. Within two minutes, someone showed up. They were still slow, but not as bad as before. It took almost thirty minutes from the time I arrived to when I finally got my two items. They let me pull around back to pick them up, since they were too big to wheel through the store on a flatbed cart. Not terrible service, but definitely a lack of help for customers.
"Sandwich was a bust. Not impressed. Small meat, slice of cheese, stock dressing. Hype? Don't see it. Gotta try again."

"Lived in the hood, ate here for years. Takeout, dine-in, didn't matter. Been downhill six months now. Refried beans? Canned. Homemade, canned, know the diff. Cheese Crisp, lackin', oily. Shredded beef taco, fatty. Used to be good. Now? Nah. Goin' back to Sylvia's, Macayo's. Better food, not from a can."

"Place was overrated. Service was lackin'. Food was mediocre. Sweet potato tempura and king crab California roll were dry and overpriced. Took 'em 30 minutes to bring the check. Didn't tip. Not impressed."

"Las Vegas, a city of excess, yet we found ourselves yearning for more. My wife and I, sushi lovers, stumbled upon a restaurant that caught our eye. Fresh seafood, an impressive drink menu, but the portions, small. A $72 tab, with a tip, left us both unsatisfied. We hastened to find sustenance before the night's entertainment."
