"Verily, I concur with many a review I've perused upon this site. 'Tis not the Wahoo's of yore, in fair California. The fish, alas, doth lack the moisture of days past, and the green sauce they proffer doth resemble a wretched mixture of sour cream and herbs. 

I have visited this establishment several times, and on one occasion, a certain bartender didst leave much to be desired. Her name escapes me, but her manner of service didst not. Whilst watching a fight in a mostly empty bar, she didst arrive on her shift and turn down the volume on the telly, changing the channel to some base reality show. I requested its return, but my plea didst fall upon deaf ears. 

On at least two other eves, her service didst suffer, forsooth, due to her being overly engrossed in conversation with a patron, leaving us neglected and unserved. I didst finally inform her that we wouldst depart without payment, that she might attend to her duties. 

Beware this place, good sirs and madams, lest ye desire a mediocre fish taco with scant regard for service."

"We hit up this market, a Best of Las Vegas joint, for breakfast on a recent morning. It was like a cheaper Whole Foods. We ordered at the counter and chilled at a table in the piano room till the grub arrived. We got some easy over eggs with bacon, wheat toast, and home fries. The ingredients were solid, but the prices were steep and the cooking was subpar. The toast was soft, the bacon was soggy, the potatoes were tired, and the egg whites were watery."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst lead me here,
To this most vile and wretched place, so dear?
A buffet, they called it, with a spread so wide,
But all the world's cuisine, could not hide,
The bitter taste of disappointment, that doth cling,
Like a dark cloud, to my soul, and doth sting.

The price, so steep, the food, but mediocre,
And service, poor, with nary a endearing feature.
Our waitress, fair, but distant, cold,
Didst pour our juice, then vanished, like a ghost, so bold.

A sense of dejavu, that doth haunt me still,
For I have been, to this same buffet, at will.
At Aladdin, it was, in days of yore,
But now, at Planet Hollywood, 'tis a bore.
No line, didst form, for this most wretched feast,
For all, didst know, its quality, so least.

Oh, how I wish, I hadst not come,
To waste my brunch, on such a sorry sum.
But alas, 'tis done, and now I must,
Endure the memory, of this most foul and unjust."
"Tacos, once again, failed to impress. Mushy centers, questionable fryer time, and subpar guacamole. Pricey too, six-fifty with tax. Not worth it, even after a few drinks."

"O, fair Aureole! How lovely art thou to behold,
Thy victuals, most divine! Yet, alas, thy service doth falter,
Like a ship without a rudder, lost at sea.
Reservations made at nine and thirty, we didst arrive,
And waited, waited, waited, for our turn to dine.
The waiter, he didst disappear, leaving us to ponder,
Their tablet, broken, with nary a drop of wine to savor.
He returned, some twenty minutes passed, with a scowl upon his face,
As if we were to blame for the device's disgrace.
Then, four times, he warned us, 'We'll be closing soon,'
As if we were not aware, the hour grew late, the moon full.
Food, oh food, how magnanimous! So very, very good!
But, alas, the pressure, to hasten and depart, didst leave a foul mood.
No more, dear Aureole, shall we return, forsooth!"

This Terrible's, near my humble abode,
I visit oft for ale, upon my road.
A car wash, once I didst use, but alas,
The cost, too steep, for such a poor show.

Gas, I do not purchase, for 'tis dear,
Compared to other stations, near and far.
The shop, with goods of diverse kind,
Doth offer fair prices, for all to find.

The beer cave, oh how grand,
With brews so cold, 'tis a wondrous land.
But parking, alack, doth pose a test,
Crowded and cramped, with nary a nest.

Employees, of minimum wage, they be,
Yet still, their service, doth meet decree.
For though the price may be a tad high,
I shall return, when ale doth call me nigh.
"Good eatery, usually. Tonight? Forget it. Group dinner, shitty service. First waiter, space cadet. Second waitress, sourpuss. Grub, meh. Used to be better."

"Werner Enterprises truckers come here. I'm one of 'em. It's got the essentials we need. I've seen worse digs. If you're looking for luxury, keep moving. Two-star joint at best. Plenty of grub nearby though."

"This place, methinks, doth lack a certain je ne sais quoi,
The victuals, passable, yet naught to write home about,
The servers, slow of foot, as if their very souls didst languish,
And tables, cramped and close, as if in haste to share a secret,
Alack, poor show, indeed, and naught but woe and disappointment doth it bring."
"Food was fair, not the best. Haven't been there in near a year. Bill came, understood why. Two-fifty for OJ, no free refills. Food was passable, but better elsewhere."

"Craved wings, drove for 'em. Good, but rubs too salty. Had Louisiana, Parmesan Garlic. Ate Louisiana, not Parmesan. Parmesan cheese smelled like spoiled dishrag. Stunk up my ride home. Tossed it straight in the trash. Won't be back. Staff got no sense of smell?"

"Alack, my lads, what folly led us here,
To this, the nearest buffet, so dear?
Forsooth, the price we paid, a sum most great,
Could've bought us passes, for a longer treat.

But still, we sat, and waited for our feast,
And when our server came, our thirst he did quest.
We made our choices, from the limited fare,
And found some joy, in grilled meats so rare.

Short rib tacos, sushi, and beef Wellington too,
Were the bright spots, in a meal most woe.
But alas, the rest, did leave us cold,
Mini churros, hard, and ice cream, old.

Our server, helpful, but our drinks, he did confound,
So full, yet dissatisfied, we rose from ground.
Away, my lads, let's not return again,
For better fare, our coin we shall maintain."

"Methinks I was ill-advised to partake in this Vegas buffet, forsooth. For in my mind, there be two sorts of folk: those who delight in such feasts, and those who do not. Alas, I am of the latter persuasion, and the mere thought of buffets doth bring to mind the unpleasant memories of college mess halls. Yet, we didst venture forth to this Saturday brunch, perchance to find some culinary delight.

The spread before us didst seem quite varied, with dishes of Asian, Italian, seafood, pizza, breakfast, and more. My omelet, a humble dish, didst prove the highlight of the meal, methought. The rest of the fare didst leave me somewhat unimpressed, for I couldst not partake of the meat. My betrothed, however, didst venture forth with greater zeal, yet found the victuals to be naught but mediocre. In sooth, we both didst prefer the notion of dining at a finer establishment, where quality doth surpass quantity. Alas, 'twas not meant to be, and thus our experience didst end in disappointment."

"Rave reviews, huh? Crowded, you say? What the hell, I thought. Pros: cheap. Cons: subpar food, undercooked pork, fake cheese enchiladas, stale marshmallows. And don't even get me started on the freakishly obese people. Woman, that was your fifth cotton candy."

"In person, the staff doth seem friendly and helpful,
But o'er the phone, they doth not even bother,
They've called me to come early, only to switch doctors on me,
The office, alas, is not very clean,
I had hoped ne'er to return, but they would not respond,
To my prescription refill requests, and so I had to go,
In person, to fix the situation, they did tell me,
That every three months, I must come in to be seen,
But when I questioned this, they did fold and give me my script,
It seems they wish to force thee to have much done,
To line their pockets with thy insurance, perchance,
I am back to hoping ne'er to need to go again."

"Methinks I didst try this takeaway of late,
On Monday last, with eager expectation.
Kung Po chicken, I didst order, with haste,
But found it not to my liking, in sooth.

The chicken, breaded it was, and the sauce,
Sticky and sweet, like a sour sauce, perchance?
Authentic Chinese, it didst not resemble,
And the price, it didst exceed my reckoning.

Alas, I shall not return to this place,
For Leith Walk's takeaways, hold my grace.
Therefore, good sirs, heed my words of woe,
And seek thy meals from elsewhere, anon."

"Pancho Villa's been kickin' around for a bit, gets enough business to keep the lights on, but I ain't exactly sure why. Had better chili at other joints, and Illegal Jack's too. Enchiladas and fajitas? Meh, they were lackin' somethin'. Friend told me they make a killer margarita, but if I gotta be drunk to enjoy the grub, ain't worth the restaurant prices."
"Pizza wasn't half bad, but the deal stunk. Prices always steep at Dominos. Medium 2-topper a raw deal. Low rating for price versus quality, value."

"Pool's clean, architecture's neat. But why concrete the deckin' in this heat? Slippery, hot. Someone slipped, hit their head, ambulance came. Lifeguards outnumber guests three to one. When someone gets hurt, all guards blow whistles, corral everyone outta the pool, no exceptions. Not even for kids or towels. Ridiculous. Won't be back."

"This joint's way overpriced for what you get. Sure, the waiter was polite and all, but for the money we spent? Nah. Food was decent, not great. But hey, when you're shelling out over a hundred bucks a pop, you expect more. Like, exceptional grub and top-notch service. Instead, we got lukewarm dishes and tiny portions. And don't even get me started on the unisex bathrooms. People were lining up just to use 'em. All in all, this place ain't worth the cash. It's just an average spot with some fancy presentation."
"Service was a bust. Girl behind counter gave me the cold shoulder. Treated others with a smile, but not me. What did I do to deserve the frost?"

"A side of Mac n cheese we did order, fair sir,
As appetizer, forsooth, to start the feast.
And, lo, the fish doth come, upon a plate,
With salads, too, to make our hunger sate.

A cup of clam chowder, hot and steaming,
Didst arrive, and with it, our souls were warming.
The salads came, and then, in quick succession,
The Mac and cheese, a wondrous, tasty fusion.

We laughed and joked, in merriment,
At how the word "appetizer" doth seem a puzzlement.
Our entrees came, and oh, what a sight,
So many plates, the waiter did take flight.

A joke, he made, of all the plates we had,
But I, in jest, did say, "Pray tell, art thou mad?"
For water, we did ask, and waited long,
And for salt, pepper, and the bill, we did wrong.

Friendly, the servers were, in truth,
But leadership, alas, doth lack their youth.
A second chance, we shall give, anon,
For local places, we do strive to show.

But, pray, address these issues of service,
For 'tis a shame, such strife to endure, in verse."

"Alack, how times have changed! This place, once fair and bright,
Hath now descended downward, nigh to night.
Our waiter, slow to greet, didst take his time,
Twenty-seven minutes passed, ere he didst incline
To take our order, and with speed, we prayed,
Lest he disappear, and leave us dismayed.
The menu, once diverse, hath now been pared,
Leaving few options, and those, not well prepared.
I had the bbq chicken flatbread, alas,
The chicken, dark and lean, with fat and gristle, was.
A burger, perchance, might still be worth the fray,
But this dish, sadly, didst not pass the day.
Management, it seems, doth suffer here,
And staff, in turn, doth falter, and appear
To lack the zeal, that once didst make this place
A worthy start, in this fair city's race.
We shall not return, but hope, in time,
They mend their ways, and regain former prime."
"I requested delivery. No issues, arrived in 30-40 minutes. Just ordered rolls. Salmon was flavorless, California rolls were mediocre. Paid the delivery woman, she left without a word. Meh."
"Pho? Don't know what that is. Smells off, tastes worse. Asked for extra veggies, got less than usual. Seat's torn up, feels like sitting on razor blades. Not worth it."

"Mexican joint, Phoenix. Unremarkable. Subpar grub. Two enchiladas, one chicken, one beef. Meh. Dark brown sauce, questionable. Beef sauce, forgettable. Tacos, no bueno. Dead Friday at 12:30pm. Punch machines idle, kiddo scootering, skeleton crew. Doubtful about their future."

"Been here twice. Service stinks. Slow as hell. Don't know if they're short-staffed or what, but it's painful. Food's mediocre. Bar food, nothing special. Could be great, but they gotta step up their game. Competition's fierce next door."

"Singing cooks mean savory grub. Staff treats you like family. Decor's a bit drab, but potential abounds. 

Fresh pico de gallo's got spice, but saltiness overpowers. Corn chips suffer. 

Flour tortillas, six ingredients. Simple. Guacamole shouldn't contain milk. Rice, too small, dries fast. Cheese crisp lacks crunch. Green chili strips, fresh. 

Decor needs work. Beer flags, mariachi hats, throw rugs, caballeros, and damas don't cut it. Mirrored walls scream '80s. 

Note my corn allergy limits menu options. Great local vibe. Facelift needed."

"Espresso's too damn pricey here. I mean, it's just too much. Went to Handsome Roasters, had a double pulled by the owner himself, and it was still cheaper than JPH. That's wild, right? LA's got some crazy prices. Went to Barista in Portland, had a double from an award-winning barista, and it was still cheaper. Same with Coava, Stumptown, and The Refinery. They're all fancy, but not as expensive as JPH. Just saying, you guys are kinda pretentious, but I still like to come here and blow some cash every now and then. Maybe it's the rent, maybe it's all the college kids with trust funds or loans feeding their coffee habits. Let's be real, yeah? PS - Love that you guys serve LADRO, haven't seen 'em in a while. They're cute."

"Blue Wasabi. Avoid it. Inflated reviews, average food. Good service, sure. Decent drinks, too. But, for the price, you get mediocre sushi. Not worth it. Sushi on Shea and Kyoto, now those are good eats. Cheaper, too. Don't waste your cash on the scene at Blue Wasabi. You'll regret it."

"Friday eve, about nine o'clock, I chanced upon this place,
And found it lacking in staff, with naught but two servers to grace
A large establishment, and no hostess in sight.
My server, though, was quite good, his service most delightful and bright.

The food, alas, did not match his excellence, I do confess.
Lemon sole, a side salad, these were my choices, nothing more,
Yet with tax and tip, the sum totalled twenty dollars, I do declare.
The salad, fresh and crisp, was pleasant to the taste,
But the lemon caper sauce, oh how it failed to impress!
The sole, sautéed, they claimed, yet fried and tough it was,
A shame, for sole is tender, and needs but little cooking, alas.

Disappointment filled my heart, and I would not recommend this dish,
For Mimi's bread, though good, cannot make up for such a failure, I do wish.
Expensive, too, this meal, and not worth the cost, I must confess.
Go elsewhere, friends, and save your coins, for here you'll find but woe and distress."

"This joint gets rave reviews, but I just don't see it. It's grimy, run down, and the service is painfully slow. And let's not forget the food - it's nothing more than greasy, bland slop. 

People say it's a great spot for affordable, delicious Mexican cuisine, but that's just not true. The salsa is store-bought and the guacamole lacks any real flavor. And don't even get me started on the tortilla chips - they're covered in shredded cheese that's not even melted. 

I tried a taco salad and couldn't even stomach finishing it. If you're in the market for subpar, Americanized Mexican food, then this might be your place. Otherwise, steer clear."

"Manager says he's gonna treat himself to Blueberry Hill. I near fall outta my chair. Seen my review on Flamingo? Terrible! But he insists, says it's 10,000 times better on Green Valley Parkway. I shrug, go back to work. Today, I need somethin' to get the creative juices flowin', so I figure, why not? Get to Blueberry Hill, order the same as before - Mexican-style chilaquiles and a Diet Pepsi. Same plate of mediocrity. Don't see how folks rave 'bout these places. Service a little faster, but still not sold. Stickin' with Denny's for comfort food."

"Ribs were small, even for babybacks. Brisket was too dry. Pulled chicken, pork, and sausage were meh. Sausage tasted store-bought. Fries had some skin, but were mediocre. Better BBQ can be found in NW Phoenix."

"Fremont Street dive, near Golden Nugget. Seen better days. 

Go for the deep fried Twinkies, 99 cents. Not good for me, but can't resist. Could use a cleaner deep fry station and friendlier service. Rude comment about tips, so I'll leave 10%. 

Slot machines don't work, staff not happy. Would be better without gambling. Good for slushy drinks and deep fried Twinkies, but avoid gambling."
"Coffee's decent, but service is lacking. Been here plenty, various times of day. Attempted small talk with baristas, got brief replies. Coffee and grub? Standard Starbucks fare."

"Tonight, I didst partake in the seafood spread,
And found it wanting, save for a few dishes.
The steamed crab legs were passable, I must say,
But those roasted in sweet chile sauce didst sway
My taste buds in their favor. The cold crab legs,
Near the cold seafood, didst taste a bit too briny.
The lobster tails, alas, were small and rubbery,
But all didst taste better when drowned in garlic butter,
As if the gods themselves had deigned to bless it.

The desserts, methinks, were the true delight,
The green tea cheesecake, a gentle, airy treat,
The creme brulee, just sweet and creamy enough,
To end a meal most satisfactorily. The bread pudding,
With vanilla spice sauce, didst earn my highest praise,
And red velvet cupcakes, though dry and foul,
Didst not detract from the overall sweet delight.

Alas, my friends, this buffet doth not live up
To its renown, and so, I wouldst advise thee,
Seek elsewhere for a feast most worthy of thy coin.
This place, though blessed with good service, doth not shine.
One star for food and options, and another for the service,
But the rest, alack, doth not make up for the hype and the price."

"Underwhelmed. Got there around four, only one table occupied. Exterior looked promising, but inside felt like a tattoo artist's bedroom. Took a while for someone to come out and seat us, not a great start. Salsa bar had variety, but was set up poorly. Containers too small, had to use plastic spoons. No metal utensils or plates provided, table was a mess before we ordered. Tacos arrived, both plates had cracks. Smoked marlin tasted like canned tuna, veggies were okay. Corn tortillas flimsy, like store-bought. Service was meh, questions met with finger-pointing and blank stares. All in all, should've gone to Chipotle."
"Sunday nights, we'd hit this joint, me and the crew. Good times, cheap drinks, decent grub. Lately though, things ain't been the same. Prices up, quality down. Shame, really."
"Food joint's a real gimmick, if you ask me. Rent-an-express, that's what they call it. But hey, the grub's just alright, nothing special."

"Place was nothing special. I wasn't too hungry, still feeling the effects of a wild night before. Got the breakfast buffet for $15, pretty standard for Vegas. Pizza was a highlight, but everything else was just eggs, bacon, sausage, hash browns. Made it 3/4 through a plate before I felt sick. Service was good though, waitress gave me two big glasses of OJ. If you're staying at Planet Hollywood, it's not a bad option. But I'd go for Le Village Buffet in Paris instead."

"A cockroach emerged from yonder sprout dish,
And with its presence, did my appetite dismiss.
I slew the beast, and with some hesitation, stayed,
Their apologies were many, and my meal they repaid.
My to-go dinner, too, they gave without a fray,
But now, alas, I fear I must seek fare elsewhere,
For though 'twas once my favorite pho diner,
I shall now journey forth to Chinatown, fairer."

"Strippers. Funny as hell, trying to be sexy. But forget it if we ain't interested. Guy named Chili. Ugly bastard. Kept offering deals for a dance. None of us wanted. Some other dancers were cool, though. Met a dude from San Jose. Pretty funny. But seriously, no seats in the main room for the girl dancers? What the hell? We kept getting invited to join bachelor parties, but we didn't want to sit with them. Saw some guy getting a hand job from an ugly stripper. Hilarious."

"Pasqual's salsa, man. Mild, medium, hot - it's all good. They used to call themselves a "salsaria." It's like the salsa makes me wanna dance, even though I got two left feet and no idea what salsa dancing is. That's how good it is. But today, man, I'm disappointed. Big plate of nachos, tiny little cup of salsa. Same thing last time, so we ordered extra, but still, just a tiny cup. Chicken, beef, nachos, tacos - three stars, tops. But the salsa, man... it's the real deal. Give me more."

"Went out tonight with a family member, ordered the $20 dinner for two. Guacamole appetizer, their tortilla chips and guacamole with corn, no jalapenos, not spicy, according to the waitress. First bite, whoa, 5-alarm fire in my mouth, full of jalapenos and other spicy things. Sirloin, mine was well done, burnt on one side. Came with loaded mashed potatoes, great, and broccoli, foul and rancid. Service, always poor, don't know why I went back. Tonight, my last visit."
"Terrible service. Took forever to sit us down, bring our grub, and quench our thirst. Then they had the nerve to take their sweet time giving us the bill. We ain't never coming back."

"Terrible. A capital 'B' Bad. 

Pizza we got? Guy who cooked it? Never been to NY/NJ. Ever. 

Half meatball. Half pepperoni. Looked nothing like menu. Twice the price. Thick crust. Tomato paste. Overcooked cheese. Not meatballs. Ground beef. 

Really bad. Wanted another NY style spot. Doesn't cut it. Sticking to regular places. 

Sandwiches? Other dishes? Could be good. But Streets of NY? Good pizza pie? Nope."

"Ran through the drive-thru, first mistake. Girl at the window, clueless about the menu. Finally got my order, pulled ahead, waited. Anticipation building. Smelled onion rings on the way home, couldn't figure it out till I got there. Bag of ice cream, greasy and flavored the ice cream. No good. Salvageable ice cream, too sweet. Had to stop, fearing a diabetic coma. Quickly downed water. Meh, never again."

"Food's hit or miss here. I stick to piccatta, but the one time I tried the veal, it was tough as shoe leather. Prices are steep too. Atmosphere's the only saving grace. Staff's gotta step it up, from their attitude to their knowledge. I went to the bar and ordered a mojito. Bartender said she couldn't make it, but the manager, Mike, said they had fresh mint. I got my drink, but it made me wonder if the bartender was telling the truth or just didn't want to make it. Last June, I set up a birthday party for my husband. Made a reservation a week in advance, but the waiter and busser were MIA. Had to beg for refills. Only had one good waiter in three years, and that's because I complained to the manager and he comp'd our meal."

"Hark! What customer service doth this place provide?
Two stood there, idle, as I entered the door.
One eyed me keenly, yet didst not utter a word.
The other, a lady, didst bid me good morrow,
But swiftly departed, leaving me quite unheard.

A slice of pizza, a salad, and drink didst I seek,
Their 'number two' special, priced at six crowns.
Alas! The sauce on the pizza was overly sweet,
And the dough, it didst sag like a rain-soaked gown.
The salad, a simple mix of greens and veg,
Didst please my taste buds, but naught else didst beguile.

Thus, I didst leave, with a heavy heart and full belly,
Praying that next time, their service may be more jolly."

"A decent place, indeed, with TVs and outdoor seating,
And a roll of paper towels at every table, neatly arranged.
I am a fan of pizza and beer, 'tis true,
But alas, the beer is draft, and not meant for takeout, anew.
They have wine, as well, for those who prefer,
Their appetizers seem fair, but I didst not partake,
For I had the pizza, with vegetables upon it,
Which was but mediocre, I do confess.
Nothing too special here, I do declare,
Perhaps 'tis the location that doth make it fair."

"San Gabriel Valley born and raised, my dim sum standards run high. This joint? Subpar. Microwaved fare, flavorless and stale. Har Gow and Shau Mai, mushy and falling apart. Rice cake dessert, a disappointment. Overcooked, no flavor. For Vegas dim sum, it'll do. Won't be back."

"Apartment complex went up in flames. Had to hole up here temporary-like. Brought my kid, me, and the two cats. Asked for a handicap room on account of my bum knee. Neighborhood ain't the best, but the train noise don't bother me none. Liked the safety bars in the bathroom though. Made me feel secure, ya know? If I had to do it again, I'd still pick this Scottsdale spot."

"Place looks good inside and out. Not packed on a Friday night, so we sat on the heated patio. Started off well, good bread and fresh salads. Went downhill from there. Spanakopita starter was decent, three big pieces, but too much cream cheese. Missed the light phyllo crust. Regular gyro and chicken gyro were nothing special. Fries and rice were unimpressive. Service was good, but I won't be back."
"Tucked away in Scottsdale Quarters, upstairs from Tanzy and iPic. Don't let that deter you, keep lookin'."

"Place was a letdown. Not the massage, that was good. But they got no staff. Masseuse does everything - reception, management, cleaning. New customer comes in, masseuse ditches me to arrange their massage. Hour-long massage takes 90 minutes. Found this joint after sushi at the strip mall's end. Won't be back."

"PB&J before 11 am? Forget about it, kid. Employees said it's against the rules, no matter how much you beg. They wouldn't even give me Tobasco for my egg sandwich. Just some weak homemade chili sauce instead. What's the point of having rules if you can't enforce 'em? Shame on 'em."

"Place had good reviews, decent happy hour prices. But it didn't do it for me. Decor was lacking, booths were uncomfortable. Service was alright. Ordered gyoza, it was okay, not crunchy though. Volcano roll was a mistake, they brought us a thunder roll instead. Rainbow roll was subpar, shrimp was chewy, avocado was off. Tea and miso soup were good. Not impressed overall, won't be back."

"Food's good, that's why I gave it a two. Been here before, always been satisfied. But this time, service was crap. Started off normal, greeted at the door, seated quick. Busy place, but not too bad. Got our drinks fast, French press was top-notch. Then, we waited. Five minutes, ten, fifteen. Others got seated and ordered, but no one bothered with us. Waitress was too busy chatting with the staff. Finally got up and left. Disappointing, especially for Postinos. Won't be back to the central location."

"Hark! A Cirque du Soleil devotee I be,
O, Ovo, Mystere, Quidam, Zarkana, Dralion, all have I seen,
And thus, my curiosity, Zumanity did pique,
For in Las Vegas, the city of sin,
A show with an adult theme, I thought would be within.

But alas, the stunts, not as grand,
As other Cirque shows, I must hand,
The dance and music, not as divine,
Yet still, a fun time, thou shalt find,
For the clown hosts, they shall make thee laugh,
With crowd interaction, their antics they'll play.

Zumanity, a unique experience doth bring,
In a small theater, intimate, it doth cling,
The performers, they greet thee, at the door,
So front row seats, prepare for some more."

"Methought the bar tops were fair and bright,
The lighting, too, did please mine eyes.
And, verily, the fries were good, I say,
But that, alas, was where the joy did cease.

My love's brother had the fish, 'twain true,
With wilted greens, that did my heart sadden.
The plate, it seemed, had been beneath the sun,
And thus, the salad did lose its luster, anon.

I, myself, did have the fish and chips,
But found the batter lacking in its zest.
It was not fluffy, nor did it delight,
And so, my hopes were dashed, my heart did ache.

My love, he had the Bangers, bean and mash,
But found them lacking, with a taste most rash.
Like breakfast sausage, they did seem,
And thus, our evening did end in dismay, I do declare."
"Food was top-notch, but the prices were steep. Lunch for three ran us $105, and that was without drinks. Service was solid, but the cost was hard to swallow."

"A pox upon this eatery, I say!
Their dishes, full of fat and gristle lay.
I ordered steak, a New York cut, they claim,
But 'twas a disappointment, full of blemish and shame.
The veal, too, was naught but a disgrace,
With sauce that resembled more a gravy's embrace.
And martini, oh how it did fall short,
Sweet, yet lacking in true flavor and sport.
The service, fair, but not enough to sway,
For there are better choices, come what may."

"Perch'd upon a stool, I sipp'd a glass of vintage red,
And plac'd an order for a meal to be convey'd.
A bartender, with mien somewhat displeas'd,
Didst pour for me a draught of wine, the price whereof didst seem steep.
I ask'd for half spinach, half romain, a mix'd bed,
For my Cesar salad, and thus didst make my wish known.
The pizza, with toppings of pear and Gorgonzola, didst arrive,
But cold it was, and not so tasty, alack!
I fear I shall not return to this place again."

"Stayed at the Hilton, across the street from the Riviera. Ended up gambling there every day. Bartenders at the poker bar were friendly, but some dealers were rude. James and Bruce were great. Lost big time to Tang, no smile, no nothing. Why bother with 3-card poker? Wouldn't play there if I was with the boys instead of my family."

"O, how my wits did play me false,
For paying o'er thirteen crowns, a sum most grievous,
For two milkshakes, which though they were not vile,
Yet naught so fine to warrant such a price,
In fair Gilbert, where I didst part with my coin,
A folly, indeed, and one I shall not soon repeat."

"Four of us hit this joint after an Overture gig. Grub was decent, but the service? Shitshow. Server cleared plates with food still on 'em. But the real kicker was our waiter. This one broad, eight months preggo, orders a virgin mojito. Waiter gives her the hairy eyeball and says, "So, you want it with vodka, huh?" She's like, "No, dipshit, without." Finally gets it through his skull. Then the bill comes and we get charged eleven bucks for this non-alcoholic drink. We're like, "What the hell?" Ask him about it, he says there ain't no button for virgin drinks and it's ten bucks for the mint and labor. We're like, "Bullshit." Ask for a manager, wait ten minutes, nobody shows. So we pay and bounce, pissed off."

"Parked, validated tickets ourselves. Left, told parking was three bucks, validation only good for three hours. What the hell? Got hit on by some dude with star-shaped implants outside the john. Weirdo. Gonna hit up College Night at Canyon Club, but they wanted ten bucks cover from underage folks. Rip-off. Just left."

"Ain't no use in sugarcoatin' it. This joint's got problems. First off, the hostesses. Three of 'em, yappin' away like they're at a cocktail party. Took 'em two whole minutes to notice me standin' there. That's some top-notch service right there. Then, I order a glass of Pinot. Tastes like it's been sittin' open for a week. I mention it to the bartender, he just shrugs and says, "Nah, I just opened it." Like that's supposed to make me feel better. Happy Hour's a joke too. One buck off? That's like they're tryin' to insult me. Portions are decent, but the grub's just mediocre. Croissants are alright, though. Warm and tasty, but not enough to save this dump. There's better places in Scottsdale. Don't waste your cash here."

"Methinks 'twas my second venture hither,
To Tee Pee Mexican Food, a place of yore.
The wait, ere Christmas, was not overlong,
Our server, swift and kind, didst attend us well.

The salsa, full of flavor, didst delight,
But alas, the chips, small and broken, didst not.
My green corn tamale, cold as winter's night,
Didst leave me discontent, and nigh unto despair.

The rice and beans, average, nothing more,
Hubby's carne asada burrito, somewhat better,
But naught couldst compare to salsa and drink,
A margarita or cold beer, didst quench my thirst.

So, if thou art in need, come hither for,
These few things mentioned, else, forget not,
For mediocrity doth reign, methinks,
At Tee Pee Mexican Food, a humble tavern."

"Avoid, my friends, the Thursday night,
For Pure, the club, doth not delight.
They open but the rooftop high,
And commoners, like thee and I,
Must gather in the patio's heart,
Far from the rail, where views doth start.
I went, full of expectations bright,
But found it lacking, a poor sight.
In Austin, clubs of better sort,
I've seen, on Thursdays, no need to sport.
XS, on Fridays, doth reign supreme,
Pure, on Saturdays, a waste, it seems."

"Went to this joint a couple years back with the fam during a Vegas trip and loved it. Ordered all-you-can eat and my old man even got sick from overeatin'! We were eager to come back this time around.

Ordered some alligator tail as an appetizer and it was tasty. But the all-you-can-eat platters we usually get were only good towards the end. Seemed like they were usin' old oil to fry the fish and shrimp at first...yuck! Don't even wanna think about how old it was. But hey, at least they changed the oil to fresh oil at the end, so that was good.

The salad bar was pretty lackluster too. Coulda used some more maintenance, ya know? Maybe put the same items on both sides to make it easier to navigate without spillin' stuff everywhere. Did like how they kept the plates chilled though.

Service was good, our waitress did her job. Shame we lost our cravin' for this place. Just ain't the same no more."

"Staying at the W, I only ate here. Hot waitresses, sure, but that's Montreal for you. Nothing special. 

They try too hard with fancy French dishes, but the flavors don't quite work. Not impressed. 

Breakfast is alright, I guess. That's all."

"We hit McCarren, got in line for the rental car. Thought I made the right choice, six people ahead of me, nobody at the other counters. Not the case. Later, needed a car again, went with Budget. Their price was just as good, nicer cars. Meanwhile, Dollar had two people working, and I waited in a long-ass line. Painful. Considered cancelling and booking elsewhere. Not cool, Dollar."

"Alas, the atmosphere didst please mine eyes,
But, alack, the food didst not suffice.
A bowl of pasta, dull and tasteless, came,
With two small meatballs, a paltry sum.
For fifteen dollars, I didst pay the price,
And left the place, still feeling quite nice.
Homeward, I went, with hunger pangs,
And there, a PB&J sandwich, I didst mangle."

"Malls are dead to me, but a gift card burned a hole in my pocket. We hit up a dusty department store, hoping for some classic retail therapy. The joint was tired, selection slim. Bummed me out, man. Felt like work, not fun."

"Arrived at 11 am, not too busy, but still waited 10 minutes for a table. Server was great though, attentive and friendly. Ordered French Toast, big portion with lots of pecans, but nothing special. Expensive too, compared to Denny's. Not impressed, maybe try a hash dish next time."

"Pizza joints like Domino's, Pizza Hut, and Little Caesars can't touch this place. Sure, they might be cheaper, but you get what you pay for. This pizza's worth every penny. Don't waste your cash on those other places. You'll be glad you spent a little extra for the real deal."
"Skip it. Worst spread I've seen. If you're at the GC, head to Palms instead. Food wasn't too bad, but still a bust. Two stars, tops."
"UPS store, package in hand, wave goodbye. Brown truck, delivery done."

"Upon a day, I didst venture forth to partake of an Orange Julius, yet lo, the contraption didst fail to function. And thus, a week didst pass, and with colleagues in tow, I didst return, seeking a chocolate cone. Alas, 'twas nowhere to be found. Alack, the staff didst seem confused, their ordering and delivery system most strange. I didst search, yet found no manager or supervisor to guide them."

"Breakfast out, nice, but not here again. Too rich. Eggs Benedict, coffee, $40. Portions big, wasteful. Menu should say. Unripe fruit, no. In season, yes. Fresh, local, ripe. Waitress asked, I said no. Hard, pink slice, where from?"

"I've got a thing for Nordstrom Rack. Whenever a new one pops up in Cali or Nevada, I make it a point to check it out. The freshest gear always shows up at the new spots. Been to a bunch, and some are better than others. But this one in Summerlin? It's a bust. Men's section's tiny, and the pickings are slim. Couldn't find squat to buy. Went to the one in Henderson instead, scored two sweet sweaters. Had high hopes for this new joint, but now I'm not so sure I'll be back."

"Starving after a night out, we craved the Mexican joint in Aria. Closed. Boo. Asked around, settled on Lemongrass. Modern vibe, nice decor. Tough to slide into booths. Wooden chopsticks. Tom Kha Chicken, good. No individual bowls, strange. Black pepper prawns, sweet and sour chicken, curry, Chow Fun. Solid, not exceptional. Better Thai/Chinese back home, cheaper. Open late, credit where due. Total: over $100. Unlikely to return."

"Place gets a bit tight, especially after hitting up LV North Premium Outlets. How it stacks up:

-Parking's a breeze (but watch out for traffic snags)
-Indoor haven from scorching Vegas summers (feels a tad cramped inside though)
-Plenty of stores to choose from (North outlets got more variety though)
-Better food options, both inside and out (less lost tourists too)

Still prefer the North outlets despite the inconvenience. Nice to be indoors, but easier to hit main stores by walking outside. Trip ended up a bust."
"Underwhelming experience. Clean, positive vibe, but staff's warmth lacking. Prices decent, not exceptional. Manicure botched, full of bubbles. Limited color options. Won't return."

"Turkey and roast beef, freshly made, drew me in. But, damn, it was shredded. Like a dog's dinner, as Ramsey'd say. Got the bobby with roast beef, so I could taste both. Bread was good, stuffing was cold. Meat was dry, real dry. Like sawdust. Other meats, not shredded, must be great on that bread. Manager, bragging about doing nothing but micro-managing. Donkeys! Guy should clean the bathrooms."
"Place looked good, but the grub didn't quite live up. Thought it deserved three stars, max. Better options back in Cali, and cheaper too. But, gotta admit, the joint looked sharp."

"Went to The Keg last night. First time. Disappointed. Ordered filet and lobster tail. Everything overcooked. Asked for medium rare. Got well done and medium well. Asparagus like canned crap. Couldn't eat it. Lobster best thing on plate. Rubbery though. Food quality marginally better than Outback. Price higher. Like an upscale steakhouse. Maybe worth it if you're into that. Personally, prefer Morton's, Ruth's Chris, The Palm, or Donovan's. Pay for quality. Actually get it. Won't be going back to The Keg."

"This joint used to be top-notch, but now it's a shadow of its former self. They used to have a bunch of classes, all day long, but now they got a limited selection and they're always crammed with people. And don't even get me started on the tip thing - it's like they're trying to milk us dry. They don't even provide shampoo or conditioner no more, and the showers are a joke. Staff's pretty disorganized too, always forgetting our class cards. I just renewed my membership after a break, and let me tell you, I'm regretting it big time. Only reason I still go there is 'cause the instructors are still top-notch."
"Patio's nice. Keepin' it positive."
"Disappointment at every visit. Dry, reheated spuds. Overcooked eggs. Lackluster flavor. Sriracha, dark and wrong. Fake sauce? Scram, it's over. Not me, you."

"Burger? Forgettable. Flavorless patty, unremarkable bun. Mixed up our order, too. Fries instead of rings. Apologies and mediocre rings followed. Nibbled some fries. Average. Overpriced at ten to twelve bucks. Beer? Decent. Cold, tasty. Service? Meh. Not crowded on a Friday. Underwhelming experience."

"First visit, great. Second, not so much. Girl forgot my name, spent 30 seconds before taking a call. Then, she chatted for 15 minutes while three others stood around, ignoring me. She kept saying 'wait' though I wasn't speaking. When she finished my brows, she yanked hard and my eye watered. Called me a crybaby. At the register, she asked for a larger tip. Two stars for decent brows, but poor service and location mean I won't return."
"Burger, big as a plate. Ok, not great. Less is more, I say. Not going back. Ate a third, disappointed. Tractor, cool though."

"Verily, my first visit didst stir within me such delight,  
That I couldst not wait to return, and savour their fare once more.  
But alas, my second coming didst bring naught but woe,  
For the service was poor, and the food didst lack its former lustre.  
The waiter, who didst attend to us with such zeal before,  
Didst now seem to care little for our needs, or our pleasure.  
He brought not the steak knives, till the meat was already cut,  
And the presentation of the dish, was utterly forgot.  
When I didst call upon the manager, to voice my discontent,  
The waiter didst arrive, with words of apology, and a promise to amend.  
But still, the bill didst come, with errors, and confusion galore,  
And the waiter didst pester us, like a shark, hungry for more.  
In conclusion, my friends, this place, which once didst shine,  
Hath now fallen from grace, and doth no longer meet mine expectations divine."

"Sis recommended this joint, but she hadn't been in a decade. I'm nearby, so I gave it a shot. Server asked if we had a Groupon. I didn't, but I checked and found one. Bought it - $19 for $30. Food wasn't impressive. Most rolls had cream cheese and krab mix. Not much variety. Freshness and flavor were lacking too. Rice overpowered the fish in every roll. Took forever to get our food. Not worth it without the Groupon. Bill would've been near $60 for mediocre sushi. People come for the $20 all-you-can-eat deal, but the rules are strict. No sharing. Pay for uneaten food. Service was good though. Won't be back."

"Place is top-notch, fountain's a real showstopper. But let's talk service. Cashier, never seen me before, asks how sweet the iced mochas are. Guy says, 'It's chocolate.' Thanks for the insight. I know that much. How many pumps we talking? Gonna leave with a sugar high? 

Look, I get it. You're stuck behind the counter while every kid in Vegas wants a gelato. But for those of us who want coffee, not a milkshake, try showing some enthusiasm. Pretend to care about service. 

Appreciate it."

"Hark! If thou dost crave a surfeit of victuals  
That be of middling quality, and service poor,  
Then this establishment shall be thy haven.  
'Twixt one and two stars, I do vacillate,  
Yet shall bestow upon them two, in fairness.  
Newly opened, 'tis clean, a sight most rare,  
Compared to Hometown Buffet, a place most foul.  
The steak, alas! Dried out and fat, did wait,  
And lo! The popcorn shrimp, a sorry sight,  
And fish, tough and fried, did leave me cold.  
Chicken, both barbecue and roasted, bland,  
But edible, lest I be too harsh.  
Some dishes, mislabeled, a confusion wrought.  
Desserts, a paltry choice, a buffet's shame.  
Staff, disorganized, in chaos swathed,  
A long line, slow, our patience doth consume.  
Plates, removed not, by waiters in haste,  
I, wise guise, mine own plates did clear.  
Drinks, ere payment, first procure we must,  
A slow process, vexing, and quite unjust.  
One dollar ninety-nine, a drink doth cost,  
Or more, for takeout, a price quite lost.  
Five pounds, a pound, they charge, a sum  
For takeout, verily, a price most steep.  
Amazed, I sat, and watched folk devour,  
In silence, next time, I shall demur."

"The place means well, but there's too much to gripe about. Interior's drab and depressing, like something outta a bad dream. Temperature's off too, sweltering hot even on a nice day. Tables and couches, tiny and creepy. Smoothies took forever, like they grew the fruit themselves. Hummus appetizer, not enough to go around. Greek salad, no feta. Spicy beef panini, good but burnt and sloppy. Prices too steep. Won't be back."
"Place ain't great. Their sesame chicken is hit or miss, about 30% of the time it's good. Rest is just okay or plain bad. Coworker found a bug in the wrapping, no way I'm eatin' there."

"Room was big, but dirty. Bed, comfy. Pillows, crap. Furnishings, nice, but dated. Robo-cop room. WiFi, one device only. Extra devices, $14/day. Ridiculous. Pool area, large, gambling outside. Pools, small. Rent chairs? Nope. Price, fair. Checkout, resort fees, taxes. Service, hit or miss. Spend more, stay elsewhere."

"Hark! This place doth seem promising, fair sir,
With menus grand and reviews most fair.
But, alas! 'Tis not as it doth appear,
For though the fries sampler didst delight,
The burgers, shakes, and beer didst disappoint.

The burgers, they didst take their time,
And when they came, they were not as designed.
The shake and beer, they didst forget,
Until we didst remind them, twice beset.

The burgers, they were not so fine,
The pepper bacon, sweet, not savory divine.
The meat, it was mealy, not so grand,
I'd only return for the shake, so bland.

So, gentle sir, do not go there,
With high hopes, lest thou be dismayed.
For though some dishes may please thy taste,
The rest, alack! doth leave much to be desired."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
My expectations of China Poblano were quite the mess.
For Jose Andres' name did grace the door,
And thus, I thought the food would be divine, no more.

But alas, the tapas we did share,
Were merely passable, without compare.
The pork sandwich, small and dear,
Did not astound, nor bring us cheer.

The eggplant dish, a gem, I say,
But not enough to make me stay.
I tried the Chinese and Mexican fare,
Side by side, to see if bliss were there.

But nay, the fusion did not sit,
Two menus in one, a curious fit.
The ambience, cool and trendy, true,
But price and taste, did not anew.

So, my friends, heed my advice,
Seek elsewhere, a better prize.
For though the atmosphere be grand,
Flavor and price, do not take hand."

"Lucky Louie's, formerly Fairview Grill, still serves poorly. The food's mediocre, the beer selection's limited. Went there last night with a friend, left feeling queasy. Had to use Pepto-Bismol later. 

Avoid Jerk sauce on wings; Barbalo's tolerable. Buffalo fries with ranch were tasty. Bacon Cheeseburger was half-eaten; should've specified well-done. Bacon wasn't crispy, no A1 Sauce. 

Lucky Louie's has some positives: 
1) Golden Tee and Silver Strike machines 
2) Pool tables 
3) Projector screen and ample flat-screens 
4) NFL Network 

Unlikely I'll return, especially for food."

"Hark, good sir, I do declare,
Panchero's doth leave much to despair,
In that place, I didst not find delight,
For portion sizes, they didst take flight.

A scant amount of cheese, they didst provide,
An ounce, perchance, and nothing more beside,
And beans, oh beans, so cheap and plain,
Yet still they gave me not a single grain.

The carnitas, tasty, I must confess,
But value and portions, such a mess,
I'd rather choose Taco Bell, 'tis true,
Eighty-nine cent bean burritos, that'll do.

So, to Panchero's, I shall not return,
For Jersey Mike's, Starbucks, Yogurtland, I yearn."

"Tusca, a place of some renown,
Within its walls, a tale is told,
Of staff, not overly concerned,
With guests, their needs unfulfilled.

Prices, fair, as we had hoped,
Food, just fine, no more, no less,
But near, a rival, doth loom,
A tapas place, of greater fame.

And there, a sight most strange,
Didst play out, on several nights,
Women, of years, and means, didst range,
In search of youth, and upward flight.

Alas, poor Tusca, doth suffer thus,
From those who seek a different bliss,
Yet still, a place, of some repute,
For those who seek a quiet kiss."

"Alas, my friends, how ill-fated was our quest
For breakfast at yon cozy little nest!
The staff, so slow, their minds elsewhere engaged,
Did leave us waiting, nigh on half a page.
And when they came, alack, what did they bring?
Two crepes, instead of one, and nary a brownie in sight!
Our little ones, who had been promised such sweet delight,
Were left in tears, their joy turned to despair and fright.
We tried and tried to hail a waiter, to make right
This grievous wrong, but none would heed our plight.
At last, a servant came, with tardy grace,
To offer apologies, but oh, how faint the trace!
The victuals, verily, were delectable, I must confess,
But service, poor, and lacking in finesse.
A reboot, methinks, would do this place some good,
Ere others suffer, as we did, beneath their mood."

"Alas, my dearest Xinh Xinh, what hath become of thee?

In days of yore, we brought our guests from afar
To taste thy wondrous fare, and marvel at thy charm.
But now, alack, thy glory doth begin to fade,
And with each visit, our delight doth turn to shade.

Last time, we ordered take-out, a meager feast
Of three banh mis and wings, with naught but ease;
The wings, well-seasoned with fish sauce, did please,
But oh, the stench of it, didst make our noses sneeze.
My wife's sister's banh mi, a decent meal did make,
But ours, alas, with little meat, didst forsake;
The jalapenos and cilantro, still there didst cling,
But mayonnaise, in scant supply, didst bring
A sorrow to our hearts, and tears to our eyes.

And, lo, the bubble teas, once strong and fine,
With flavors unique, and worthy of our dime;
Now, alas, with non-dairy creamer, made
A poor substitute, and our taste, didst betray.

Oh, Xinh Xinh, how art thou fallen from grace!
We shall not return, nor spend another penny;
For now, we shall endeavor to make our own
Banh mi and pho, and thus, our hunger satiate.

Yet still, the service, with a smile and cheer,
Didst make us feel welcome, and dispel our fear."

"Where's the beef, you ask? Damn good question. Had the green chili beef chimi, but it was more like a tease. Few bits of beef and barely any green chilies. Klohe Kardashian's got nothing on me. Give it six months, tops. Unless they beef up the meal."

"The helpings they did serve, were scant and small,
A princely sum, they did demand for all.
No sisig, they had not, when we did dine,
In earliest days, their opening time did shine.
Our victuals came, at diverse hours, I say,
Unmeet, for one who doth expect a play.
Our server, middling, in his task did stray,
And, with the tables, more concern did sway.
In brief, our visit, did not please me well,
A pox, upon this house, wherein we dwelt."

"Not my idea of utopia, this place. Good atmosphere though, on a cool street. Mixed bag of people. Bartender suggested their IPA. Big mistake. Flavorless. Not what I expected from an IPA. Should've tried something else. But I didn't. Also, they only take cash. Sucks for business travelers like me."

"Mediocre, at best, my dear friend,
A visit to Peru Chicken did bend
My expectations, forsooth,
No grilled fowl, alack, what woe!

A Tacu Tacu, I didst order,
With Antichuchos, and a dish of potatoes,
But lo, the presentation, poor,
A heap of rice and beans, no more.

The meat, a slab, so small and lean,
No vegetables, nor pickles seen,
A fail, methinks, at such a price,
Improve, good sirs, your culinary device.

The Antichuchos, slices of meat,
On skewers, with corn, not sweet,
And potatoes, undercooked, alas,
The meat, a saving grace, 'twas.

An appetizer, pappas a la huancaina,
Three cold potatoes, served with cheese,
A styrofoam plate, a sorry sight,
Five dollars, far too great a sum, indeed."

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."

I stepped into the joint with high hopes, but they were quickly dashed. The burgers and fries were nothing to write home about, and the prices were steep, even for Vegas. The only saving grace was its 24-hour availability.

"Sunday morning, ten a.m., place was hopping. Staff scrambling, kitchen overwhelmed. Packed house, empty tables. Ordering took ages, orders botched. Cinnamon roll MIA, drink unrefilled, pancake burnt to a crisp. Hash browns lacked TLC, French toast stale. Hope they shape up, potential's there."

"Alack, our group of four didst eagerly anticipate
This eatery, based on tales of its greatness.
We entered at four, seeking a meal betwixt
Lunch and dinner, yet our hopes were dashed to bits.
Forsooth, they doth serve but brunch on weekends,
And dinner not until five and thirty minutes.
Alas, who doth desire pancakes at such hour?
A pox upon their limited schedule, say I!
Our work doth bind us to the weekday grind,
So we shall ne'er partake of their noonday fare.
But still, we shall attempt to dine with them
At eve, when chance doth grant us liberty."

"Slowest service ever. No host when we walked in, so we hit the bar. Not busy, just two couples and a table keeping the bartender busy. Had to wait for a greet. She said she had to find mint for my mojito. Finally got our drinks but no menus. Had to grab 'em myself from the host stand. Ordered water pre-meal, bartender never brought it. Asked again when the food arrived. Food's okay, typical Applebee's fare. Finished the apps, drinks, and entrees. Nothing got cleared till she grabbed our credit card. What really burned me was a three-top walked in, bartender knew 'em, greeted 'em, and got their drinks right away. Never going back, even though it's behind the hotel."

"A pox upon this place! Recommended, I did expect
Much joy and merriment, but nay, 'twas not so.
The dirt, it did abound, and service, slow,
We near did walk away, our patience did grow thin.
Managers, many there were, yet staff, few and far between.
Bored and untrained, they did appear, alack!
What woe, what disappointment doth this place bring!"

"Cheesesteak in Philly? Forget it. Dried up, lukewarm mess. Not worth the menu ink. Hubby's turkey sandwich? Meh. Passable if you're famished and can't tell the difference. But sober and hungry at lunchtime? Keep walking."

"Tis a shame, my friends, that this curry house doth fail,
In flavor and in quality, it doth pale.
Their veggie dishes, I have tried, and found them weak,
Lacking in the spices that make curry unique.
Perhaps their non-veggie options fare better, I pray,
But as it stands, I would not send thee their way.
For though they be near campus, and convenience doth reign,
Good Indian food, they do not serve, in vain.
So seek elsewhere, friend, for a meal most fine,
And leave this curry house to its mediocrity, and decline."

"Service here's gone downhill fast. Tickets for two cost $120 plus a Platinum flash pass for another $140. Supposedly, it cuts wait times but that's questionable. Feels like a scam. Website describes it as limited but that's not what I got. Had to wait in line for some rides and not all rides were covered. Ordered a beer, paid $6.50, but got mostly foam. Kid poured it, too. Not legal. Gonna complain to the RACJ. Teens shouldn't pour alcohol. Six Flags in Quebec doesn't seem to care about provincial rules."

"The show was a letdown. Overpriced and underwhelming. Not enough real dancing, too much suggestive crotch-grabbing, and mime comedy that fell flat. We waited in vain for something exciting to happen. It never did. One number stood out, but the rest didn't live up to the standard set by ABDC. \n\nAs we left, someone said, "It was amazing!" My husband and I looked at each other, wondering if we'd been at the same show. Maybe it's geared towards teenagers."

"Kirkland Signature frozen yogurt, love it. But this food court, they rip you off. Leave the middle hollowed out, like the employees are trained to do it. Pepperoni pizza, too greasy. Need a fist full of napkins, can't eat it without 'em. Bottom of the pizza, all over the plate, damn messy."

"In fair Arizona, where sun doth shine bright,
I thought, alack, any Mexican eatery would be in sight,
But lo, my dear huband's kin, they didst swear,
This place, 'twas grand, and we shouldst venture near.
A plaza, it be, with decorations fine,
And within, the ambiance, it didst shine.
The loo, it be, clean and neat,
Our waitress, kind, and our drinks, she didst pour,
Salsa, they hadst, two kinds, I didst declare,
But alas, the house salsa, it didst not impress,
Nor chips, they were not of the finest fare.
Cheese dip, it was, quite good, I must confess,
But chimichanga, oh how it didst disappoint,
No cheese, nor taste, it didst possess,
I sent it back, and ordered naught but air.
My daughter's food, my husband's too,
Didst not impress, and so I do declare,
This place, two stars, for service good,
But food, alas, it didst not as it should."
"Pizza's good. Delivery's a bust. Get it yourself, or wait an hour and a half to chow down."

"Kabuki's a joint I know well, mostly for work lunches. But today, Saturday, I wanted to take the missus and kiddos out for some sushi. Service was a real bust, though. Guy named Andy, he had four or five tables, but all he cared about was griping to the other waiters about having to work on a nice day and chatting up the hostess about his weekend plans. Our apps and salads came after we finished our sushi, drinks went unfilled, and it took him 20 minutes to pick up my card and check. What a shame they can't find anyone who wants to work hard. Buyer beware, bad service, just okay food."

In sooth, I must concur with those who say
This Walmart, with two stars, doth falter and sway.
A year hath passed since I didst first set foot
Within its halls, but now, my scrips I do shift
To another Walmart, for I cannot bear
The squalor more. Alas, how I do despair!

I love Walmarts, in truth, but this one doth mar
My fondness for them. A friend, perchance,
Didst enter, and within the restroom, didst hear
A wretched soul, in dire need, didst spew and sputter.
So now, my friend, in fear, doth vow to shun
All Walmarts, forevermore, alack!

"Happy hour menu, Friday. Steak and cheese, six bucks, not bad. Neopolitan milkshake, four dollars, decent. Gyro, six bucks, but no more next time. Panini, six bucks, just okay. Service slow, even though it's dead. Overall, it's alright if you're starving, hungover, drunk, or didn't think of better options."

"Hark! What's this? A place that doth deserve
A rating of three stars, or so it seems.
The blueberry scone, alas! Was quite awry,
Blatant in its horror, savory in its guise.
Granular in texture, a strange sight to see.
My espresso con panna, oh how it did sting!
More bitter than Starbucks', a taste most dire.
But fear not, dear friends! For there were some
Redeeming qualities found within these walls.
The lemon olive oil cornmeal cake, a delight!
And the mocha, a drink most wondrous and fair.
The counter worker, a friendly soul indeed,
Knowledgeable in their craft, with a smile so bright."

"Hark! What's this? A place to dine, they say,
But lo, the fare, it doth not sway
My taste, for it is but average, I fear,
Unless thou art a fan of plants, my dear.
And oh, the wait, it doth prolong,
Two hours or more, a tedious song.
So cross the street, my friend, and save
Thyself from woe, at Franktuary, they crave."

"Hark! This place doth leave much to be desired, fair friends.  My hunger for Mexican victuals didst lead me hither, but alas! 'Twas a mistake, I do confess.  The service, indeed, was friendly and warm, but lo! The guacamole, though decent, could not make up for other faults.  The tortilla chips, I swear, didst lack the freshness of yore, and thus, their flavor didst suffer.  And burritos, thou askest?  Alas, they doth offer them but on certain days, a strange and woeful fact, indeed.  The chicken quesadilla, a dish I didst hope to savor, didst fall short of my expectations, I do declare.  Soggy and bland, with naught but dead space betwixt the tortillas, it didst leave me unimpressed, I do confess.  So, heed my words, dear friends, and seek thy sustenance elsewhere, lest thou suffer the same disappointment as didst I."

"Hark! We've been to this place many a time,
And found the portions fair when dining in.
But lo! When ordering out, they do decrease,
The size of the meal, yet still the same price they charge.
Last Friday, we did partake of Mahi Mahi,
With veggies galore, and all was well.
But on the Sabbath day, we ordered the same,
To take away, and oh what a shame!
The fish, once plentiful, now but a morsel,
And the hummus, once a generous helping, now a mere dollop.
So beware, dear friends, when ordering to go,
Lest ye be cheated of thy just desserts,
For they do seem to think thou art a fool,
Who'll not notice till safely at home."

"Frozen yogurt's my jam. But here's the thing - if you're gonna get FroYo, you might as well go for a fresh, fruity flavor. Otherwise, you're better off with ice cream. Every time I've been here, they've had one measly fruit flavor, and it's always been something I'm allergic to or just plain don't like. No original tart, either. That's a crime. \nBut hey, they've got a decent spread of toppings. Place is clean, service is meh, prices are standard."

"I came back for round two, thinking maybe my first visit was just a fluke. But nope, same crap service and food. Ordered the table d'hote for my buddy, and what do we get? A burnt-to-a-crisp piece of beef. Unbelievable. And the server? Didn't give a damn. Didn't even ask how the meal was. That's the problem with this joint - nobody gives a damn. Not worth my time or money. Won't be coming back."

"Twas a place of middling sort, where we didst order three pizzas of specialty, and thus didst find: one was of fair quality, another but mediocre, and the third, alack, didst leave much to be desired. A salad, good in its own right, didst come with naught but ranch dressing, which didst please mine taste, while bleu cheese, oh how it didst dismay! Chicken tenders, burnt to a crisp, didst fill mine nostrils with smoke, as if the kitchen itself didst burn. How strange, that they didst bring such fare to us! And though the buffalo sauce didst have its charm, 'twas lost upon the unfit chicken. Baked potato fries, a novel thought, didst taste of promise, but alas, their sogginess didst mar their worth. Alas, our hundred dollars didst bring us naught but woe, and thus, this place doth fall beneath mine standards."

"Went to Bottles & Burgers at Tivoli Village. Not impressed beforehand, but a friend wanted to check it out. Willing to give any place a shot, especially with patio seating. Patio was between two escalators, lots of traffic and noise. Didn't try the food, but had their cucumber martini - decent but not the best. Sangria was terrible, like prune juice. Honey jack on the rocks was good, can't mess that up. Better off going to Brio for a nice patio experience - comfy chairs, fire pits, and great people watching."

"Imadake, a restaurant of much renown,
Didst disappoint me, with its over-saucy crown.
The octopus balls, gummy and raw,
Were not worth the coin, I do declare.

The okonomiyaki, too, was a letdown,
Drowned in sauce, without a doubt.
And the black cod, oh how it failed,
Rubbery and bland, it did not prevail.

The jellyfish salad, a strange delight,
Was not enough to make things right.
I shall not return, forsooth,
For Imadake doth not meet my truth.

A trendy place, with oyster sauce galore,
But alas, the food doth not live up to the score."

"This ain't no premier resort. Suite was small, needed a refresh. Bathroom, too. One of 'em lacked TP and a working lock. Grounds needed a paint job, some trimming. View of the highway wasn't bad, but the noise didn't bother me none. Kids liked the waterpark, but it had its moments. Confusion over hours on Saturday left the girls bummed. If you're lookin' for a kiddie waterpark and a basic room, this'll do. But if you want a real resort experience, try the Fairmont Princess."
"Diner near stadium, topless. Decent grub, gorillas keeping watch, some habitués. FYI, I was the sole hen."

"Polite waitstaff, but mediocre grub.  Overpriced, too.  If you must eat here, get a beer.  It'll make the food taste better.  I ordered a steak quesadilla with guac and a Coke.  The soda looked like weak tea, and I wasn't offered a refill.  The quesadilla looked good, but the guac was skimpy.  The dried onion garnish was unnecessary.  The filling-to-cheese ratio was off, and the whole thing fell apart.  The steak was overcooked and inedible, and the corn and bean relish made the cheese clump together.  Save your cash and hit up Burger King instead."
"Fair price, but nothing special. Wings needed more time in the oven. Burger was alright, bread was good."

"Fifty bucks for a meal in Vegas? Damn right. Fresh fish, too. Left more cash at the restaurant than at the craps table. Food was good, fresh, and well-prepared. Portions were small, but worth it. Pricey, sure, but not as bad as DC. Drinks were reasonable, though. My manhattan martini was generous and ten bucks. Same in DC. Sat at the sushi bar, enjoyed the animated display behind the chefs. Service was good, friendly, and prompt. Waiter's recommendations were on point. Went to another casino to recoup my losses. MGM, you owe me."

"I been to two Twin Peaks. First was in Austin. Second was in Scottsdale. Waitresses in Scottsdale were cold as ice. Hardly saw 'em, even when we needed the check. Other girls were huddled in the back, outta sight.\n\nFood was decent. Had a burger and fries. Cooked like they said it would be. But no reason to come back here. Better burgers elsewhere. Whataburger's the real deal. Was hopin' to see some waitresses. Not in Scottsdale, though."

"Food was decent, nothing special. Few things bugged me though. They charge for refills, what's the point? And this big group comes in, 9 people, first timers like me. Lady behind the counter says they add a 15% gratuity. But how's that fair when you order at the counter and they ain't bringing you jack? On the bright side, folks were friendly."

"A scanty choice of flesh, a sluggish pace,
And yet, not crowded, didst thou find thy space?
The meat, alas! of poorest cuts, I fear,
Sirloin, a sorry sight, didst bring thee cheer?
The salad bar, dull, lacking in delight,
A year hath passed, and now, thy mind doth flight.
Thou art displeased, thy words do plainly show,
Yet, once, thy praise, this place didst know."

"I shot back an email to the CSR rep, like they asked. She was polite, concerned. I hit send a couple times, got a reply from some suit too. They said the local boss would get in touch. That was weeks ago. Don't know what's up with that. Had a rough time with 'em before, but this just adds insult to injury. Don't need nothin' else from 'em, but figured I'd give 'em an update on the review."

"Clean joint, polite service. Like the blue film over the lights, gives it a lounge feel. But the grub...

Salt and pepper calamari, $7 for 14 pieces drenched in grease, no salt or pepper. Bland, just tasted like grease. Came with sweet and sour sauce. Best part was the fried carrot garnish.

The'special combination' bahn mi, big letdown. Meat all stacked on one end. Opened it up, found blackened meat - looked spoiled, not cooked. Picked out some pieces, bit in, and damn, crazy spicy sauce. Made my eyes water. Only saw jalapenos, don't mind 'em. 

This place may be by my gym, pho might be good, but I ain't comin' back. Can't trust the meat in your soups if you can't serve unspoiled meat on your sandwiches."

"Went to Harvest with a bunch of suits last night. Place claims they're all about local stuff, but that didn't mean much when we got there. No fish on the menu, two steak specials, and three desserts. Couldn't even get a damn Diet Coke. Ran out of straws too. Not exactly slammed, but they sure as hell weren't ready for us. Disappointing. Won't be taking anyone else there."

"Upon a Saturday eve, we chanced to dine,
Arriving at six, with hopes to sup and wine.
But lo, the place was empty, and our seat,
Was not yet cleaned, a sorry sight to greet.

We waited long, for one to take our order,
But nary a soul, did come to bother.
At last, the manager, didst take the task,
And brought us drinks, with haste and ask.

A nearby server, didst note our plight,
And brought our waiter, to end the fight.
Our garlic bread, didst arrive, alack,
With entrees, all together, in a stack.

The food, save bread, was lukewarm, I fear,
A dismal state, that didst bring a tear.
The staff, discombobulated, seemed,
And organization, was not their creed.

I doubt, fair friends, I'll return again,
To this place, where chaos did reign."

"Roland's, again? Yeah, I know. But I was in town for business and thought, why not? Kaya, though. Thirty minutes, easy. And the place is empty. Always. Like, what's that tell ya? And it's hot as hell outside, but inside, no A/C. Nice. 

Grilled veggie sandwich, clam chowder. Meh. Same as before. Service was better, I'll give 'em that. 

But, honestly? Doba's to-go taco salad the night before was way better. Save your cash, folks. Try somewhere else. 

Beer selection? Impressive, I guess. If you're into that sorta thing."

"Went to Pin Kaow 3 with the missus. Bad move. Service was slow, water took 20 min, curry another 20. Waitress MIA. Disappointing. \n\nLater, had the flu. Called Pin Kaow for my trusty tom ka kai and sticky rice. Soup was small, too salty, and thick. Ended up adding water. Not worth the hassle when you're feeling rough. Paid $12 for a cup of soup and a small side of rice. Sticky rice was good, though. Warm and tasty."

A goodly hostelry, if thou dost seek  
But a place to rest thy weary head,  
In sinful Sin City, where vice doth reign,  
And pleasure doth thy senses invade.  
'Tis situated on the outskirts of the Strip,  
Where foot traffic doth abound, and buses doth stop,  
In front of its entrance, with nary a fuss,  
So transportation doth pose no problem, by my troth.  
The drinks at the bar, though cheap they be,  
Are passable, and the chamber, clean as can be.
"Beer selection, good. Service, meh. Food, mediocre. Atmosphere, over-the-top. Someone's got deep pockets, but they should sweat the small stuff too."

"Macayos' pricier, blander cousin. 

Went with a group of nine on a quiet Monday eve. They made us wait till all nine were present, despite six being there already. Odd. 

Server was great, kept our drinks full. Food? Underwhelming. Carne asada taco plate with guacamole. Flavors lacking. Not expecting authentic Mex, but some seasoning would've been nice. Won't return."

"Coffee beans, Verve and Forty-Ninth Parallel, good choice. But, too crowded, pretentious scene. Tough to navigate, especially to the bathroom. Chocolate chip cookie, greasy, but some like it that way. Coffee drinks, no complaints. Solid espresso, worth the wait in line."

"Don't believe the hype. This place ain't all that. Forty-minute wait, slow service, and mediocre food. The hurricane roll was decent, but that's about it. They even had the nerve to ask us if we needed anything else after we paid the bill, basically telling us to get out 'cause they had other customers waiting. Rude. Won't be going back."

"Vegas for SHOT show, stayed at Venetian. Taqueria Canonita, close to border, lots of LA visitors, should've had great Mexican food. Ordered Santa Rosa Pork Barbacoa, per waiter's rec. Slow-cooked pork, stomach churned, but it was bland, dry. Chipotle's barbacoa better. Empanadas not crispy, guacamole not fully mashed. Too many mistakes for a sit-down joint. Tequila helped me forget the bad food."

"A fitting name for a spot that's lost its charm. Won't be makin' any new memories here. 

Rating Scale:
1 Star: Skip the whole town, ain't worth the risk. 
2 Star: Too many better options, why bother? 
3 Star: Might give it another shot, or eat here if desperate. 
4 Star: Regular spot, if the budget allows. 
5 Star: Lookin' forward to bringin' the missus or pals here."

"Gym's alright. Cleaning crew's always in the way, but place never seems clean. Women's locker room's a mess. Gym's too small, feels cramped. Front desk girls clueless, not exactly cheerful. Except for Candice or Candy, she's okay."

"Place gets 2 stars due to amenities. Pool area worth more than massages. Couples massage, 50 minutes, $300. Automatic 20% tip, don't agree. Spa beautiful, but separate areas, felt rushed. Asked for deep tissue, didn't get it. Massage lackluster, frustrating. Bad knots in shoulders, not touched. Wouldn't return, find another spa in Scottsdale."

"Scottsdale joint, mediocre grub, crummy service. \nFood was decent, not great, but passable. Service, on the other hand, was laughable. Restaurant was frigid, asked 'em to close the back door, they ignored us. Lunchtime on a Monday, only two tables, shouldn't be that busy. \nServer disappeared for 15, no water, had to ask thrice. Finally got it with our entrees. Asked for extra salsa, never saw the waitress again. Friend had to get up and grab her own refill. Took 'em that long to realize we were miffed. Food could've been amazing, but the service was so poor, never going back."

"Here's what you'll find:

1. Sashimi - mediocre, frostbitten
2. Scallops - might make you sick
3. Witches' den

First two are self-explanatory. Third, I'll explain.
Food's okay, Americanized sushi. Three stars, tops.
Ambiance is good, might bump it up to 3.5.

But the service? Chinese waitresses, speaking Chinese. I'm Chinese, I understand Chinese. They're selling my coworkers and me crappy alcohol on the side. Come on...

Hiro's where it's at."

"Love their joe. Need help in the a.m. Moms and high schoolers orderin' doubles, line's out the door. Not waitin' ten min for a plain cup. Usually buy beans, brew at home. Now, I'm goin' elsewhere for a quick cup. They should get someone just for straight coffee orders. More business that way."

"Place looked good, real good.  Wanted to like it, I did.  Slow night, we were there.  Downstairs bartender, friendly fella.  Went upstairs when friends showed.  Service slow, food unimpressive.  Had a few dishes, variety and all.  Place got potential, bring up the grub and service though."

"No frills joint. Apartments converted to motel rooms. No AC during our stay. February, mind you. Outside, crisp sixty degrees. Inside, sweltering eighty-plus. Inquired about AC, got a negative. Guy said it was a no-go, just hot air coming out. Tried it myself, 'cool' setting on the thermostat. Room got stuffier. Staff, friendly though."

"Airport's a mess. Dirty, ridiculous. Not user friendly. Need more outlets. Business folk need to charge their laptops and cells. Layovers? Good luck. Long walk ahead. Stressful travel, made worse by this place. Slot machines everywhere. Lose your cash quick."

"Six years since we last dined at Streets of New York. This time, thin crust pizza, Caesar salad, bread knots. Pizza, not great, but better than remembered. Salad, inedible. Romaine, brown, past its prime. Returned it, no questions asked. Cheesecake, on the house. Embarrassing for the cook. Doubt we'll return."

"Airport shuttle, slow to leave. Waited 20-30 minutes, still not full. Called for pick-up, they said 15-minute window, hour to airport. No thanks, took taxi instead. Worth the cost. Don't recommend, too slow. Two stars for cheap rates, that's it."

"We've been hitting up Casey Jones for a while now, but our latest visit was a real letdown. Ordered the new "Juicy Lucy" burgers with some friends, and they came out bleeding, like a gutted horse. Cheese oozing out like a bad horror flick. Took 'em back, they came back cooked to a crisp, like they were torched with a propane torch. No cheese, either. Used to recommend this joint, but now I'm singing a different tune. Won't be back till they get their act together in the kitchen."

"A coupon of twenty dollars didst arrive in the post,
And thus, we didst decide to give it a go.
But alas, 'twas many moons ago,
Since last we didst set foot within its doors, ye know.

The service, fair and good, didst meet our needs,
But lo, the victuals, they didst not please.
I asked for cheese enchiladas, full of hope,
But found instead, a scant few scraps of scope.
My love, she didst order chicken, with high expectations,
But they were served with naught but disappointments.

The sangria, a lone bright spot, didst cheer,
But not enough, alas, to make us come near.
So, there you have it, friends, a tale of woe,
Of a restaurant visit, that didst not go."

"Fair victuals and courteous attendance, but alas, the cost doth mount for ribs and flesh! Menus old and new, didst claim desserts were included, yet when requested, 'twas not so. Pray, inform us ere we order, lest we suffer such surprise! A star or twain doth drop for this mischance. \n\nThis place doth suit a solitary diner or pair, for greater worth, since sides and seafood pancake, do remain the same, despite the number gathered round."

"Hark, good sirs, I pray thee tell me why,
This place, Dos Gringos, doth seem so vile?
Awhile, I have not stepped foot inside,
Or perchance, 'tis the Tempe site that doth shine?

The lavatory, with foul stench doth reek,
And all about, doth seem most unclean.
I'd ne'er desire to eat, nor take a seat,
In such an atmosphere, so unkempt and mean.

Why, pray tell, do folk gather here,
When fairer, merrier places doth abound?
Scottsdale, with glee and mirth doth cheer,
And yet, this den, doth sadness profound."

"Jasons Deli, been there a few times, always good. Ordered delivery today, forgettable. Turkey sandwich, dried out croissant, falling apart. Best brownies, usually, but not today. Overcooked, burnt taste, dry. Disappointing meal, won't be ordering again soon."

"Rip-off. State-of-the-art gear, but too rich for our blood. Friendly staff, except one doc who suggested putting our pup down. Cold, man. Dog stayed a day, cost us two grand. Took him elsewhere, same treatment, fraction of the cost. Doc's motto: do no harm, just drain the wallet."

"Alack, the store didst boast of many a line,
But, alas, the wares they didst display were scant.
The MAC, which I didst seek, was in short supply,
And most of what they had, was broke, or didst seem quite used.
The service, too, was woeful, I didst find,
For those who worked, didst sit, with nary a word or sign.
No greetings given, nor didst they ask if aid I needed,
Which, alack, I didst, in truth, most sorely need.
Disappointed, I shall seek the indoor place,
In hope of finding better fortune, and a happier face."

"Food's decent, prices are right. Got there late, still got seated quick. Shared a steak with the missus, 'cause I wasn't that hungry. Steak was alright, coulda been cooked better. Hash browns were meh, toast was good, eggs were fine. Coulda used more salt, but I get it, old folks don't wanna overdo it. Alright spot if you're hammered or don't wanna deal with the strip, but not someplace you should go outta your way for."

"Hark, what news is this? A dinner most foul,
Where service was lacking, and prices most steep.
The food, though passable, did not make amends
For rude behavior and poorly trained attendants.

Our server, a scowling maid, did glower and sneer,
And smiled not once, as if 'twere a crime most dire.
The busboy, too, did reach across my wife,
A faux pas, indeed, and cause for great strife.

I called them on their errors, loud and clear,
And sought the manager, who did appear.
He apologized and changed our waitstaff then,
But still, my ire did not abate, nor calm descend.

For such a place, with prices high and mighty,
Should offer service worthy of a king or queen.
Alas, they failed, and thus my counsel be,
Seek elsewhere for dinner, lest thou suffer similarly."
