"Went to Leroy Fox for grub tonight. Used to be the Hotel Charlotte. Nice reno job. Place was hoppin', though. Couldn't hear ourselves think, what with the racket and the live tunes. Had the northern bird, fried up nice. Came with a side. Menu looked good. Service was decent, but kitchen got slammed, place was so packed. Can't say I'd recommend it for chatty dinners."
"Hotel was plain, not worth the dough. One night was enough, then we scored a better joint for the same price."

"Alas, my friends, I must confess,
This BJ's doth earn but two stars at best.
Their victuals, when correctly served, do please,
But alack, their kitchen doth oft decease.

Seven times have I visited this place,
And six times, they didst fail to grace
My table with the order that I sought,
Leaving me in discontent and naught.

A veggie pizza, sans cheese, doth seem
A simple request, yet they doth deem
It too complex, for every time, they err,
And bring me sausage, or cheese, oh so queer!

The waiters, with apologies, do abound,
But alas, their kitchen doth astound,
In ineptitude, it doth excel,
Leaving me to pine for a meal well-spelled."

"Methought I wouldst love this eating house, and thus my spirit didst soar with anticipation. Alas, upon entrance, I didst find the space to be small and cramped, with tables packed in like sardines in a tin. Though I understand the need for profit, 'twas a discomfort to mine ears. My spouse and I didst dine there on a Monday, and verily, we couldst scarce hear each other's words. The menu, too, didst lack variety, and service was slow, some twenty minutes betwixt order and consumption. And alack, the victuals themselves were naught but middling, with bacon hard and oily, and my companion's sandwich lacking its promised garnishes. In conclusion, 'tis a noisy, mediocre establishment, not worth the coin."
"Records, all used and beat up. Dollar bin stuff, priced at five bucks and up. Service? Forget about it. Not worth my time."

"I lived in the Bay Area, so I knew what good Asian food tasted like. I was in Montreal, and I wanted to see how their Chinatown compared. Beijing was supposed to be top-rated, so I gave it a shot. It was your typical loud, crowded joint, but I wasn't there for the ambiance. I ordered the Chicken Soo Guy, and the server told me it was some special Asian sauce. Yeah, right. It was just sweet and sour sauce. Didn't impress me much. The spicy beef had a little kick, but only because we asked for it extra spicy. Otherwise, it was nothing special. Overall, I wasn't impressed, and I wouldn't go back."

"OnTrac's delivered plenty of Amazon Prime packages for me, but twice they've delayed. First, they couldn't deliver after I paid extra for next-day. Today, their tracking said 'out for delivery,' then 'UNDELIVERABLE - OTHER REASONS,' followed by 'REDELIVER ON NEXT BUSINESS DAY.' The delivery guy couldn't give a solid reason for the delay. Maybe he was running late and figured he'd handle it the next day. Either way, OnTrac needs to step up their customer service game. Their delivery guys should smile and say thanks, like I do when I receive my packages. Instead, they just hand over the package with a scowl and drive off. They do a decent job delivering, but compared to UPS or FedEx, they're not quite there. Two stars, tops."

Friday eve, I chanced upon a new Panera,
With youthful friend in tow, to dine and share.
She sought a bread bowl, full of soup, so fair,
But staff member snarled, "Bread bowls? Nay, we've none there."
My friend, dismayed, chose salad, chicken-laden,
Whilst I, a Thai flatbread, savory and gladden.
The passageway, narrow, led us to our seat,
The decor, unimpressive, with poor lighting beat.
Tables, unclean, with toilet paper in plain sight,
Awaiting food, I ventured forth, to do my duty right.
The kitchen, dull, like decor, lacked finesse,
Yet prices lower, than Paradise, or Wildflower's excess.
But Fry's, on route, offered La Brea's delight,
A tasty loaf, with olive oil, rosemary in sight.
And Progresso's soup, a can, so pure and true,
A meal most satisfying, for less coin, anew.

"This joint used to serve up some top-notch grub, but last Thursday's burger night was a bust. My burger was cooked way ahead of time, and it showed - dry, cool, and tough as shoe leather. Same story with the chicken - super dry and tough, like trying to swallow a rock. In the old days, their burgers were freshly made, juicy, and served hot. Not anymore, it seems. If you want to draw a crowd with your burgers, don't precook the meat and let it sit around. That's what McDonald's does, and look where it got 'em. Two stars for service, at best."

"Tis but a humble abode, my dear,
No special charm doth it hold, save for the eyes of a stranger.
The confectionaries, too sweet by far, doth harm the taste buds,
And the price, oh how it doth inflate the cost!
A lollipop holder, designed by Katy Perry, no less,
For twenty-five silver coins, a steep price to pay, indeed.
I give it one star for the merriment of its decor,
And another for the convenience of its cafe, anon."

"Hepatica didn’t impress me much. Went in for some roses, waited damn near half an hour. Place was empty too. They tossed in some greens, bug-bitten and all, without sayin’ a word ‘bout the extra cost. Then they had the nerve to double-charge my card. Real smooth, those folks."

"Methinks last eve, my second attempt didst prove,
Alike the first, in trouble didst it bring.
Two woes didst plague mine appetite,
Uncooked dough, a taste most vile, didst cling.
And red sauce, a poor choice indeed,
Didst fill mine innards with excessive speed.
So now, I shall forsake this woeful feast,
And seek Domino's, where Spinach doth truly gleam."

"Vegan options? Sure, but limited. Miss meat and dairy, huh? Food was good, not great. Drinks? Average at best. Overpriced, too. Staff? Rushed, unpleasant. Host? Obnoxious, rude. Not worth it. Won't be back."
"Went there with a few others for lunch on a Fri. Food was good, but service was slow and inattentive. Had the Blue Petit Mignon, nice portion size."

"Food's good, no question. But service? Down the drain. Ordered three gyros, only got half. Called 'em up, manager's all attitude. Still waitin' for our grub, hour and a half later. Paid in full, still nothin'. Terrible."

I craved drunken noodles, found this joint, and gave it a shot. Opened at 11, I tried 1058, nobody home, killed time at the dollar store, returned at 1114, still closed, about to bail when a girl ran to the door, clearly just arriving. Ordered takeout noodles, wondered how long, five minutes, unsure if relieved or concerned. Greasy, reheated, flavors lacked zest. Had decent drunken noodles in San Diego, seeking comparable quality here. Third try with noodles, a few other Thai meals, worst thus far. Unfamiliar with Thai cuisine, recognize freshness, didn't get it here. Also, smelled like old lady mothballs.

"Terrible customer service at that wedding dress shop. Me and my sis went in, nobody said hi. We looked around for 10, had to flag someone down. Told her what we wanted, she blew us off. Awful experience. Two stars 'cause the dresses were nice, but that's it. Wouldn't recommend it to nobody."

"Twas a mediocre feast, methinks,
At this establishment of sustenance and drink.
The server, distracted by calls from afar,
Didst attend to me with slowness and tarry.
My order, placed with haste, didst take its time,
Five minutes passed, ere I couldst dine.
And when at last I sat, with naught else near,
I found my meal to be o'er-saturated with oil,
The rice and egg roll, both cooked beyond repair.
Alack, I shall not trouble them again,
For greater fare, my taste doth seek and yearn."

"Paid $300 for me and the missus to get in, and it was a decent show, but not worth the scratch. Found out later we were one of the few who actually paid, which stung like a sonofabitch. 

Interesting stage show, some of 'em interacted with the crowd, but the price tag was way outta whack. 

If you're one of the lucky ones who got in free, take a gander, but otherwise, steer clear unless you're rollin' in dough. 

Performance art was entertaining, and the audience interaction added a nice touch. Think well-dressed street performers meets Tap Dogs meets Blue Man Group-lite. 

Don't wanna say it's a ripoff, but it ain't worth the entry fee, especially when most of the joint was filled with freeloaders. 

Feelin' a little sour, like I'd been taken for a ride. It's a stage show followed by a regular ol' nightclub. If you mixed the sign with a dash of cabaret and a light sprinkle of Cirque du Soleil, you'd get rose rabbit lie."

"Grassroots' vibe feels right, but the cook's got some 'tude. Told him it was my second time there and he was outta what I wanted, he says it's 'cause everything's fresh. Sure, I get that. But c'mon, baked potatoes? That's basic. He goes on about how they're doin' well...whatever, dude. Just apologize and move on. Food's alright, but I'd stick to drinks here."

"Haven't been to the Sunset road Outback in Vegas for a year now. Food went downhill. But when they opened a new spot in Henderson, we gave 'em another shot. Big mistake. Steaks weren't cooked right, even after they recooked 'em. Service was meh. Only good things were the bread and salmon. Disappointing, Outback."

"Alack, what woeful fare didst thou provide,
O restaurant of ill repute!
My wife and I, in search of sustenance,
Didst venture forth to thy abode,

But lo, the victuals thou didst serve,
Were naught but mediocre, o'erpriced.
Thy cocktails, ten dollars each, didst taste,
Of naught but common spirits, void of zest.

Thy servers, raw and unrefined, didst seem,
As if new-hired, without finesse or gleam.
The steak, a New York strip, didst come,
In scanty portions, cooked not aright,
Asked for medium rare, but got it medium,
A faux pas, indeed, a sorry sight.

My wife's sandwich, rare, didst she receive,
When medium was her chosen creed.
Ten minutes passed, ere it didst return,
A sorry state, a culinary affront.

Alas, the cost, forty dollars, didst mount,
For such a meal, a paltry sum, no doubt.
Disappointment doth reign supreme,
In this, thy house, a gastronomic tomb."

"Went to this joint once. Pitt club was raising funds, don't know if it was just this spot, but underwhelmed, I was. 

Ordered a pumpernickel bagel with plain cream cheese. Bagel was thin, flavor lacking. Cream cheese scarce, poorly applied. 

Location decent, price right, but Einstein's or Panera, better options, they are."

"The merchandise? Yeah, it's pricey, but folks seem to like it. My gripe's with the customer service. Been to this joint before, no issues. This time? Not so much. Sign at the door said 40% off one men's item, no specifics. Grabbed a shirt, got in line. Waited. Finally, it's my turn. Told the item I picked wasn't part of the promo 'cause it's new. Said I didn't want it. Cashier mumbled something, not sure if it was to me or her headset. Then said they'd honor it. Whole time, no eye contact, no greeting, no thanks. I was the one who said thanks. Felt like they were doing me a favor by selling me the shirt. TSA agents are friendlier."

"Tourist trap, World's End pub. Overpriced, catering to out-of-towners. Locals need not apply. My crew and I got the cold shoulder from the barkeep, like we were dirt. 'You ain't tourists? Too bad, move along.' But we stuck around, had a decent time. Won't be going back, though."

"People dig this joint for its generous helpings and slick presentation. But let's be real, the wait's a bitch and the grub's a tad greasy. Not exactly the freshest fare either. And if you're lookin' for something light, forget about it. But hey, who's counting calories in Sin City?"

"Satay, a clean and cozy joint. I visited with a big group, which probably affected my experience. We tried to wait for everyone's dishes, but that was a mistake. Food got cold, 50 minutes for everyone's dishes to arrive. Disappointing. My chicken pad thai was basic, flavorless. Not impressed. Unlikely to return, unless it's for happy hour."
"Floors were a mess, sticky with disease. Bartenders made up for it with stiff drinks. Cheap too. Worth another visit if I'm in town."

"Went to the new Lincoln Square Mall location. Decor's a mess. Cramped seating, depressing track lighting, drop ceilings, and weird art that keeps bumping into you. Out of the first two things I ordered, one being a special, but the other a basic bread-based dish? Pasta took forever to come out, and my friend's was cold, cream sauce congealed. Sigh."

"Reserved a table for six at a joint participating in Restaurant Week. Ordered the appetizer sampler, which was decent, but the chicken pot pie nuggets lacked flavor. Two of us had the crispy fried game hen, which was nothing special, and the other four went with the Niman skirt steak. Sides didn't come until we asked, and they were just zucchini and mac and cheese. Dessert was either freshly baked cookies or a trio of sorbets. Cookies were good, but nothing impressive. Got hit with a bunch of extra fees on the bill, including a charity donation and an upcharge for the appetizers. Didn't notice any mention of it on the online menu or when we ordered. Not worth it. Won't be back."

"Went to Rustic Cafe for brekkie, 'cause it had a four-star rating. Yelpers usually know their shit. Not this time. Hubby and I both got omelets. Filled with stuff, but damn greasy. His hash browns were cold. We were both pretty underwhelmed. Price was decent, though. I'm picky about my OJ. If it's not fresh, I'm taking off a star. Don't even drink concentrate at home. Why pay three bucks for it?"

"Terzetto, a joint that looks good on the outside, but doesn't quite deliver. Menu's got the usual suspects, but nothing too exciting. Service was top-notch, though. Server was on it, attentive and helpful. Food? Just okay. Steaks were cooked right, but lacked that rich beef flavor and a nice char. Sides were forgettable. Not a bad value, price-wise, but you get what you pay for. Underwhelming experience."

"Tom's ain't all that. Good vibes, solid service, but the grub's gotta step up. I mean, a grilled cheese should be simple, right? Not here. No butter, one lousy slice of cheese. You call that a grilled cheese? And don't even get me started on the price. Twelve bucks for a half-assed sandwich and some fries? C'mon, man. At least the server was friendly. But seriously, Tom's, get your act together. Vegetarians deserve better than a sad salad and a side of fries. Let's see some real options, huh?"

"This joint was a real stinker. Came here for lunch with a colleague from out of town. Closest place around, but it didn't do much for me. Dingy inside, service was lacking. Just had a chicken salad, forgettable experience."

"Methinks I've visited this place afore, 'tis nigh my work, ye see.  The matron that doth attend the counter, a kind soul she be.  Yet, alas! the victuals, they do leave much to be desired, I fear.  Ne'er have I had cause to complain, but today, my meal, 'twas not of the best.  Shrimp fried rice, I did order, come midday, and lo! 'Tis different, mayhap a new cook, or mayhap they didst change the oil.  Aye, 'twas fragrant, but devoid of flavor, alack!  Nay, not even soy sauce nor pepper couldst save it, 'twas unfit for consumption, I do declare.  Fie upon it! Now must I seek another meal, to sate mine hunger."

"Yesterday, I chanced upon a bakery called Batch,
Whose fougasse breads did pique my curiosity's catch.
I hastened there today, my heart full of cheer,
To sample their wares and see if they were dear.

Alas, my hopes were dashed, my expectations crossed,
For though their breads were shaped like pretzels, they were lost
In taste and texture, more like pizza crust,
Than the delicate, airy fougasse I had trust.

Their "Hello Dolly" bars, seven layers deep,
Were sinful, true, but not worth the step,
For in their roasted garlic, sundried tomato,
And rosemary, I found a flavor monotono.

Still, I did eat the bread, though heavy and dense,
But found it lacking in the finesse I had sense.
A firm exterior, soft within, it did not show,
Leaving me to seek elsewhere, I do know."

"Fuel Pizza, a place of dismay,
In uptown Charlotte, doth lay.
A star for location, fair enough,
And one for service, with a gentle touch.
But alas, the pizza, bland and weak,
Doth leave the taste buds in a state of seek.
The side salad, colorful indeed,
Yet lacking dressing, a true misdeed.
Combos, too pricey for such fare,
A flavorless pizza, without compare.

A nearby Sabarro's, a better choice,
With larger slices, and a better voice.
The decor, interesting, yet unfinished,
The restrooms, clean, but poorly garnished.
A theme restaurant, in a prime spot,
Yet a mess, and a sorry plot.
I'd not own this place, with shame,
For Fuel Pizza, a disappointment came."
"Room, just okay. Staff, nice. Parking garage, spooky. Pools, unimpressive. Adult store nearby, weird and creepy. Convenient spot, but won't stay again."

"Our meal began with promise, fair and bright,
The service, though slow, did please our sight.
The waitress, friendly, did attend to our needs,
And the chef, generous, did discount our deeds.

But alas, the drinks, they did not impress,
Tasting of dirt, we did express.
I sent them back, three times, in dismay,
And stuck to water, pure and plain, I say.

The chips and salsa, decent, they were,
But the fajitas, oh, how they did fare.
Beef, tasting of teriyaki, strange and new,
Chicken, dry, and not juicy, I do declare.

Alas, the taste, it did not delight,
And thus, we shall not return tonight."

"Tis not a place for tourists, but for those with kitchens true,
Where cooks may find their ingredients, both fresh and new.
Few stalls did offer samples, and ready-to-eat fare,
Was scarce, unlike the bounty found at Pike Place fair.

The market, though small, did surprise, for in the South,
I had thought the warmer clime would bring forth more abundance.
But nay, 'twas held in a small parking lot, beside Old Town,
A humble gathering, with little fanfare or renown."

"I dropped into Nourish after hearing some rave reviews on Yelp. I'm not a vegan or gluten-free kinda guy, but I do appreciate a healthy meal that still tastes great. Nourish seemed like it would fit the bill, but unfortunately, it didn't quite deliver. First off, the regular water tasted a bit funny, so it's a good thing they had flavored options. The salads were tasty, but tiny - more like an appetizer than an entree. The sandwiches were a better value, but nothing special. The sweet potato fries were decent, but not as good as regular fries. The dipping sauce was the highlight, though. The atmosphere was laid-back and comfy, and the service was top-notch. But at the end of the day, it's the food that keeps me coming back, and I'm not sure I'll be returning to Nourish anytime soon."
"Mac and cheese with chicken, my husband had. Said it was good. I had the baby back ribs. No good. Dry, burnt. Not worth it."

"Methought I wouldst have loved this place, forsooth,
A diner, dive, or drive-in, all are my heart's desire.
And here, within the Melrose district's bounds,
I had hoped to find a gem, a true delight.
But alas, the victuals didst not please mine taste,
A breakfast sandwich, with eggs, sausage, and cheese,
Upon a croissant, which was naught but mediocre,
The eggs and sausage, greasy, lacking in zest,
And the potatoes, m'eh, a side dish most uninspired.
Yet still, I shall give this place another chance,
For hope springs eternal, and my heart doth dance."
"Steak, excellent. Duck, mediocre. Sides, good. Hot water, $5. Ridiculous."

"This joint's like a mega-mart, but they might be in over their heads. The meat's not the best, it's brown to black, and that ain't right. Meat should be red, period. I'll still shop here, but I'll steer clear of the meat counter. Other than that, the store's alright."

"Hark, what woeful tale doth come from Henderson's Picture People! Alack, the white backdrop, marred with scuffs and scratches, doth show in my photos, a sorry sight indeed. And lo, the cropping, poorly done, doth leave much to be desired. They gave me but a limited number of photos, and nary a word of warning, that I might prepare mine own self for such a paltry sum. And worse still, they would not take my coupon, worth twenty gold coins, no, not even for the photo CD, which doth seem most strange, for nowhere in the script doth it say, 'excludes the photo CD.' Alas, the manager himself, a man of little wit, didst deal with me, and verily, my husband, a gentle soul, didst ask me to calm myself, lest I lose my temper altogether. And so, I weep and wail, for my poor photos, and vow to tell all who will listen, to avoid this place, forsooth! A pox upon Picture People, and their false guarantees of satisfaction!"

"Cabo, new name, same old story. My fiancé and I swung by after work, looking for some grub and a drink or two. Margaritas all around, we thought. But no, they had other plans. Waited for the hostess, waited for chips, waited for drinks. I waited for water, too. Never came. Drank my fiancé's instead. Service was slow, like molasses in January. Food? Meh. Margaritas, though. Top-notch. Blended like a dream. They honored the check-in deal, gave us sopapillas to go. Why do Stations Casinos keep changing their restaurants? This one, not an improvement. But hey, I'd come back for another margarita. That's for sure."
"Good service, decent drinks, but the grub's just alright. Stuffed peppers and dates, that's the ticket. But the joint itself, it reeks of stale rags. Makes you question the cleanliness."

"Beer? Sure, it's fine. Food? Meh. Don't get me started. After binge-watching too many restaurant rescue shows, I should've known better than to expect much from a place with a never-ending menu. BJs? No exception. Pizza-like products dominated the menu, so I went with a flatbread. Tomato and cheese? Check. Sausage? Not so much. A few sad, sausage-like substances scattered on top, but don't get your hopes up. The bread itself? Crispy in spots, soggy in others. Not exactly a masterpiece. And let's be real, if they can't nail the main attraction, what are the chances the other 90 pages of menu items are any good?"

"We ate at the joint during restaurant week, which we didn't know about till we got there. Menu was limited, my husband's pork belly appetizer was too greasy to eat, and his cod entree was flavorless. My sea bass was overcooked, tasting bland and not fresh. Only thing we liked was the dessert. First time here for my birthday, and it was a letdown after all the good reviews. Maybe it was an off night, but we won't be going back. Our waiter was cool, though - knowledgeable and friendly."
"Three hours, nose deep in books. Wi-fi, seats, and noise - good. Service? Needs work. Friendly folks, that's what matters. Peach green tea lemonade? Enjoyed it."

"Food's good, but making good Italian grub ain't easy. Even O Garden gets it right sometimes. But this joint thinks it's "exceptional Italian food" and charges accordingly. Problem is, it's not even close. Just the same ol' dishes every other place serves. No originality. 

It's like all the other overpriced restaurants in Vegas nowadays. High cost, low atmosphere, mediocre food. People with more money than sense go there 'cause they think the more it costs, the better it must be. 

And don't even get me started on the bartender's greeting. "I'll be with you in a minute!" Like I'm just a number, not a person. If I wasn't meetin' someone, I'd have walked out."
"Last visit, bad. Hair in curry, pic posted. Naan flat, dry. Chicken lackin' in curry. Variety, some good grub. Pricey, not worth it."

In fair St. Mark's Square, where Venice's splendor doth reign,
A restaurant doth sit, with ambiance so fair and bright.
But, alas, dear friends, our visit didst prove in vain,
For service slow and spotty didst mar our night.

When first we sat, the waitress didst say,
"Water forthwith shall be brought, ere we doth play."
But lo, the liquid nectar didst not arrive,
Until our meals and drinks didst grace our lives.
And when the parmesan didst make its way,
The man who asked didst vanish, leaving dismay.

Our waitress, fair and lovely as she seemed,
Didst absent-mindedly drop a chunk of cheese, unheeded.
Throughout the eve, her presence didst wax and wane,
Leaving us to ponder if she didst our plight maintain.

The food, alright it was, and swiftly didst arrive,
As if 'twere prepared ere we didst our order devise.
But, friends, the whole experience didst leave us cold,
And to return, our hearts didst not enjoin.

For in this city, full of restaurants galore,
We shall seek elsewhere, and try our luck once more.

"Applebee's Arrowheads, a place we'd rather not be. Karaoke night, a horror show it was. DJ and crew, they sang most of the tunes. Families, they came after eleven, an age limit there should be. High school girls, they screamed Spice Girls, oh how we wanted to flee."

This joint's got killer yogurt, especially the oatmeal cookie. But their service? Pure aggravation. They dish out samples like it's a chore. I stood there five minutes, waiting for some dude to hook me up. He finally hands it over, grunts at me, and that's it. No thanks, no have a nice day. Forget about it. Not going back.

"Been here a few times, loved it. But not this visit. Only English speaker wasn't around, communication difficult. Asked for Andy, got a lady instead. Therapists chatted, distracting. Lady seemed rushed, bothered. Not great. After massage, saw man taken to private room. Odd. Wondered why private room while my friend and I were out in the open. Don't support shady business. Unsure if I'll return."

"Underwhelmed. Late to the table, server seemed indifferent. Asked for drinks, got the menu, but no drink. Guy at the end of the table, didn't bother asking about food. Starving, I persevered. Ordered the apocalypse sow, disappointing. Dry, lacking flavor, aoli just plopped on top. Meat crumbling, had to eat it with a knife and fork. Should've stuck with the soup."

"Two stars for frozen hot chocolate, a tasty treat indeed,
Yet service slow, our patience doth it try.
Thirty minutes to be seated, a wait most long,
And water came not quickly, but with a lag.
Then fifteen minutes more, ere our order taken,
A delay most vexing, our hunger unabated.
Forty-one minutes passed, ere food did arrive,
A wait most tedious, our spirits doth dampen.
Fare was but so-so, neither great nor small,
Leaving us unsatisfied, our bellies unfilled.
Hark! I shall order at the window next time,
To avoid such delays, and make my visit more prime."

In fair Rio, where I didst lodge with friends,
The state of things was far from pleasant.
The rooms were foul, with mold and grime,
And pool, alas! was closed most of the time.

The food, though passable, could not compare
To other inns where I have lodged before.
The gaming floor, in disarray and stench,
Didst make me wish for fresh air and a bath.

The elevators, full and slow, didst test
My patience, as I waited with the rest.
Reception and concierge, long lines didst form,
And shuttle service, poor, didst leave me warm.

A cab, I thought, would be a better choice,
For Rio's faults didst leave me without voice.
But still, the rate was fair, I must confess,
Though other hotels, better kept, didst address.

So, friends, take heed of my words, I pray,
And avoid Rio, lest you wish to pay
For troubles and for woes, as I didst do,
For other hotels, better, there are, 'tis true.

"New joint, still workin' out the kinks. Sat at the bar, server took his time comin' back to take our order. Shared General Li's dish, asked 'em to split it. They brought out an extra plate, which was cool, but coulda put the damn thing on two plates instead of makin' a mess. Rice was a bit scarce too, not enough to balance out the soy sauce, so it was a bit too salty. Tip: ask for extra rice."
"Food was mediocre. Kung pao chicken, same as any other Chinese joint in a strip mall. Celery overload. Wife had cashew chicken, similar appearance, but with nuts."

"Tits and ass, that's what it's all about. Dancing, schmancing. They think they can distract us with some mediocre moves and a pair of knockers. Holly, the silent one, let's her body do the talking. And the black chick and white dude, they do all the singing and talking. But let's be real, it's all about the view. For 113, it's worth it. But for 85? Not so much. And don't even get me started on the fake boobs. La Reve at the Wynn, now that's a show worth seeing. Amazing, just like the Wynn itself."

"I'm a big fan of Pottery Barn. Their stuff is solid, built to last. No flimsy veneer crap here. But let me tell you, the service at this particular store? Not great. The manager, in particular, is a bit of a snob. Treats me like I'm some kind of slacker because I dress down on weekends. Like I'm not a paying customer or something. But you know what? I don't give a damn. I'll just stick to the floor samples and buy my stuff online or at the Henderson store. That's how I roll."

"Tried this joint out. Only a couple other customers. Waitstaff was friendly and attentive. Clean place. Clam Chowder was decent. Angel Hair pasta with Marinara sauce? Not so much. Too bland. And there was waaay too much water in the bottom of the bowl. Should've drained it better. Wasn't pleased. Returned the dish. Kid's cheese pizza was alright. But that's it. Waiter knew about my issue but didn't say squat. Owner didn't come over either. They took the dish off the bill, but that was it. Didn't leave me feeling too eager to come back."

"Hark, my friends, to Ditka's we did stray,
Where food, oh so wondrous, did abound.
Shrimp cocktail, a feast for the eyes,
Pork chop, a marvel of flavors profound.
Burgers, juicy and cooked to perfection,
Dessert, a sweet delight, no deception.

But alas, our waiter, a woeful soul,
Didst leave us waiting, our thirst uncontrolled.
Beverages, a tardy arrival,
A beer, requested, but nary arival.
Bread, a scarcity, we didst implore,
And dinner orders, a laggardly pace, once more.

Yet, thank the stars, our meal was free,
A blessing, indeed, for waiter's negligence did we see.
In upscale halls, service should ne'er falter,
A period, no excuses, 'tis the standard, none other.

Food, a 2.5 rating, we wouldst confer,
Bar area, a wise choice, for those who do infer.
My kin, in bar, they dine with glee,
Waitstaff, attentive, a pleasant spree."

"Not the greatest show in Vegas. Jokes were meh, stage was nothing special, and overall felt like something from another era. Got bored halfway through. If you're gonna see one show, this ain't it. But hey, if it's free and you're feeling nostalgic, go for it. Just don't expect too much."

"Hubbard Ave Diner, been there a few times. Pie, good. Service, good too. Food, average. Kitchen, inconsistent. If it's slow, order's right and hot. If it's busy, forget it. Need someone to keep things moving in the kitchen."

"Food's the focus, service is usually satisfactory. Let's get on with it. Bread's decent, but that's the highlight. Pasta's a letdown, especially the creamy garlic chicken - needed lots of salt. Fresh tomato mozzarella's no better. Gorganzola salad's the only saving grace. Local's great, but this place doesn't cut it. Olive Garden's better."

"First-time customer, last weekend. Not the best start. Ordered, waited, wrong order. Took too long, everyone else finished. Had to take mine to go. Waitress cleared the check, no discount, no apology. Food was good, but not worth it. Won't be back. Screw up, miss the meal, offer something."

"Wet burritos? No thanks. Ruins the whole damn thing. They tried to cook my half-eaten burrito in the oven and told me they couldn't add anything else unless it was on top. What a joke. I should've walked out right then and there. But no, I didn't. And you know what? I ended up paying twelve bucks for a crappy burrito with chicken, rice, and cheese. What a waste."

"Upon our morning sojourn, we chanced upon this eatery,
Whose reputation, fair and bright, did reach mine ear.
A non-chain, unique and quaint, I thought it would be,
But alas, 'twas much like any other place, I fear.

The eggs benedict, with avocado, I did select,
A variation from the norm, a change of pace, I reckoned.
But lo, the dish, though different, did not impress,
As menus oft do lie, and this one, I must confess.

My companions, their salads and skillets did devour,
With relish and delight, their hunger to assuage.
But I, with coffee absent, didst feel quite vexed,
For in my morning haze, it is my chiefest solace.

The wait, though not unduly long, did seem to drag,
And children, unattended, ran about with glee.
The service, too, did leave much to be desired,
For I, a patient man, didst wait in vain, quite tired.

In conclusion, this establishment, middling fare,
Did provide, but shall not see me there again, I swear."

"High hopes, but underwhelmed. Arrived post-rush, staff friendly yet lackluster. Indoor/outdoor seats, a plus. Ordered two veggie sandos, dressed with a hair in my salad. Soggy, but passable. Might return, if nearby."

The Shoppes at Wynn Las Vegas are no joke, kid. They got high-end stores like Barney's, Coach, and Burberry. They're caterin' to the rich folks who can afford that kinda luxury. My buddies and I checked out Michael Kors and my girl found a purse she liked. The associate said it was $1400 and she quickly put it back and walked away. We ain't got that kinda money, so we were just lookin'. The place itself ain't too special, but there's a two-story waterfall in the middle that's pretty cool. Lots of tourists takin' pictures, so you might wanna join in on the fun. If you're a regular Joe like me, you might wanna check out Miracle Mile or Fashion Show instead. When the summer heat hits, this place'll be a nice spot to chill and escape the strip.

"Went on a weekend mornin' more than a year back. Still remember the details, though. Place was a mess, disorganized. Lady who seemed to be in charge was barkin' orders left and right. Maybe we shoulda waited for a table outside, but I reckon we woulda had a more peaceful meal."

"Methinks 'twas my second time to dine at The Parlor,
With mine own dear boyfriend and brother in tow.
I had been there once before, at opening week,
And found the victuals to be quite pleasing, I do confess.

But alack! This last time, the service was poor,
The food, but mediocre, and the staff did bear
A most unpleasant demeanor, full of disdain,
As if they thought themselves above their station.

Verily, I say, the pizza there is naught but hype,
Overglamorized and served with a foul attitude.
If thou art in search of pizza in that place,
Better to seek out NYPD or Pizzano's, in faith."
"Rude guy did my nails. Gel manicure, cuticles, skin, messy. Staff same. Won't return."

"Hark! If thine address doth lack veracity,
And thou dost shun the call of assistance,
How canst thou hope for plaudits of the crowd?
Alack! My stomach did anticipate thy fare,
Now doth my heart feel doubt and dismay."
"Hype train derailed. Bread's good, meat's lackin'. Paid for bread, got a snack. Waited 25 minutes, left hangry. Two stars for bread, but it's oily. Better sammies elsewhere in Vegas. Overhyped."

"Petal's been hit or miss for me lately. Mostly misses. Can't seem to find anything that fits right. Feels like I'm trying on a dozen things and they all fall short. And that damn dressing room, always feeling rushed. Like they're trying to hustle me outta there. Don't like it one bit."
"Taste in my mouth, strange. Maybe from roach in my burger. Free wings on Monday night football, not bad. Cheap beer too. Raised over a grand for local teens, good work. In Wickenburg now."

"Methinks I do not fancy this place, my dear.
As background, know that I am a Chase devotee,
With two accounts that do bear my name.
I ventured forth to cash a check of some worth,
And lo, the new accounts specialist did ply his trade,
With zeal most fierce, he sought to open yet another account,
And would not take nay for an answer, by the stars.
He pestered me for fortnight, with calls most dire,
Beseeching me to return and open wide the door.

And, prithee, teller, what say you of this sign?
A service that doth allow deposits by phone, divine.
I asked if 'twere available for my humble Blackberry,
But alas, the teller knew not, and had to seek the truth.
Alack, fair maiden, shouldst thou not know this?
Yet, praise be, thou didst not lie, nor play the fool.

Lastly, a word of caution, ere I take my leave,
Concerning the ATM, and the foul trash that doth conceive.
A plastic bin, o'erflowing, and most neglected,
A sorry sight, and ill-omened, for those who do expect.
A better first impression, pray, for those who may be swayed."
"Scouted joint before bailing. Went there with a buddy. Grub was meh, service meh, ambiance sketch. Not worth another visit."

"Don't like this place. Bartender tries to help, but no greeter. Cashier too busy talking about tips to serve us. Finally, she asks what we want. No receipt, told to go to table. Don't talk to me, I'll forget the number. Chairs too tall, have to jump to sit. Burger undercooked, but better than overcooked. Whole thing too expensive if I gotta wait in line."
"Pizza's fine, I reckon. Not too fussed about it, though. Maybe 'cause it took 'em an hour to bring it over when we're just five minutes away."

"Frustration's been building with Danny's Family for years. Upselling's off the charts. Brought in a new ride, barely broken in, and some salesman's still pushing a buff and wax. Tiny crack in the glass, and the windshield guy's telling me it's gonna shatter any second now. Come on, man. Good job on the detail, but enough with the hard sell already. Wish there was a better way, but looks like this is how it goes down at car washes."
"Tacos, dry meat. Wife's salad, bad. Chicken, sauce like Italian."

"St Rose Pediactrics is grinding me down. Eleven am appointment, forty-five minutes in the waiting room. Still no doc. Time to cut back on clients or appointments. Enough time to write this and read all the other reviews."

"Food was top-notch. Galbi burger with house kimchi on the side, can't go wrong. But what's with the bad review? Big group, 12+, they accommodated us, warm welcome. Why the delay? Two parties' grub took 30 minutes longer than everyone else's. Appetizers came quick, sweet potato fries, great. Huge gap till the entree. Waitress said kitchen was backed up, burger was being made. 10 minutes later, forgotten order. Finally, burger arrives, 30 minutes late. Don't care how busy they are, should've been our turn. Watched other tables get their food faster. Disappointing, not because of the food, but still."

"Had a good time with the fam, but the service was crap. Place was cool, lots of TVs, not many people. Server was terrible, forgot stuff, didn't bring things. Not just picking on her, she even said she was ignoring us. Game area was meh, machines took my money, had to keep getting them fixed. Food was okay, house salad was good, pizza was thin, had to ask three times for more dressing. Mom ordered a wheat beer, got something else, then had to wait ten minutes for the real deal. Had fun, but won't be back."

"Sushi joint was mediocre at best. Been to better places in Charlotte, Davidson, and Asheville. This one was a snooze. Not terrible, just uninspired. Got another coupon for Ayrsley's place. Maybe that'll be an improvement."

"A platter of cheese enchilada and chicken taco, the waiter didst bring to me, despite my order of beef enchilada and chicken taco. I didst inform him of his mistake, and he didst look upon me with a quizzical gaze, asking if I desired a side of beef. Fie upon this establishment! I shall not return."

"Chips and salsa, good. Margarita, decent. Spinach dip, passable. Cheese enchilada and chile relleno, average. Husband's chicken chimichanga, subpar. Beans and rice, a highlight. Friend from Canada, beef enchilada and hard shredded beef taco, enjoyable. Flan, tough."
"Food was lousy. Ravioli like rubber, chicken burnt to hell. Waiter didn't give a damn. Never going back. Plenty other joints around, try one of them instead."

"Alack, I must confess, fair friends,
That KAK, a bakery of much renown,
Didst fail to meet my expectations,
In truth, their cupcakes didst frown.

Their customer service, I must admit,
Was prompt and friendly, a true delight.
Jay, the proprietor, didst respond swiftly,
And his staff, with smiles so bright.

But alas, the cupcakes themselves,
Didst fall short of my hopes, I do declare.
Frozen in the middle, stale and dry,
The icing, hard as stone, didst lie.

I had heard great tales of KAK's prowess,
And looked forward to their sweet success.
But now, I fear, I shall not return,
For their cupcakes didst not impress.

A shame, indeed, for such potential,
Wasted on poor quality, I do feel.
But still, their service, I must commend,
For that, they didst truly excel."

"O, woe is me! My internet service doth fail,
A plague upon the land, a curse most vile.
Three times this week, my connection doth cease,
And with it, all my work, doth come to naught.

They say they work to improve, to make it better,
But nay, their efforts doth but cause disaster.
Down completely, doth my service go,
Leaving me to suffer, woe is me, oh so!

They be as bad as Comcast, a dire fate,
A pox upon them, for their woeful state.
Alas, what shall I do, my work doth suffer,
My patience doth wear thin, my temper doth flutter."

"Alas, my heart did yearn for fondness towards this place, yet alack, 'twas not meant to be. A combo dish, with pork and chicken, fried rice, didst I order, in hope of satisfaction. But lo, the pork, so chewy and tough, didst offend mine taste, and the chicken, oh woe, a clump of jelly-like sauce, most vile and gross. The rice, so soggy, and the beans, ill-suited to the rest, didst complete mine dismay. Alas, the staff, so friendly, yet the crowd, in haste, didst they herd, like cattle to the slaughter."

"Dinner at this joint was a slow affair. Waiters took their time takin' our order, and the place wasn't exactly bustlin' with activity. We went for "The Theresa" and some corn on the cob with chili, cheese, and lime. The grub was decent, but I reckon it was a mite pricey. Six bucks for a single ear of corn with chili and cheese? That's a mighty steep tariff, pardner."

"Food? Adequate at best. Service? Subpar. Waiter didn't speak English, order got botched. One-hour limit. Ginger overload. Atmosphere? Meh. Lighting sucked. Not going back, even though it's close to home."

"Been to this joint dozens of times. Steak's always good, but seafood's a crapshoot. Had a lobster yesterday, total rubber. Barely edible. Shoulda known better, but I'm a sucker for surf 'n' turf. Disappointing, that's for sure."

"I went to this joint in Pittsburgh 'cause folks said I had to. Place was packed, real chaos. Told to find a seat, then told to sit down. Waited a bit before some dude came by. Then, two more showed up right after. Food was alright, fries were cool, stuffed in the sandwich like that. But overall, nothing special. Don't get why it's so popular. Worth it? Nah."

"Terrible service at Caesar's. Found previous guest's skivvies in our room. Took six hours for extra blanket, 24 for pillows. No wake-up call. Supposed to be world-class? Don't think so. Told staff, they didn't care. Manager said it's a holiday weekend, they're short-staffed. Solution? Hire more people. Hello."

"Food's alright, not mind-blowing. Typical Greek fare, you know, gyro sandwiches and the like. Service? Forget about it. You'll be lucky to get a smile out of 'em, let alone attentive service. Prices are meh, but hey, it's an option if you can't get a table at that joint around the corner and you're hankerin' for some Greek grub."

"Hark! A group of colleagues, I didst come,
In search of mirth and merriment, perchance.
The decor, unique and intriguing, didst catch mine eye,
But, alas! The black, a tad too much, didst lie.

The chairs, they didst seem, of custom make,
And, verily! They didst cause discomfort, forsooth.
A triangle, sharp, didst dig into mine back,
Forcing me to sit, upon the edge, in haste.

The service, prompt and friendly, didst abound,
But, alack! No other souls, didst gather round.
We ordered diverse, ramen noodles, waffles, too,
Edamame, and sliders, our hunger to subdue.

The edamame, a delight, with garlic, so bold,
Dipping sauce, a perfect complement, to unfold.
The ramen, alas! Didst fail, to meet mine expectations,
Broth, too thick, and lukewarm, a sad observation.
Noodles, a bit warmer, but not by much, I fear,
Finishing, a struggle, without a fiery cheer.
My comrades, in agreement, their ramen, not hot,
A disappointment, we all, didst surely got.
Waffles, passable, but not worth another try,
Sliders, a mediocrity, didst pass them by.

I wish this place, success, in times to come,
Yet, alas! Not a place, where I shall be become."

"Place ain't what it used to be. Corners being cut left and right. Queso fundido, gone. Service, slow. Not 24/7 no more. Drinks, scarce. Hassle every time I order one. Better options in town. No point in wasting time or cash here."

"Terrible meal. Guacamole was off, tasteless and gritty. Tacos, a disappointment. No cabbage, cilantro, or lime. Fish tacos, a joke. Black beans and rice, flavorless. Table next to us, sent food back. Uncooked. Wouldn't come back for this meal."

"My buddy and I decided to grab some grub at this joint while the others slept off their hangovers. I was starving, so I didn't care what they served. Luckily, the buffet started at 11 am for 11 bucks a pop. It was an Italian spread - spaghetti, lasagna, meatballs, and Parmesan chicken. They also had soup and salad. 

The food was pretty rough, though. My clam chowder was nasty, and the only thing I really enjoyed was the fettuccine. I stuffed myself with bread because I didn't want to feel like I hadn't gotten my money's worth. 

I was surprised how cold some of the dishes were, considering they had just opened the buffet when we arrived. We were even the first ones there."

"Twas but a mediocre feast, my friends,
A mashup of two eateries, so unrefined.
Panda Express and Taco Bell, they did blend,
Into a dish most strange, and fried rice, oh t'were pretended.

But lo, the fried rice, it was not good,
Like a drunkard's craving, it did not satisfy.
For munchies, 'twas a poor choice, I say,
Better to stick with one, than this odd array."

"This joint? Meh. Lunch, yeah? Chicken salad, fruit. Scoop of mediocrity on greens, grapes, strawberries. Asked for dressing, they said it's on the table. Oil-covered squeeze bottle, tasteless vinegar. Unimpressed."

"Alas, my dear parents, I brought thee here,  
Forsooth, the view doth please mine eyes, so fair.  
And yet, the victuals too, they do impart  
A taste most wondrous, worth our while, I thought.  
We ordered steak, a tender cut, 'twain true,  
The filet, and salmon, fresh from the sea, anon.  
But lo, the beets, they didst taste most sour,  
A shame, indeed, for such a costly hour.  
Two hundred dollars, and no drinks, alack!  
I cannot recommend, though the view doth lack.  
So, two stars, for the sight alone, doth shine,  
But nay, the fare, it doth not merit a line."

"This joint was just okay. Did the all-you-can-drink champagne brunch, which was top-notch. But the grub? Not so much. Salad was mushy, eggs were bland, everything swimming in grease. Breakfast burrito? Forget about it. Normally, when I'm hungover in Vegas, anything breakfast sounds good. But not here. Left feeling peckish. With all the great buffets in Vegas, give this one a pass."

"Samurai Sam's. Three of us. Different orders. My tacos, good but sparse on meat. Veggie-heavy. Friends' teriyaki bowls, rice-loaded but lacking substance. Panda Express serves more food, better value. Bill tallied $24.70. Two stars. Sorry."
"Thanksgiving dinner at this joint? Meh. Limited menu, uninspired grub. Service? Forget about it. Clueless runners, oblivious waiters. Cheesy decor. Pass."

"Skip this joint if you're lookin' for grub that'll knock your socks off. Decor's neat, but the chow? Not so much. You get a sweet take-home glass with your brew, but the nosh? Bland, baby. Service was A-okay, but can't save the day. Forgettable eats. Go for the trinkets, not the food."

"Claim Jumper in Cali's been good to me. Avondale joint's alright, but not great. Been back a few times, still not impressed. Service is meh. Once got undercooked chicken. Not sure if I'll be back. Still love the one in Deer Valley, though."

"Hark! Twice in four journeys to JJs didst we return,
And find the sub, alas! without the toppings we had sought.
The second time, we didst call to voice our discontent,
And they, with nerve, didst lay the blame upon us, yea, even we.
They offered us a new sub, but at a cost,
To drive it back, and claim it, we didst not choose, no, not a chance.
For ne'er shall we return to that place again,
Where service poor, doth reign supreme, in such a state of woe."
"Subpar experience. No welcome or direction upon entry. Burgers, rare. Food, average. Lacking flavor. Smash Burger, superior. Don't see this joint lasting. Operations, disorganized."

"Overpriced and overhyped. Ordered the wrong steak, but at $60 a pop, I expected better. Bone-in, sure, but chewy? No thanks. Had better steaks in Texas, and for less money too. Sides were meh, except for the mac and cheese and spinach. Drinks? One iPad for seven people? Come on. Cheesy bread was good, but not worth the two-star rating. Service was fine, but nothing special. Two hundred bucks for a bad steak and some mediocre sides? No way. Won't be back."

"Tuna, cold as ice. Veggies, frozen stiff. Service, unremarkable. Travel nonstop, see the little things too. Second time at Phillips, hoped for better. Next, saving dough, hitting CPK quick in terminal B."

"Buses full of rowdy kids, barely any adults to keep 'em in line. Chaos, pure chaos. Kids runnin' wild, throwin' balls, no one to rein 'em in. Tough to enjoy the exhibits with all the commotion. They gotta get their act together, or it's gonna be a long day."

"Food was decent, but could've been hotter. Place was clean, though upholstery was dated. Service? Slow. Like, painfully slow. One waitress for a near-empty joint, and our 30-minute meal dragged on for an hour. Might return if they step up the service game and get the rice and soup piping hot."

"The cookies and muffin, delicious. Service, patient and kind, despite rude women with kids who sent their food back. Ordered the chopped salad, mixed greens were old and decomposing, smelled terrible. Disappointed the chef didn't care enough to check the quality of the food. Not picky, but a lazy chef who doesn't care about food quality is a bad sign."

"Drove out to Camelback from Gilbert for a burger joint rated top-notch by Phoenix Magazine. Delux, the name of the place. Two burgers, mixed fries, lemonade, Diet Coke, and a tip came to $39. Fries were decent, but the service was lacking. Our waiter disappeared, and we had to ask another server about our order. Everyone around us was getting served, and they ordered after us. Not worth the risk for a $40 burger. We'll stick to Burger King or McDonald's, where we know what to expect."
"Sunday dinner at this joint. Me, the missus, and our eight-year-old picky eater. Service was snappy, atmosphere loud, grub decent. Basic burger, cheese, bacon, fourteen bucks. Fries extra. Ripoff."

"Pearl was a letdown. Sushi top-notch, but everything else subpar. Large selection, happy hour all day, food excellent. But damn, it was hot. Almost made us sick. Plates chipped, waiter too touchy. Soup came after entrees, weird. Won't be back."

"Placed my order at 8:10. Forty minutes later, still no word from the restaurant. They claim to update the status, but all I see is "pending." If all they do is delivery, they'd better do it damn well. Delays happen, but they should've placed the order promptly. Not impressed, Foodie Call. Won't be using them again unless I have to. Selection's limited too. Spoiled by Chicago's options? Maybe. But here in Charlotte, it's slim pickings. Called 'em up, they said they're swamped and short on drivers. Solution's simple: hire more, pal."
"Food's good, but I won't be back due to poor management. It's one of the worst according to government inspectors."

"Hark, what chaos doth this Saturday night bring!
The crowd, so great, doth make it hard to sing.
We came ere eight, yet still we had to wait,
Till nine thirty, when the show did finally abate.
The throng, so dense, doth make it hard to see,
The band, their music lost in cacophony.
The fire marshall, Bill, would shut the place,
So full, 'twas hard to move, or find a space.
All for greed, they sold too many tickets,
And now, the crowd doth suffer, in their pickets."

"Food, four stars. Service, one. Maybe it was an off day, but the experience was lacking. Our waiter, Rodrigo, tried his best, but the service was subpar. Had to wait 15 minutes for a refill, while the table next to us got theirs twice. Odd, for a nice, moderately priced spot. Personally, I go out for the whole experience. Good food isn't enough; dining out should be more than just a pricey meal and pretty decor. Doubt I'd go back."

"Hark, what news is this? A place of victuals,
Where food doth lie, almost of average worth,
With hot wings, fries, and such, a meagre feast.
But lo, the service doth move at snail's pace,
On a Friday afternoon, a woeful sight,
I must seek out the waitress, ere I pay.
The drinks, they doth flow, and bottled beer,
A paltry selection, Miller and Coors, alas.
And sports, they doth play, on screens all round,
A sorry state, that doth detract from the ground.
Alas, poor tavern, with two stars, I fear."

"Terrible staff. Like I was bothering 'em just askin' for directions. Rude, miserable bunch. Spa? Don't waste your time. Dirty, smelly. Couldn't last 20 minutes. Front desk? Forget about it. Waited 10-20 minutes every time. Better hotels on the strip for the same price. Not comin' back."

"We tied the knot at The Venetian, a swell joint. We return annually. Night before, me and the missus, plus four pals, hit a quaint Italian eatery. Atmosphere was top-notch, and we're suckers for pasta. Ordered a chicken pasta dish, but it arrived sans poultry. Waiter was regretful, scurried to the kitchen, then returned with a bowl of microwaved, cream-drenched frozen chicken. Absurd. Friends' pizzas were lackluster too. A funny letdown."
"Food court review. Bad. Price no good. Better burgers at McD's. Cheaper too."

"Space was off the lobby, views of the pool and Strip. Great atmosphere, sports-oriented vibe with flat screens broadcasting the Wisconsin v Arizona game. Burger was good, but service (Erin from South Dakota) was slow. Took 40 minutes for our burgers, rings arrived cold and inedible. They comp'd our coconut shrimp app and rings, appreciated, but would've preferred timely and hot food. Not particularly busy, so hard to imagine what the problem was...judging from other Yelp reviews, service issues persist."

"Brat Haus, a joint with promise, failed to deliver. A birthday celebration for my son, 26, turned sour. High hopes, based on Yelp's praise and the spot's hip vibe, were quickly dashed. Service was lacking, grub subpar. My boy's chorizo dog, flavorless. My wife and I shared a burger, cooked well past prime. Pepper, the dominant taste, overpowered the already questionable beef. No booze for me, but thirsty pals struggled to snag a server's attention. Pretzel fundido, the lone bright spot. Doubtful about a return visit."

"Methinks 'twas not a feast most wondrous fair,
That I didst partake of at this place.
The wonton soup, a dish of some renown,
Didst please my taste, and filled my belly with delight.
But, alack, the Orange flavored chicken,
Was but a middling dish, scarce worth the mention.
And, oh, the fried rice, how plain it didst seem,
Like unto white rice, lacking in flavor and zest.

In sooth, I wouldst liken this place to Panda Express,
A decent alternative to fast food, perchance,
But, alas, the service here, doth leave much to be desired,
For thou must pay a tip, ere thou dost depart.

The dining hall, a space of some disarray,
Doth seem unfinished, with boxes piled high,
A sight most strange, and not a little vexing,
Yet, still, I wouldst say, 'tis worth a try."

"Sushi? Yeah, tried it a few times. When I'm out running errands, you know, Home Depot, Target, Pet Smart, I get a hankering for some raw fish and cold Japanese brew. And lucky me, there's a sushi joint conveniently tucked away in the same parking lot as Home Depot. But let me tell you, it's been a disappointment every damn time."

"Wasn't impressed. Got up, sold for the hand wax, and tipped well in advance. But when it was ready, they didn't do a good job cleaning the inside. Still had trash on the floor and door panels. Outside and tires were wet, though. Just use them for the cheap exterior wash next time."

"O, what a woeful tale of woe doth here unfold,
Of yoga class most vexing, full of sound and fury,
In Phoenix' city, where the sun doth shine bright,
I chanced upon a studio, with candles alight.

A class of yoga, called Candlelight, didst I attend,
With hopes of peace and tranquility, my heart didst rend.
But lo, the music loud and boisterous didst play,
And with each passing moment, my annoyance didst sway.

The instructor, uninvolved and bored didst seem,
Pacing back and forth, with little care or scheme.
Her demeanor, distant, tired, or perhaps bored,
Didst leave me feeling empty, and my soul unexplored.

Yet, the studio itself, didst have a certain charm,
Urban, artsy, hipster, a place of some disarm.
And though the workout, didst leave me feeling spent,
I cannot say, this class, my spirit didst invent.

For those who seek, a deeper, calmer way,
To find their inner peace, and yogic sway,
I pray, avoid this place, with its cacophony,
And search instead, for a quieter harmony."

"I returned for round two, hoping for another knockout. Last time, the service was top-notch, and the sandwich was a real contender. But this visit, the cheese-stuffed tenderloin with signature white sauce was a letdown. The sauce was more like cheese whiz, and the pork was tough. I left most of it on the plate, but no one offered a discount. Maybe they should stick to sandwiches, something they do well. A restaurant needs both great food and smart business sense to succeed. That's the way it goes."

"Stopped in at this joint on my way to Cali, hopin' for somethin' gluten-free before my flight. Place was packed, couple of stressed-out servers. Long bar, like you'd expect in Vegas, and a bunch of cramped tables and booths. Server was nice enough, pointed out a few options she thought I'd be able to have. Didn't seem too sure about the gluten-free stuff, though. Asked the kitchen if I could have the nachos, they said yeah, but I prob'ly shoulda been more careful 'cause of the language barrier. Heard the kitchen staff talkin' and it sounded like they weren't too sure either.

Went with the nachos anyway, they were pretty good. Chicken, cilantro sauce, nacho cheese, and jalapeños. Good-sized portion, took some leftovers with me for later. Didn't get sick, so I guess the nachos are okay here. Other notes, heard another customer complain about dirty silverware, mine was alright. Food came out pretty quick, but not a lot of attention from the servers. Prices were average for airport grub.

Overall, it's alright. Might try somethin' different next time I'm in the airport."

"A pair of drinks, o'erpriced, didst I purchase,
From a bartender, grouchy and quite surly,
Who, with haste, didst serve the loud and drunk fair maidens,
Whiles others, patient, waited in vain.

A vexing wait, of fifteen minutes' length,
Didst I endure, for drinks of little strength.
Methinks 'twas folly, to part with my coin,
For such poor fare, and service so slow.

Yet still, I sought to quench my thirst,
And thus, didst pay the price, with nary a fuss.
But, gentle reader, take heed of my tale,
And avoid this tavern, with its grumpy ale."

"Fuddruckers, once a proud burger joint, now reduced to a shadow of its former self. Quality's taken a nosedive since opening. Can't blame a great burger for poor service and quality. Had three combos, one with half and half, but only got three onion rings and 14 fries. That's not what I expected from Fuddruckers. Used to get five to seven onion rings, 20 to 25 fries. None of the combos my family had today met my expectations. Place was dirty too. Tables, restrooms, floors. They nickel and dimed us to death."

"Foul victuals and potions! Fair restaurant's design, yet naught but woe doth fill mine eyes and belly. Staff and masters, attentive they did seem, save for one small matter. First Friday, full the hall did swell, alack! A sorry choice indeed. The manager, in sooth, did own he had not tasted aught of food or drink. A sign, perchance, of ill-prepared feast? 

Beers of art, unfamiliar, yet mediocre all. Mixed draughts, in batches brewed, so said the servers. Flavorless, alas! All failed to please.

Appetizers, three sorts of chips and dips, they bore. Chewy, as if undercooked or stale, the chips did feel. Salsa, queso, guacamole, all lacked zest. Queso, like potato broth, did seem.

Five tacos, on the menu, alas! Dry, flavorless, the carne asada and carnitas did taste. Lukewarm, at best, their temperature did lie. Cactus, unique, with mild grilled savor, yet so-so it did remain. Calamari, o'er-breaded, o'er-fried, it did seem. Chicken, flavorless, as if frozen, thawed, then sauced, at last, did taste.

Staff and masters, visits many, did make. Our meal, they did comp, and ask us return. Gladly, will I update, if food doth improve. Hark! I do implore, good sirs, heed my words, lest ye wish to suffer similar woe!"

"Amore, once great, now blows. When it opened, management was friendly, prices were cheap, and pizza and wings were excellent. I recall Amore making a deal with my cousin's middle school for pizza Fridays, and the kids loved it. But things took a turn for the worse after the original owner sold the place. New employees were just looking for extra cash, not putting their heart and soul into cooking, delivery, and service. Food quality suffered, and prices kept rising. Now it's just another greedy joint."

"Panda Express, a place I shun,
Where veggies once did make me swoon.
But needs must when the kitchen's in disarray,
And healthier options beckoned me away.

A first-time visit to the Buckeye site,
With veggies fresh and crisp, a pleasant sight.
No sickness did ensue, a happy fate,
And chicken, mushrooms, steak, a decent plate.

Flavors strong, yet meat and veggies blend,
A culinary symphony, a friendly end.
A place of need, not of great desire,
But in a pinch, a meal to conspire."

"Four of us rolled in without a reservation. No biggie, we plopped down at the bar. I ordered a killer mojito, shoutout to the bartender. 

Sat outside, live music jammin' below us. That's where the good times ended. Service was meh, drinks took their sweet time arrivin' at the table. Food? Nothin' special. Appetizers were decent, entrees? Three small tacos for $30? No thanks. Banana cream pie? Basic. 

Might give 'em another shot, though. Other menu options looked alright."

"Place was a real disappointment. Tables weren't cleaned, staff was uninspired. Ordered fish, asked for tartar sauce, didn't get it. Another guy had to ask for bread, which was also missing from my order. Chicken was crispy but flavorless. Catfish had no taste either, just some Old Bay seasoning. Cole slaw was stale. Not worth the time or money. Skip it."

"Panchero's looked promising, the tortillas were a highlight, fresh off the press. Friendly staff, attentive service. Basic burrito, underwhelming rice, steak lacked zest. Medium salsa needed more heat, but the Tapat\u00edo saved the day. Quesadillas were decent, Monterey Jack the sole cheese option. Prices were fair, worth another visit."

"Rositas, been goin' there 'bout 10-15 years now, mostly for lunch during the week. Their tacos, real good. Enchiladas, cheesy, taste nice, but also a gut bomb, makes ya wanna take a nap. Always been one of my spots, 'd give it four stars, but last Sunday, food was just okay, service was crap. Waitress seemed pissed to be servin' us, got an order wrong, we didn't even see her for 20 more min, tortillas for fajitas came 20 min after the fajitas, check took another 20 min. Typically go there every month, but haven't been in 3-4 months, hopin' this was a one-off, next visit'll be better, place ain't gone downhill."

"Bakery Square, once home to Nabisco, has undergone urban renewal. A few years back, no one would've given a damn about this forgotten community. Now, it's a prime example of revitalization. Google, Urban Active Fitness, and a quaint coffee shop (can't recall the name) have set up shop here. Parking's a breeze, with ample garage space and street-level spots available off-peak. Weekends bring a different crowd - horn-honking Mercs, brake-slamming Beemers, and VW GTI-driving, skinny jean-wearing yuppies fighting for street parking. Good luck with that."

"Overpriced for what you get. Three pieces of equipment, tops. My five-year-old was bored after an hour, but my twenty-month-old enjoyed the Toddler Zone for a bit. Don't forget to bring socks, they cost three bucks a pop. Place was clean, staff was friendly. Not worth the twenty-two bucks we spent for 1.5 hours. Would rather take the kids to Bounce Jungle or Bounce U for half the price."

"A second time to Indian Land's Red Bowl didst we venture, with hopes high and spirits light. Alas, our expectations were not quite met, for though the service was fair, the victuals didst leave much to be desired. Won Ton soup, a bowl of broth most rich, didst please our taste buds somewhat, but alas, the Beef a la Szechuan, devoid of flavor it was, and the Sea of Love seafood combination, a sorry sight indeed. Alack, a pervasive lack of spice and zest didst plague their dishes, a shame for such a pleasant place, with d\u00e9cor most fine. Methinks we shall not return, our appetites unfulfilled."
"Indian food? Been better. Price? Not worth it. Service? Shit. Waiter? Jackass. No tip. Followed us out. Saag paneer? Small portion. Naan? Expensive. Closed between meals. Not going back."

"Place looked good, renovation-wise. But food and service? Not so much. Sat at the bar, hoping for a quick bite. Messy. Barstools everywhere. Unprepared. Staff, a bunch of kids running wild. Dropping silverware, laughing too loud. Pollo fundido? Awful. Floury taste, mushroom soup sans mushrooms. More like a fried fajita wrap. Disappointing. Wanted it to be good. Hope they shape up."

"Methought, fair sir, that entering in and ordering face to face wouldst prevent mistakes of great proportion. Alas, howe'er, 'twas not the case, for those who served me didst add three items of worth, which I hadst not requested, nor didst desire. I didst not reckon the total to be just, yet knew not until mine arrival at home, what a foolish sum 'twas. Verily, 'tis a wonder, howe'er, that I didst not espy their errors, ere I made my exit."

"Came here when Market Street had a line, like it usually does. But it's getting tougher to find something good. The hamburger steak used to be solid, but this time it was off. Maybe it was the grill. The philly steak sandwich wasn't great either. Not enough cheese and the meat was flavorless. Needed salt. We were so disappointed we skipped the friend wonton and teri beef, our usual go-tos."

"Hark! I didst order from this place today,
A dish called General Tao chicken, they say.
And I didst ask for it to be quite spicy,
But alas! They didst not heed my request so nicely.

For when it came, the sauce was naught but tame,
A mere packet of hot sauce, what a shame!
But on the bright side, the chicken was quite fine,
Big chunks, not like some other places that combine.

But still, I fear I shall not order from them again,
For their General Tao sauce doth not meet my demand.
A pox upon their house, for they have failed to please,
My taste buds, with their lackluster sauce, if you please!"
"Patio's nice, but service stinks when it's busy. Made us feel like we didn't belong, and that's no way to treat paying customers. Won't be back."

"Nay, I shall ne'er return to that wretched place,
Whose foul stench of smoke doth pierce mine nostrils,
And service, oh so poor, doth leave me in disgrace.
The victuals, middling at best, do pale in comparison to IHOP's fare.
I would not recommend it to mine enemy, let alone a friend,
For 'tis a den of disappointment, and sorrow doth attend."

"Two cleaners, for two hours, didst I hire,
To scrub an empty condo, devoid of fire.
When three days passed, and I didst arrive,
The place didst look the same, save for some items that didst thrive.
Alack, the alcohol, light bulbs, and cleansers,
Were gone, leaving naught but empty containers.
I asked, why takest thou all from the shelves?
And was told, 'twas custom, for new tenants to receive.
But I say, 'if it be not thine, leave it be.'
A policy of honesty, for all to see.
They didst clean the oven, fridge, and some drawers,
But what else didst they do, in those two hours?
My feet, bare and black, didst testify,
That their work, was not of the highest quality.
They offered to return, and clean once more,
But I, didst decline, their offer, forevermore."

"Fie upon this wretched feast, my friends!
'Tis but a sorry sight, a culinary offense.
Pasta, pizza, Chinese food, all drowned in grease,
A veritable famine, not a feast, I pray thee.

The seafood, a paltry selection, fried and limp,
The shrimp, unpeeled, a laughable whim.
Pulled pork and chicken, drenched in sauce,
A sodden mess, without a trace of grace.

Beans, from a can, alas! no fresh delight,
And the salad bar, a sorry plight.
No choice but what they deign to give,
A bitter pill, a culinary slight.

Service, a word unknown to these,
Neglectful, slow, with nary a please.
A call to arms, the manager must come,
To right the wrongs, ere all is undone.

Yet, in fairness, one star more I give,
For desserts sweet, a saving grace, they live.
Mini donuts, ice cream, cookies, a treat,
At least, in this, they did not falter or cheat."

"Paid for service, but the house remained unclean. Surfaces were wiped down, dirt pushed around. Sent pics of filthy tiles after their so-called cleaning. No attention to detail or care from this outfit."

"Went to 1902 tavern for lunch. Waiter was on something, man. Ordered a steak, but it was overcooked and cold. Salads took forever to arrive, and they were full of iceberg lettuce and tasted like shit. Place was a dump, and the area's filled with vagrants. Don't know where they come from, but they need to get a job, like their fathers did."

"Hark! If Hometown Buffet didst open a casino, 'twould be a sight to behold, me hearties! For a mere $25.99, thou dost receive a feast fit for a king, or so they say. But alas, the dining hall, noisy and drafty, doth resemble a high school cafeteria, I do declare. The victuals, diverse though they may be, are cooked to a mediocre standard, I fear.

"But wait, there be a silver lining to this cloud, me friends! They do serve beer, in a humble solo cup, no less. A pity, though, that they do offer but a single brew, Miller Light, and naught else.

"So heed my words, good sirs and madams, and hold tight to thy utensils, lest thou lose them forevermore. For in this place, they do not abound in generosity, nor in cleanliness, I do suspect."

"Chicken tenders at Popeye's Louisiana? Forget about 'em. They're drier than the Sahara desert. Stick with Canes, my friend. Their chicken is cooked to perfection, not left to wither away under a heat lamp."

"Late night, I was jonesing for dim sum. This joint was the only spot still serving. Been craving it for months, so I devoured everything. Bad move. Got food poisoning. The pork shumai smelled off, but I was too hungry to care. Should've known better. Limited dim sum menu at night. Sweet custard buns and shrimp balls were decent. Banana leaf sticky rice, shrimp potstickers, and pork buns were kinda like dim sum. Pork shumai and shark fin potstickers were either bland or bad. Heard there's better dim sum in Vegas. Avoid this place unless you're desperate."

"Hark! I called at six o'clock, a question to pose,
If here they had a place for children, young and small.
The man who answered, said with haste,
Aye, we have a kids' section, come one, come all!

We arrived at half past six, with eager feet,
But lo! The man, he told us, ere we could seat,
That at seven o'clock, the kids' area doth close,
And left us with a problem, like a thorn that grows.

My children, two in number, both of tender age,
One nine years old, the other but two,
What to do? My eldest, with the teens he could play,
But alas! My youngest, what could he do?

I asked for a refund, and swiftly did depart,
To Jumpstreet, a place where children's joy doth start.
For there, the kids' section, open doth remain,
During their business hours, clean and free from pain."

"Verily, I must confess, this establishment doth falter. Service, slow and surly, doth mar the experience. Hummus, nigh bereft of zest, doth taste of naught but tahini's earthy pang. Lentil soup, akin to Chef Boyardee's concoction, yet lacking in flavor, doth leave a sour taste. I do not recommend this place, for there be many other options in the vicinity, far better than this woeful tavern."

"Place always out of items. Twice ordered chicken fried steak, no fresh bread. Waitress slow, takes long cigarette breaks. Team leader no better, never smiles. Food good when hungry. Love unlimited hot cocoa. Avoid water, tastes like algae."

"A plague upon this eatery, dear friends,
For portion size, a king's ransom doth it cost.
And should thou dare to order guacamole,
Pray tell, how much dost thou expect to savor?
A chilly meal, half-eaten, doth await thee,
As frost doth claim thy carne asada's fate.
Yet, credit where credit is due, good sirs,
They did replace it, and thus our ire doth dissipate.
The flavors, verily, do please our taste,
But alas, the price and portion, a bitter pill to swallow, doth make us wary of return."

"Place was nada special. Started with spring rolls, they were meh. Had the Pacific Cove salad, fishy and segregated on the plate, not my jam. Crab and shrimp tasted frozen, everything was just ok. Not worth the dough. Atmosphere was basic, like any other chain joint."

"Ay, fondness didst I bear this place, forsooth,
For Sundays, work doth keep me from its reach.
But lo, the checkout, doth it take so long?
Twenty minutes, sometimes more, doth linger strong.
Tons of stations, yet few hands doth man.
Six stations, two open, throngs doth stand.
Manager doth cry, 'Cashiers to the fore!'
But nay, none doth heed, nor doth bestir.
Wasteful days, in line, doth fade away.
And lo, some twenty workers, doth stroll.

Dill buttons, of worth, this store doth sell,
Metal and plastic, of finest quality to tell.
Hobby Lobby brand, and others, doth pale.
Recently, Dill, they doth cease to hail.
Two for one, their own brand, doth prevail.

Now, online, I doth order, to avoid the fray,
Forsooth, no more lines, doth trouble my day."

"Shopping on Black Friday? No thanks. Had a cert to use, but no way was I going through that hell again. Planned ahead this time. Went last weekend, 10:40 am. Place was empty. Organized merchandise, not a single shopping bag. Scored four items, one a gift. No receipt since it was a gift cert. People bringing alcohol in? Bad idea. Girl went up the escalator the wrong way. WTF?! Not a stressful morning at the Forum Shops. Forever 21 wouldn't allow that."

"We showed up late and they had sold our room. We had to shack up elsewhere for the night. Not cool. But we got free brekkie for two days and the spread on the exec floor was better than expected. Gym and net cost extra and have limited hours. Disappointing."

"Plenty restaurants serve great grub for a fraction of the cost. This place? Just okay. Shrimp on my salad, over-salted to hell. Cut my tongue like a knife. Scallops, good. Steak, good too. But not worth the outrageous prices."

"Hark! I've visited this place thrice, my friend,
Twice for the morning meal, and once at noon.
The victuals here are akin to Denny's fare,
Naught special, save for the atmosphere.

This eatery doth feel dingy, foul, and grim,
With locks of hair within the dish, a whim.
The service, middling, yet the staff doth seem
As dirty as the place, in sordid dream.

No more shall I return to this domain,
For cleaner pastures call my name."

"Perplexed by all the five-star reviews, we walked in, out-of-towners looking for a quick bite near our workplace. Packed house, thirty-minute wait, no big deal. But the humorless greeter, sourpuss all night, set a bad tone. Tofu appetizer, ikkura and condiments, delicious. Hand scallop soy roll, small, not spicy as requested. Edamame overcooked, various rolls lackluster, ingredients not fresh. Twice sent back the tuna sashimi. No alteration to the bill. Green tea creme brûlée, tasty but tiny portion. Sake, good, but for twelve bucks a bottle, it should be."

"Alas, poor service doth mar this place,
A pedi, once a treat, now doth disgrace.
The polish, fair and bright, doth please,
But all else, alack, doth bring disease.

A young man, with cuticle nippers bold,
Doth attack me, leaving wounds cold.
Four hours pass, and still I feel,
The sting of his rough, ungentle zeal.

And then, for Mani, oh how rude,
They leave us sitting, like birds in a mood.
Our arms, they pull, from their sockets,
Leaving pain, where once was comfort's socket."

"Dark, classic vibes, like the good ol' days. Service? Sub-par. Maybe 'cause I looked like a comfy tourist, but hey, we spend money too. Hate how high-end steakhouses ignore health-conscious folks. Hubby likes steak, but I wanna eat right. How 'bout some healthy options, Capital? Had to modify my salad, took off all the extra stuff. Entree-sized, but still left me hungry. Special order messed up too. Watched my husband eat while I counted carbs in the napkin. Won't be back. Too many better places to spend my hard-earned cash."

"Cold beer, good eats, decent TVs. But the service? Awful. Every damn time, it's like they're trying to set a new low. New servers every visit, and I heard it's because the management's crap. Treat their people like dirt, they do. Time to cut our losses and find a better joint. Plenty of other great sports bars out there with decent staff."

"Hark, what news is this? A burger, medium well, yet dripping red within. A feast most foul, upon my lips it doth not fit. Alas, fair burgers, how thy quality doth suffer from poor form. In size, thou shouldst increase, yet in a manner wise. Forsooth, Stack'd in Shadyside, a quarter of the cost, doth serve a better feast. And lo, the hall, it was a chilly space, with tables small, that could not hold our plates with ease. The burgers, too, they were presented in a basket, tiny and cramped, making it hard to partake. Fear not, good sirs, for this place doth have its charms, yet near by, better fare and atmosphere doth wait, at a price most fair."

"Hamburger steak's alright, but too pricey. Starts at 4.50 bucks, but can easily add up to a ten-spot with extras. Takeout's quick, about a quarter hour for a burger. But the joint gets loud when it's hopping."
