"Back for round two. Greek salad with kabob, but the plate was laughable. Couldn't even cut the bird without a mess. Iceberg lettuce? Forget about it. And the chicken? Swimming in sauce. Stick to the gyro, that's the ticket. Had it last time, pure gold. Good folks here, no doubt."

"Upon a whim, we chanced upon this place,
And found our time there, quite mixed in grace.
The tofu rolls, they pleased our taste,
But not so much, the lemongrass broth did waste.
My pad se ew, it was good, I must confess,
But sweetness marred its flavor, I do profess.
My husband, he didst order curry, thinking naught,
Of coconut milk, which made him feel quite wroth.
Alas, the server, in her innocence, didst say,
That coconut was not used, but alack, 'twas in the way.
He swapped it out, for pad Thai, with haste,
But lo, the spice, it didst burn, and left a nasty taste.
In sum, Curry on Murray, doth win our praise,
For service, decor, but food, methinks, doth raise.
A mediocre score, doth this place receive,
For though the meal, didst start well, it didst leave us grieve."
"Folks said they laughed 'til they cried. Didn't see much of either from where I sat. Maybe it was the age gap. This show ain't for the young bloods."

"We checked this joint out after reading some reviews. I was let down 'cause I had high hopes. It's just your average coffee shop. I was with my husband and one of our twins. I was gonna get the breakfast burrito, but I wanted turkey sausage instead. The girl at the counter said they couldn't do it. So I went with turkey sausage, egg, and cheese on an English. I asked for a scrambled egg for my little girl, but the girl said they couldn't do that either. The eggs come pre-made in a patty, which sounded about as appetizing as my sneakers after a 3-mile run. I canceled the food and paid for the coffee and OJ I got for my baby. Too bad, I'm always lookin' for breakfast spots."

"Affecting airs of elegance, yet lacking substance to match the cost,
Their pomp and circumstance doth not befit the fee they boast.
I do confess, a better view could scarce be found,
Yet for the price, my expectations were not quite profound.

The service, too, did leave much to be desired,
With naught but empty words, their claims uninspired.
For though they strove to seem refined and grand,
In truth, their efforts fell flat, like sand.

So if thou seekest luxury, look elsewhere, my friend,
For here, 'tis naught but show, with little true intent.
But if the view alone doth please thee, then by all means,
Prepare thy purse, and suffer their pretenses."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir,  
That for a pedicure, fifty dollars, ne'er shall be spent,  
For though the service may be grand,  
The price doth seem quite exorbitant, doth it not?  
And had I known of this cost, ere I did enter,  
I would have sought elsewhere, to save my purse,  
For at The Bath House, such luxuries are found,  
And there, my coin, doth flow more freely,  
And lo, the question doth arise,  
Why mop the floor, so early in the day?  
When but just opened, doth the salon lay,  
And who, pray tell, doth wish to be,  
Amongst the cleansing of yesterdays disarray?"

"Thursday night, we rolled into Vegas, nine strong. Somehow, we got in free, promoter must've put us on the list. First time in Vegas, first club experience, and it was a bust. Dead vibe, man. Outdoor patio upstairs was the only spot jumpin', but even that was a slog through cougar town. One bar, swamped. Real letdown. Haven't been back."

"Service was decent, but the grub wasn't great. I had the Tuscana Sausage Soup, which was too salty and the potatoes were undercooked. The sausage was alright, though. I tried building my own pasta, thinking it'd be a better option than pizza, but I was wrong. I got spaghetti with bologonese sauce, meatballs, and mushrooms. It cost around $22-$24, but it wasn't worth it. The pasta and sauce were just lukewarm, and the meatballs tasted like they were straight from the freezer. All in all, I wasn't impressed with the pasta. Maybe I'll stick to a slice of pizza next time."

"Verily, I didst not enjoy this establishment.  Forsooth, I held a fondness for its antiquated visage and 'dive' allure, yet it proved to be naught but a dive, devoid of any true merit.  Its prices were not the most reasonable, and alas! the burgers didst leave much to be desired.  The layout didst pose a hindrance, making it difficult to access the soda fountain for refills.  Methinks this place doth thrive solely through the patronage of travelers, who, in their ignorance, do not discern its shortcomings.  I wouldst not return, anon."
"Rude waitress. Food mediocre, but not worth a single star. First and last visit. Better options nearby, cheaper too. Only plus: veggie options on menu."

"I tried twice to reach Sherry's Pampered Pets by phone, but no one picked up. I left a message, but they never called back. After waiting a few days, I gave up and made reservations elsewhere. If they couldn't be bothered to return my call, I sure wasn't going to leave my dog in their care."

"Stayed at a crummy joint for a night. Decided to go cheap, but it was all show and no go. Beautiful from the outside, but inside it was old and grimy. Service was terrible too. Asked for a non-smoking room, but it reeked of smoke. Called down to the manager's desk, but no one helped us. Finally got someone's attention, but she was rude and sent us to the other side of the lobby. Had to wait 10 minutes for someone to help us, and even then, they told us to go back to the other side. Long desk, especially with two full bottles in my bag. Overall, bad customer service. Maybe if we had arrived an hour earlier, it wouldn't have been so bad. But still, wouldn't stay there again unless I really had to."

"Chopstix, a name that rings of authenticity, but don't be fooled. The service is as fake as the smiles of the staff. I ventured in, hungry for some decent Chinese grub, but what I got was a taste of disappointment. The card reader was busted, so I had to trek to the nearest ATM, shelling out an extra three bucks for the pleasure. I returned, cash in hand, ready to devour my wor wonton soup, house fried rice, and orange chicken. But alas, the man behind the counter was too busy taking a personal call to bother with me. I waited, patiently at first, but as the minutes ticked by, my hunger turned to frustration. Finally, another man sauntered over, sans apology or acknowledgement of my wait, and took my payment. No discount, no freebies, nothing but a bland, unfulfilling experience. Save your taste buds, folks. Chopstix ain't worth the trip."
"Nah. Not worth it. Vegas has better buffets - Wicked Spoon, Bacchanal. This one's a dud. Dry food, sitting out too long, and it attracts the wrong crowd. You're in Vegas, splurge on the good stuff."

"Service was adequate. Menu options were overpriced. I ordered the street-style pork sandwich. Pork was blue rare. Sandwich was small, like a biscuit. Underwhelming experience. I also had a pork taco with green salsa. Pork was cooked well, but taco was soggy from pork grease. Friend had dim sum, no issue with size. Dim sum had an odd smell, but tasted fine. Place was sub-par. Wouldn't go again. Drinks come in small bottles, no free refills. Some bottles are smaller than others. Not worth the money. Wouldn't recommend."

"First time here. Service good. Waitress, friendly and helpful. Location, perfect. Westgate, fun spot. Pizza, not so much. Tasted like something from the freezer. Sauce, gross. Crust, thin and mushy. Shame, given the spot and competition."
"Staff unimpressive. Food, just okay. Overpriced. Trying too hard to be upscale, but falling short. Limited wine list, small portions, and snobby staff. Better options in Charlotte."

"Been meaning to hit this joint for a bit. Now that I have, I'm good. 

It's the kind of spot you hit after a night of drinking, when your standards ain't so high. It wasn't all that bad, but not great either.  

I gauge Latin eats by their chips and salsa. If it's not good, I know what to expect from the kitchen. With that said..
the chips were greasy, salsa tasted like Pace. 

Had the two taco plate - grilled chicken and steak tacos with re-fried beans and rice. Steak taco had good flavor, but the chicken was real dry. Added lime and salsa to try and juice it up. All in all...it was decent, but not any better quality than a late night taco stand."

"Stayed here last year on a family road trip. Enjoyed it. Room and bathroom were clean. Convenient location, close to I-77 and a great mall. Returned this year, but room wasn't as clean. Hair on the floor, noisy AC kept us up. Staff still friendly, but might look elsewhere next time."

"A fine eatery, by my troth, with atmosphere most pleasant,
But alas! the victuals they do serve, lack zest and vigor.
Chips, straight from store shelves, they bring to dip,
And macaroni, fit for bairns, doth taste of naught but grit.
Chicken, in yonder salad, doth seem o'ercooked and tasteless,
And upon mine pizza, a mound of raw arugula doth lie.
Salt, a precious resource, they do employ with grace,
Yet, I do pray, good sirs, to partake of this fare no more."

"Alas, the grub remains most delectable, a steal at four dollars, mark my words. But lo, the `douche factor` doth swell, a plague upon this humble eatery. A group of four, most corpulent and clad in business attire, didst exit, boasting of their thrifty find. Fear not, fair patrons, for I didst arrive post-haste, ere the Friday luncheon crush. 'Twas then that I didst espy the change, a crowd of soccer moms and penny-pinching gents, their hunger sated by naught but basest fare. Oh, woe betide the day that social media doth bring such rabble to our doorstep, making queues most odious and dining a chore."

"Alas, fair maiden, no reservation couldst be found,
After the hour of five, when day doth turn to night.
And, by the stars, no charging station for my phone,
A plight most vexing, and a cause for great despair.

But lo, the waitress, a gem beyond compare,
Didst serve with grace and speed, a wondrous sight to see.
Her skill and art didst make the evening bright,
A shining star, that doth outshine the night.

Yet, alack, a new bartender, green and slow,
Didst take his time, and caused my dreams to flow.
His lack of skill, a hindrance to my cheer,
A bitter draught, that doth leave a sour taste here.

So, farewell, dear tavern, I shall not return,
After the hour of five, my heart doth yearn.
For though the waitress was a treasure true,
The rest, alas, didst fail to meet my view."

"Pizza joint claims to have vegan menu, but after 10:30pm, not a single vegan option to be found. Every other pizza available, but not a single one for us plant-eaters. Feels like they're just pretending to care about our business. No offer to make a vegan pizza, even when asked. Shoddy customer service, if you ask me. Feeling mighty disappointed."

"I'll return for a must-see band, elsewise, no dice. 

Security's cool, helped my buddy propose, no issues there. 

Parking's a bitch, limited spots, pricey too. Get there early or you're screwed. 

Sound's mediocre, not the best, not the worst either. 

Drinks? Ripoff! Don't drink, come drunk, or sneak some in. (Not advocating for sneaking it in, but they do pat you down at the door.) 

In summary, this joint's a ripoff, but it's the only game in town for big acts. Screw it."

"Savory, clean eating, love it. Four visits to Layer, not impressed. First time, good grub, bad service. Second visit, out of flatbread, really? Friday night, busiest dinning night, no flatbread. BBQ beef sandwiches, great, burnt sweet potato fries, not so much. Third visit, same story. Fourth visit, breakfast, an hour past opening, door open, no breakfast menu, empty restaurant, staff ignores me for four minutes. Finally, 'good morning, we're open.' Too little, too late."

"Hark! My dear friend, listen well to my tale,
Of two establishments, both of which do prevail,
In serving victuals, fit for a king,
But alas! One doth stand out, in this humble soul's reckoning.

Einstein's, a place of wonder, doth provide,
The most delectable bagels, that doth astound,
Soft, fluffy, and fresh, they doth delight,
Leaving all others, in a sorry plight.

And yet, fair Bruegger's, doth not falter,
For their softwiches, doth please, and doth matter,
A worthy alternative, to the former's might,
But alas! Their bread and bagels, doth not excite.

So, my dear friend, heed my words of wisdom,
And choose Einstein's, for thy next visit,
For there, thou shalt find, the most divine,
Bagels, that doth rival, the heavens' design."

"O, how I yearn for Greek eats, served up with love,
By hairy, ugly Greeks, in a family-owned dive.
A law, there should be, to keep it this way,
For I fear the corporate type, will ruin the fray.

Daphne's, a place nearby, did catch my eye,
With meat, bread, and fries, my hunger did cry.
But alas, the gyro, a styro-gyro, they called,
Was cold and tasteless, like a forgotten brawl.
The pita, old and rotted, crumbled apart,
Like a Frisbee, left out in the sun's smart.
The fries, hot though they were, had a frozen taste,
Like a bag of secrets, locked away in haste.

But one thing, a drink, a diet Soba delight,
Grapefruit flavor, a tasty, refreshing sight.
Oopah, how I savored each sip, with glee,
A gem, in a place, that failed, to impress me."

"Alas, my friends, a tale of woe doth come from yonder tavern, Juniper. A place where drinks flow free, but service doth falter.

In sooth, I didst try to book a table, five days in advance, thrice didst I call, but nary a soul didst pick up the phone. And lo, the Germany vs Brazil match didst begin, and I didst give up, in despair.

Two days later, I didst call once more, and after much discussion of seating arrangements, a high table by the window was confirmed. But alack, upon arrival, the table was given to another, and they didst know naught of our booking. Fie upon it!

And thus, we waited, while four walk-in patrons didst receive their drinks ere we didst. No greeting didst we receive, nor acknowledgement of our presence. Forty minutes didst pass, ere our cocktails didst arrive, and near twenty-five minutes after that, didst we receive our snacks.

But lo, the server, a kindly man, didst arrive, and with him, our fortunes didst change. He didst serve us with haste, and his pleasant demeanor didst ease our ire.

Yet, alas, the damage was done, and though the drinks were good, the service didst leave much to be desired. Nay, I wouldst not recommend Juniper, save thou art willing to suffer poor service for a decent dram."

"A bar most curious, where fortune doth play a part,
In choice of bartender, a matter of the heart.
Some nights, a skilled hand doth pour the draught with grace,
Whilst others, a laggard doth mar the drink's embrace.
I shall not name the culprit, lest I cause offense,
But on certain eves, best to avoid the place, my friend."

"Good people, good vibes. BAM, pickling factory smell, but don't worry, fun bar. Bad experience though - undercooked noodles in ramen, made me feel sick. Small person, but can still eat. Spinach, refreshing. Carrots, lovely. Pork, cold, but good. Nori, standard. Broth, salty, but good. Tried Pai Ton, tonkotsu broth without pork. Friendly staff, made us non-alcoholic shots. Super nice, but food doesn't agree with me. If sensitive, try Cherry Blossom Noodle Cafe, more classic and authentic."

"High expectations, hyped up joint. Dig the vibe, but the pizza's a letdown. Overpriced, too. Thin crust, toppings slide off. Cheesy bread? Forget it. Little Caesar's is better. Friendly waitress, but she vanishes for ages. Might give it another shot, try something else. Calzone looks promising."

"Four stars we didst deduct, my dear,
For grub that left us both aghast.
Chili, full of cheese, didst taste,
Like marinara, spicy and vast.

Beef stroganoff, a dish most foul,
Didst leave a slick of oil, a pool.
Gastric woes didst plague me still,
The rest of eve, I didst not will.

Yet, hope doth spring, a burger fair,
Might tempt me back, who knows? Pray tell,
If thou hast tried their burgers, speak,
And let me know, if 'tis worth the seek."

"Aye, forsooth, my friend didst sing the praises of this place for six moons, and thus, I hadst to see it for mine own eyes. Alas, the turkey sandwich I didst partake of was naught but average, I do declare. And, alack, they didst not possess Sweetener for their unsweetened iced tea, a dire oversight indeed! Methinks I shall not return, forsooth."

"This joint used to be alright. But, last time I was here for lunch, it was a bust. Server was jabbering to his pals about how crappy the tip was from the table before me. And they were out of the two drinks I wanted. Not going back."

"Celebrated my birthday at this joint and the service was top-notch. But the grub? Not worth the scratch. Ribeye, pork, bone marrow, and a couple glasses of vino set me back $250 for two. Skip it. Head to Bobby Flay's for a better steak and a fairer price."

"Airport's clean, but it's a den of sin. Booze, gambling, and likely strippers too. Plenty of grub, always neat, and easy to navigate. Give it five stars, except for the damn taxi line. It's a mile long and moves at a snail's pace. Unacceptable, especially since the casinos can't seem to fix it. They should be ashamed. Get your act together, airport."

"Methinks two stars doth be a fair assessment, my friends. Forsooth, we didst first alight upon a humble Motel 6, and verily, this Windermere Inn didst prove an upgrade, though by but a single star. Alas, the bathhouse didst leave much to be desired, a state of affairs that, an it please thee, a thorough scrubbing might yet amend. The chambers, spacious and well-appointed, didst boast a balcony, a pleasant feature indeed. The pool and hot tub, too, didst offer solace, though a trifling matter, methought, a net and diligent hand might yet remove the debris that didst mar its surface. \n\nThe servitors, kind and helpful, didst attend to our needs with grace and aplomb. The morning repast, sufficient unto the day, didst round out our stay in fairness. O, Windemere, heed my words, and with but a small effort, thy rating shall rise, anon!"

"Ate at this joint years back, inside the Mirage. Good grub, we thought. Recently, though, it was piss poor. Server didn't know squat about the soup du jour. Nutty broad, too. Made us feel rushed. Food? Shit, it was cold. Sent it back. Prices? Outta whack for the crap they serve. Too many better spots in Vegas. Won't be comin' back."

"Hark, good sir! Their victuals be most fair, an' 'twere not for the woeful lack of attendance, our bellies wouldst be full and merry. Alas, on my last visit, nigh thirty minutes didst pass, and still, no servitor came to take our order. So, off we didst go, to seek sustenance elsewhere. Now, we doth but call ahead, and fetch our wings with haste, lest we suffer similar neglect once more."
"Steakhouse in Vegas. Disappointed. Party of ten at lunch. Menu looked good, but my steak was burnt to hell. Where's the porterhouse? Wine was decent, but pricey, even for this town."

"Ew. Flavorless canned mushrooms and frozen spinach in my omelet. No seasoning, just a big sloppy mess. Took forever to take our order, much less get it to us. Hash browns were okay, but that's about it. Don't understand the high reviews."

"A foul mood and rigid mindset can swiftly turn a pleasant encounter into a dismal one, alas! 'Tis a pity, for I had meant to pen a glowing review for 360 Physical Therapy, praising the skill of their practitioners and the care they took with me. But lo, a draconian policy regarding appointments doth mar their reputation. A fee, they claim, for missed appointments, and naught but strife doth come of it. I swear upon my honor, fair reader, that I did reschedule ere I failed to appear, yet the billing manager doth contest it still. A stubborn streak, indeed! Forsooth, is't not worth the while to keep thy clients content? I, a faithful patron, ever punctual and prompt in payment, doth urge thee, 360 Physical Therapy, to reconsider thine ways. Alas, a missed chance, for now I shan't return, nor recommend thee to mine acquaintances, save thou changest thine unyielding stance."
"Place was a dump, real sketchy. Rented some skates, moldy as hell. Only rink in Madison, so not like we had choices. Kids didn't seem to care, still had fun. We dealt with it."

"Went to Frank and Lupes. Grub was top-notch, but service was slow. Had to grab our drinks at the bar 'cause our waiter was MIA. At the end of the meal, my buddy stepped out to use the can, and the waiter finally decided to grace us with his presence. Asked me if I was waiting to be seated...after he'd been slackin' off for an hour and a half."

"Hark! What news is this? A building grand and fair,
The Marché Bonsecours, a sight to behold, they say.
But, alas! 'Tis naught but a place for the rich to play,
A shopping center, full of expensive trifles, I pray.

They say it's a place for artists to show their wares,
But all I see is similarity and prices that scarce bear.
So, go and visit, but do not expect to find
A place that will leave you in awe, save the exterior design."

"Been here twice. First time, liked the menu, had lunch. Food was good, standard bar fare. Service was decent, not too busy. Found out they got UFC fights, so went back for that. Fight night, they hit us with a $10 cover charge. What the hell? Everywhere else in EV, it's five bucks. Already there, so we stayed. Waitress asks for credit card or ID as security. Are you kidding me? We're a couple of forty-somethings. You think we're gonna dine-and-dash? Reluctantly gave her my card. Fights started, but not all the TVs were tuned in. Had to crane my neck. Even after the game ended, they didn't switch 'em. Food was okay, service was good. Go back for grub, but not for UFC. Stickin' with Old Chicago or Tilted Kilt for that."

"Burritos do the trick when I'm stuck at work, cravin' breakfast. Use 'em every couple weeks or so. Service, though? Horrible. Always get put on hold, never get picked up. Call back, finally get my order in. If there was another joint that delivered, I'd be gone."
"Crappy joint, this hotel. Room's a mess, dust everywhere. Missing stuff, like cups and laundry bags. Bed sheet's filthy, bloodstained too. Had to get housekeeping to swap 'em out."
"Beer selection limited. Tap labels, just words. Claims, empty. We sought more, found better up the street."

"Verily, I say unto thee, good sir, that the service at this establishment doth leave much to be desired. 'Tis a far cry from the swift and efficient care that I have received at other eateries of its ilk. Methinks I shall have to journey forth to the one located on Sahara, alack, for it doth lie some ten minutes hence. Yet, so great is my discontent with this place that I shall deem it worth the trouble."
"Thai food, mediocre. Lunch special, $7.99. Till 4 pm. Service, average. Won't be back."

"Went for lunch, my second time. Ordered a chicken ceaser salad burrito, my mistake. Thought it didn't come with tomatoes, but it did. Don't like 'em. Had 'em make another, tasted better, but not by much. Maybe they had too many tomatoes, tryin' to get rid of 'em. Shoulda gone to Costa Vida, but it's always packed. Damn my burrito cravings."

"My daughter and I went on a mission to get fresh bagels. We copped some from a spot in Montreal, but they didn't impress. They were thin and a bit too sweet for my taste. I'm a New York bagel man myself, and I've been known to go the distance for 'em. The sesame bagel was alright, but the rest were stale and day old. We tried a couple different spots, but in the end, we decided Montreal bagels just ain't our thing. I think other Americans who've had the real deal in NYC would agree. And let's be real, I can get better bagels in Boston."

"A new Olive Garden popped up near my place. My husband and I decided to give it another shot, despite our reservations. Big mistake. It was a total letdown. Why do we keep doing this to ourselves? Trust your instincts, right? 

The fried mussels were decent, but nothing special. The chicken alfredo pizza was way too salty. I could barely finish it. I tried dipping it in the chicken and gnocchi soup to tone down the saltiness. But nope, still too much. I should've sent it back, but I've worked in restaurants before. I know what happens to returns. Not worth it... My husband's spaghetti with meat sauce was unremarkable. The herbs and spices were MIA. 

The food only deserves one star, but the service was top-notch. So, I'll give it two stars."

"Food's good, atmosphere's swell. But the service? Forget about it. Cashiers look like they're sucking on a lemon. You'd think they'd crack a smile, but nope. They're as grumpy as a cat in a bathtub."

"Stone Crab and Joe's, good on the right day.  Sat at the bar, Sunday afternoon, great service, good meal.  First visit, recon for a date with the wife.  Went back Thursday night, crab was off, texture strange, tasted like piss.  Waiter, a clumsy oaf.  Should've flipped my plate, spit in his face, walked out without paying.  Caesars, hit or miss, buyer beware."

"In year of two thousand and one, I didst purchase my first pair of orthotics from yonder place. They didst treat me well, and made me feel most valued, as if they were foot specialists or podiatrists indeed. I didst pay a sum of one hundred and ten dollars for two pairs.

But lo, I didst visit the same location yesterday, and didst explain that I had lost my inserts. I didst purchase shoes instead, paying six hundred dollars for what I had bought long ago. And yet, the shoes didst cost one hundred and thirty dollars still. I didst ask for slip-resistant shoes, and didst feel as though I were at a roller rink, passing through the kitchen.

This morn, I didst return, and the male attendant with a feux hawk didst quote the manufacturer's words to me, when I didst try to return or exchange the shoes within two sentences of our converse.

And thus, I do submit a low but generous score to the only surviving location in Clark County, for their overpriced and prescribed inserts, not from one with a degree in sports medicine, and for the careless treatment I didst receive.

I must add, that the female who didst assist me yesterday, was polite, but didst say that their products would last five to eight months at best, which is piss poor for one hundred and thirty dollars indeed."

"This joint's owned by Treasure Island, not some corporate bigshot. No fancy perks here, just straight-up coffee. Employees are friendly, but don't expect them to chat all day. No tables or chairs, so grab your cup and go. It's the only Starbucks on the strip now, but don't get your hopes up for a spiritual awakening with your morning joe."

"Hunger pangs didst beset our bellies, thus we chanced upon this establishment, hoping to find sustenance. Alas, our expectations were not met, for the victuals were naught but mediocre, and the drinks, a sorry sight indeed. No RITAS, nor any other potion of worth, didst grace their menu. My heart, once filled with hope, didst sink, and I was left to ponder the fare, which didst not stir within me, any desire. The day we visited, didst lack the sweet melodies of music, and the atmosphere, didst leave much to be desired."
"Coffee, sweetened. Simple request, no? Yet, they managed to botch it. Rock sugar, unmelted. A travesty. Disappointment, pure and simple."

"A place with atmosphere quite neat,
For drinks and revelry most meet.
Their meals, though priced a bit too high,
Are mediocre, and that's no lie.

The Irish Pasty, mostly potatoes,
With some cabbage, cheese, and beef in tow,
Is eclipsed by Guad/Dobson's version,
In flavor and in worth, I do avow.

The rest, just common bar fare found,
In any other tavern, all around.
So, if thou seekest strong drinks and cheer,
This place may serve, but don't hold dear.

For more than just a pint or dram,
Thou mayst find disappointment's bitter gram."

"The dimly lit room impressed us. Bread basket came first, with Asiago roll, walnut and cranberry bread, and a French roll. We both ordered broiled walleyed pike, which was a bit dry, and shared a baked potato (overcooked) and creamed corn. Finished with a crème brûlée. The creamed corn, served in a large casserole dish and broiled, was the best part of the meal. The crème brûlée, unfortunately, was one of the worst we've ever had. Twenty years have passed since we last dined at this restaurant, but it's improved with age, lacking in ambiance but making up for it with friendly staff and reasonable prices. Ms. Westie's 8-ounce filet was good, but not quite prime, served medium rare as requested. My Chilean sea bass was cooked to perfection - crispy outside, moist inside, with garlic mashed potatoes, a small fennel salad, and sautéed spinach."

"Methinks I did desire to give them a fairer rating,
For their toppings were most wondrous and bright.
The service was good, the restaurant quaint,
With beer and wine flights, a delightful sight.
But alas, the pizza dough, it was not quite right,
Too doughy, lacking crispness and bite.
I sought a pie that would bring back memories,
Of those I savored in Italy's sun-kissed lands.
Great toppings, indeed, but work on the dough,
That it may rise to greater heights, my friends."

"A soiree, by my count, didst take place within these hallowed halls,
And, by the stars, 'twas a sight to behold, so fair and beauteous!
The staff, with smiles and grace, didst tend to our each whim,
But, alack, for those who doth eschew the flesh of beasts,
There was little to savor, save a few meager morsels.
The kitchen, too, didst disappoint, despite their store of fine ingredients,
For they didst not strive to fashion a salad most excellent."

"Tired from our tourist traipsing all day,
We returned to our humble inn, the LVH, to rest awhile.
By dinnertime, our weariness did prevail,
And thus, we chanced upon this place, with naught else to do.
A friendly greeting met us, and a table straightaway,
But from that moment on, believe the other reviews, I pray.
On a Sunday eve, the place was empty, save two tables more,
And Motley Crue's music videos did loudly roar.
Vince Neil, I understand, but this was quite too much,
Our server, kind and attentive, though the crowd was scant.
Food, unimpressive, I must say,
Chips and salsa, store-bought, I could not stay,
Fish tacos, fried or microwaved, a sorry sight,
Beef machaca, cold and mushy, a pitiful plight.
We were weary, food was needed, no one fell ill,
So I suppose 'twas not a total waste, but still...
Avoid this eatery, and the LVH, I do advise,
New ownership, it seems, doth bring demise."

"Honey Bears ain't my cup of tea, friend. Been there twice 'cause I'm a sucker for BBQ, but it just don't cut it. Sauce is more like broth, lackin' that smoky kick. Meat's alright, though - had some good pork and chicken. But them sides? Forget about it. Potato salad's as dull as a butter knife. Overall, stick to the meat, but there's better BBQ in Phoenix."

"Skip Scottsdale. Stay elsewhere, gamble here. Pool's mediocre. Restaurants are meh, except Orange Sky - felt like a carnival cruise with tatted-up dudes and stiletto-clad teens. Save your cash, gamble, and bunk elsewhere."

"Excited, I was. Saw the 'Coming Soon' sign, I did. Twice, I've been there. Not going back, I am. Food, not bad, it's true. But overall, unsatisfactory, my experience was. Overpriced, they are. Stingy, I tell ya. Hate 'em, I do. Pollo a la Brasa', I ordered. Fries, they did not give. False advertising, it is. Cheap, they are. Yuca fries, don't order. Six bucks, it costs. Five fries, you'll get. Strange looks, the waitress gave. Insane, I must be. Minimal tip, I would've given. Back, I won't go. Business, poorly run, it is."

"No beer specials here. First time for everything, I guess. Been to five Maggianos, and each one's been a letdown. Food's gone downhill. But I love Italian food too much to give up. Almost makes me wanna cook my own pasta, grab a good bottle of wine, and call it a night."

"Upon a Sunday, fair and bright,
I chanced upon this place, my first sight.
The hour of three did strike, and I did say,
"A to-go order, prithee, pray tell what's the way?"

A gallant lass did answer my query,
"The salad, sir, is vast and plenty."
I asked of mixed greens, and she didst reply,
"In truth, the salad doth not contain them nigh."

I didst ponder then, a wiser course,
To buy a salad bar, and save some force.
For lesser coin, a larger portion thou shalt see,
A better bargain, verily, for thee.

But lo! A question didst arise,
Concerning dressing, and its prize.
I asked, and she didst make reply,
"No choice of dressing didst thou specify."

Now, by my troth, I was not asked,
Nor offered free ice cream, as some task.
Yet, still, a patron, fortunate soul,
Didst receive this boon, and didst control.

And thus, I didst inquire,
Of crackers, too, and their allure.
But nay, they didst not come, I didst find,
With this order, alas, so I didst design.

The salad, fair, was good, I must confess,
But not as described, alack, the mess.
So, heed my words, and take heed,
For here, my friends, a moral doth proceed."

"Hark! Our carriage, left with Fletcher's for repair,
Didst sputter and jolt, a sorry plight.
Three calls we made, yet nary a word didst come,
Till Monday eve, when they didst claim all was right.

But lo! The very next day, the engine light didst gleam,
And we, in haste, didst drop it off once more, in the night.
Now Tuesday afternoon, and still no word,
A poor showing, indeed, of their communicative might.

Two days, they had it, and couldst not find the cause,
A sorry state, and one that doth our patience pause.
If they do find the fault, 'twill take yet another day,
To fix the problem, and send it on its way.

Oh, woe betide the poor soul who doth entrust
Their carriage to Fletcher's, with naught but dust.
For though they mayst profess to be skilled and true,
Their lack of words doth show a lack of clue."

"Been goin' to Lee Lee's for years, but it's gone downhill lately. Ethnic sections still got some variety, but Japanese foods ain't gettin' restocked regular. Never been their strong suit, but they had the basics. Me, bein' Japanese, relied on that section. Now it's just a bunch of Kirkland seaweed takin' up space. Sure, I get seaweed from CostCo sometimes, but when I'm cookin' up some good rice, I want the real deal - thicker, more flavorful Japanese brands. Their rice selection's all but disappeared too. Guess I'll have to find a new spot."

"Hark, fair sir! The victuals here be of high quality, 'tis true,
But lo, there be two issues that doth vex me sore.
A milkshake, I do order, yet 'tis not mixed aright,
Chunks of ice cream, huge and frozen, that doth bite.
And service, alack! Doth falter, doth fail,
A waiter, I must hail, and beg, and prevail.
Yet still, the food, so tasty, doth make me stay,
Despite the flaws, I come, and pay, and play.
But nay, not for me, the service, poor,
Doth mar the joy, and doth me bore."
"Food's good. Service too, when they ain't slammed. But I'm really in it for the apps and cold ones during happy hour."
"Thursday, May 1st, 2014. Two girls working. One reluctant, one seated. Reluctant one helped, begrudgingly. Followed us, hurrying our order. Bad service, great ice cream."
"Disappointment hit hard when I found out they didn't stock yard art or Talavera pottery. Always on the lookout for unique touches."

"Went to The Vig, been there before, good grub, nice patio, decent service. Went back, different story. Me and the boys stood at the host stand, nobody greeted us, servers just chillin' at the door. We grabbed a table, reserved signs everywhere, expected someone to seat us. Server comes up, asks if we walked in, if we need menus. Sure, we say. She says the table's reserved, but any other table's fine, she'll be right back. Found another table, guy from the big party tells us that one's reserved too. Feel like staff wasn't paying attention to anyone else. Left feeling frustrated and impatient. Hope it's a one-time thing, The Vig's usually better than that, don't wanna miss their good food."

"Parking should be free. It'd liven up this joint, make it more worthwhile. When it first opened, folks from all over came to check it out, shop, eat. Now? It's just a bunch of chain stores and mediocre restaurants. But hey, happy hour specials are still good. That's one thing they got right."

"Methinks this playhouse doth possess some charm,
With seats that beckon comfort, a stage not quite so large,
And drinks, alack, of price most reasonable,
A four-star rating, methought, it did deserve,

But lo, a grievance doth my heart now bear,
For on the night of improv, I chanced to hear
The loud bass thumping from Tabu next door,
A constant din that did my senses sore,

My show, which cost me dear, did start at eleven,
The noise, a cruel fate, did ne'er cease,
My husband's seat did shake, the vibrations strong,
A woeful distraction from a show most fine,

I do protest, in conscience clear,
How canst thou sell dear tickets, and thy guests
Expect them to endure such noise, oh so near?
I shall make formal complaint, 'tis my intent."

"Dim Sum's no good. This joint's better, but that ain't sayin' much. Frozen dishes, not fresh. Bland dim sum, not much variety. Can't expect Charlotte to have the same quality as big cities, but I do expect the classics like chicken feet and shrimp rice noodles to be decent. They're not. If you're lookin' for good dim sum, drive to Atlanta."

"Hark! If thou dost order a combo at this place,
One item shall be strange, and cause thee disgrace.
The buffalo chicken salad, that I didst choose,
Came with fowl, chewy chicken, that didst not please.
My friend's apple gorgonzola, a sight to behold,
Was filled with too much iceberg, and thus grew cold.
But fear not, for Za's doth have a treat,
A selection of cheesecakes, to soothe thy feet.
So, on a bad day, when thou art feeling down,
Indulge in their sweets, and let thy cares drown."
"Excalibur for cheap digs. Tropicana? Skip it. Went there a couple years back. Adequate. Last week? Super gross."

"Burgers were decent, not the best I've had, but worth the dough. Server was friendly, checked in often. Atmosphere was meh, too twangy for my taste. Lots of pool tables, some bigger games, plenty of TVs. But nobody cleans the tables, had to wipe down my own mess."

"Fair sir, I must confess, the victuals didst not dazzle mine eyes. The establishment, quaint and charming, yet the cost of the repast, most certainly didst exceed its worth. I shall not return, save another's coin doth pay the tab."

"Inside JCPENNEY's hallowed halls, a Sephora doth reside,
Near mall entrance, on lower level, doth abide.
A blessing, indeed, for those who seek to find
Their beauty needs, without the need to wander blind.

But alas, dear friends, the inventory doth lack,
In this small space, only basics doth it keep,
And popular items, in limited quantity doth stack.
Still, 'tis a boon, this Sephora, in this place doth sleep.

But, oh, the customer service, how it doth falter!
Five sales reps, at cash wrap, doth cluster,
Two busy, three, in personal affairs doth flutter.
Invisible, I did feel, as through the throng,
I squeezed, to check the fragrances, they doth throng.
No acknowledgement, from them, did I receive,
A potential sale, of $100, did they not perceive.
Tocca, the fragrance, I did seek, in vain,
For three long minutes, did I search, in pain.
JCP's employees, affiliated, or not,
Management, take heed, the tapes, doth show,
How helpful, thy staff, doth not, alack."

"Methought we'd try a mobile groomer for our pup,
A Bolognese of eight summers, blind, alack!
Twas stressful taking her to groomers, loud and rough,
And ours of six years didst flake, most uncouth.

I called Green Dog, a company of great renown,
Their reviews didst prompt me, left a message down.
I gave my number, asked when they could come,
But nary a word, a full day hath passed, 'twas done.

I tried again, voice mail, a hang-up, alas!
Twenty-four hours, a lengthy wait, methinks, for a new guest.
I shall seek elsewhere, though their praise didst gleam,
For promptness, it doth seem, doth not their business beam."

"Birthday dinner for Mom at some joint, forget the name. Place was dead, just us and the staff. Started with calamari, too much breading, couldn't taste the squid. Risotto Milanese, that was good. Service went downhill from there. Told 'em it was a birthday dinner, expected something small, got tiramisu instead. Order all your desserts, don't count on freebies. Didn't even get my doggie bag, guy said he'd take care of it, then disappeared. Won't be back. Two stars, decent food, crummy service."

"Food's mediocre, overpriced. Service is off too, runners and waitstaff forgetful. Call it an American brasserie, but it's fake French at best. Not worth the cost. Ambiance and drinks are good though. Expected more from a hotel restaurant, especially one near theaters. Disappointing."
"Downtown's your best bet. I stick with buffalo shrimp, but the coating here's too thick. Ice tea's got a dirt taste and service is crap."

"Ale and victuals, both didst please mine eyes,
But, alas! the burgers, they didst not rise
To expectation's height, in taste so bland,
And portioned out, like a giant's hand.
Service, good, didst make amends, in part,
For grub unsatisfying, a heavy heart.
Methinks, I'll return, for drink and bites,
But not for burgers, that doth lack delight."

"Alas, my friends, I must report,
The food at this place did not comport,
With the high praise that Yelp did bring,
A disappointment, indeed, it did sting.

Chicken satay, dry and overcooked,
Basil fried rice, mushy and oversauced,
Shrimp and chicken, scarce and small,
A heavy hand, their flavors did dull.

But wait, there was a dish, a gem,
A stir fry, with black bean and ginger,
The best of all, a taste most fine,
A saving grace, for this poor repast.

Yet, alas, the price did cause dismay,
One app and two entrees, thirty dollars they did say,
A steep sum, for a meal not quite grand,
A pity, for a restaurant, once so bland."

"Group decided on all-day buffet, cheap and easy. Shoulda saved our stomachs and cash, gotten decent grub instead. Food ain't terrible, just can't handle three meals of stale stuff. Breakfast was whatever, standard fare but fried rice and weird breakfast items. Lunch, same crap as breakfast. Fried chicken, big whoop. Dinner, a bit better, but still, stale food all damn day. Boo."

"Walking through the Mirage, my wife and I stumbled upon this restaurant. It looked great, so we gave it a shot. Big sushi fans, we were let down. Pricey and unoriginal. Calamari was alright, but not worth it. Three rolls, all disappointing. Closed out the bill, still hungry. Don't waste your time if you're looking for real sushi. San Diego spoils us, maybe. Won't be back."

"Food was alright. Decor was swell, but the tunes killed the vibe. They should stick to instrumental chill music, ya know? Ciabatta chicken sandwich was just okay. Bread didn't have that classic ciabatta taste. Sweet potato fries were a bit soggy. Hummus was decent, but the pita had a raw taste."

"This joint's got everything - bowling, pool, grub, and games. But let me tell you, it ain't exactly kid-friendly. It's wide open, no barriers to keep the little ones from wandering off. Safety's a concern, especially if you got multiple rugrats. Parents gotta keep a close eye, but that's tough when there's too many kiddos to watch. 

Another thing, they don't got much in the way of classic arcade games. Most of 'em are violent or ticket-based, neither of which is good for youngins. 

And let's not forget, the games that dole out tickets? That's just a slippery slope into gambling. Paying to play games of chance for a prize? No thanks. I steer the kiddos towards games that'll be fun regardless of the tickets. 

So yeah, kids might like the place, but I ain't a fan."

"Hark, good sir! My review doth focus solely on the service provided, forsooth. The cashier, alack, didst possess not an iota of charm or verve, his visage dour and uninviting. His voice, too, didst lack luster, a dreary tone that didst bespeak his disinterest in his work. In stark contrast, the manager, a merry soul, didst present my repast with a grin and a jest, a bright spot on an otherwise lackluster morn. Pray, let this employee take heed and learn from his superior, that he may spread joy and positivity, ere the day doth fully bloom."
"Enchiladas, ruined. Soggy tortillas drowned in a pool of horror. No taste, just mole overload. Disappointed."

"Mia Bella Cafe, empty at 11:15 am. Zero people. Signs advertising shawarma, my weakness. Went for a wrap, side of potato salad, and a turkey panini to go. Not impressed. Shawarma burrito, confusing, just okay. Potato salad, diced potatoes, no mayo. Dry. Panini, turkey, cheese, lettuce, tomato, good bread, but soggy from Israeli salad leakage. Open-faced panini, not worth it. Meh, wouldn't return."

"Upon the eve of Valentine's Day, my wife and I didst venture forth to dine at this establishment, with high hopes and great expectations. Alas, our experience didst not live up to the hype, for we didst wait for nigh on two hours ere we were seated, and by then, my patience hadst worn thin, my stomach didst grumble with hunger, and my mood didst sour. The victuals, though overpriced, didst prove to be but mediocre fare, and the tables, cramped and close together, didst afford us little privacy or comfort. A pillar, too, didst block my view, leaving me disgruntled and dismayed. Methinks, fair reader, that I shall not return to this place, forsooth."

"Hark! A place of sustenance, though not of feast,
For those who find themselves in dire need,
At four o'clock in morn, with naught but cash,
And no concern for separate checks, I reckon.

A diner, 'tis, yet not of finest fare,
But passable, perchance, for those who dare,
With friendly waitresses, clad in scrubs,
Like nurses tending to their patients' rubs.

The grub, akin to what a mother might prepare,
Who cares not for the culinary arts,
Yet still, a meal, and nourishment to spare,
For those who seek refuge from the cold, hard starts."

Saturday night, 9 PM, we walked into the joint. Busy, but the service was decent. Big menu, mostly bar food. My girl got a taco salad, greasy shell and all. I went for the club sandwich, fries, and a cup of chili. Fries were crispy, homemade. Club wasn't toasted, no spread. Chili was good. Prices were a bit steep, but it's Cave Creek, you know?
"Decent grub, but no sports package? Forget it. I'll find better places to grab a burger and catch a game."

"Alack, what woeful fate didst befall me at Pure!
For all our waiting, naught but woe didst ensue.
Six fair maidens and three swains didst make our group,
Yet still they grudged, with ratios most obtuse.
Inside, the floor was sticky, staff slow and sour,
And for each fair, five swains didst swarm and cower.
The roof lounge was a solace, and a gain,
For there a high roller didst make it rain.
Five tens in cash, a fortune, didst he bestow,
Yet still, I'd ne'er pay entrance, such woe doth show."

"Methinks 'tis a wondrous sight to behold,
Friendly waiters and waitresses, so bold.
Their laughter doth ring out, a joyous sound,
As they serve me with a smile, unbound.

Aye, free popcorn and icy tea, a treat,
Decent fare, though not a feast, doth meet.
But alas, the TVs, a sorry sight,
Do not reach all, a disappointment, quite right.

And worse, a tale of cole slaw, so vile,
Recycled, a practice most foul and vile.
I know not if the staff member doth remain,
But that dish, I shall never touch again."

"In town, Lakers too. BF, friend, and me tried for tix from a scalper. Didn't know the joint, got ripped off. Ended up with tickets to some dump called Verve Lounge. It's like a dive bar between the cheap seats and the good stuff. Nowhere to sit, crappy view. Not worth it. I'd rather sit in the rafters or be at Staples altogether."

"Firefly, a place of trend and fray,
Loud, crowded, and not for the gourmand way.
Their menu, dull and uninspired,
No bold flavors, just a tired parade.

The fries, a mediocre delight,
Manchego mac, a middling sight.
Grouper, dry and plain to taste,
Salad, passable, yet nothing to embaste.

Empanadas, small and lacking zest,
Albondigas, meatballs devoid of quest.
Paella, the best of their fare,
Yet, still, a dish beyond compare.

If tapas be thy quest, my friend,
Firefly, a place to thus it end."

"Maine Lobster Pot Pie and Shrimp and Scallops, we didst order,
Crab cakes, an appetizer, a curious start,
Presentation, neat and cool, a pleasant sight,
But alas, the taste, a bitter disappointment, a woeful plight.
The flavors, strange and unpleasant, a capital D,
The service, struggling to be genuine, a poor show indeed.
We've dined at Michael Mina's, a similar tale,
Not up to par, compared to other celebrated chefs, a sorry tale.
A cost of thirty dollars less, than Gordon Ramsay's fee,
No comparison, in quality, a disappointment, a decree."

Sitting in Plato’s Closet, waiting for them to go through my clothes. Five associates, three customers, and not a single greeting. Had to stand at the counter for five minutes before someone finally approached me, and even then, it was with a scowl. Great selection, but the vibe is off-putting. Sign says “like us on Facebook,” but I won’t be doing that. After today, I’ll take my business elsewhere. Buffalo Exchange is more my speed. Spreading the word about this place.

"A meal on Sunday night didst thou seek,
A venture most unwise, I do perceive.
The victuals, verily, were not of high quality,
Even for a chain Italian place, most unseemly.
The service, however, was quite good, I must confess,
For we didst sit at the bar, to watch the game with ease.

But still, I ponder, what didst cause this woe?
Was it the poor menu, or perhaps something else,
That doth escape my comprehension, I know not,
But truly, the fare was most disappointing, I do protest."

"Sura's Korean BBQ, a joint I've been meaning to try. Buffet style, pick your meats, bring 'em back to the table, grill 'em up. Server'll get you drinks, clean your grill now and again. Food's not half bad, but not great either. Middle of the tray, you might find some frozen meat. 

Went to the can while I was there, saw an employee leave the stall without washing her hands. Next thing I know, she's behind the buffet line, serving up meat. True story. 

Made me sick to my stomach. Wanted to go back to the stall, puke my guts out. AYCE menu's around the same price as the other places in town? No thanks, not after what I saw in the restroom."

"Fringe, Int'l Fest, Film Fest, I get it. Book Fest, stretching it. Politics Fest? Come on, that's just ridiculous. Not that politics ain't important, it's just not fest material. Can't picture a bunch of hippies getting high and debating tax reform. Next, the Accountancy Fest."

"Hark! What shabby spa doth think itself so grand?
Awaiting twenty minutes, ne'er a soul didst take my hand.
Bidden to move, my nail technician didst speak but twain,
In tongues unknown, to others she didst freely converse.
Above the polish, a sign doth threaten doom,
For breaking one of their most ancient bottles, 'twill be thy tomb.
Decrepit lotions in a corner, a spray tan booth for sale,
Yet, strangely, many didst flock to this poor excuse of a spa.
My nails, they turned out well, a mere $15 for a fill,
But ne'er again shall I return, forsooth, to this wretched mill."

"Hark, what luck! A vape shop lay before mine eyes,
And in I went, with naught but curiosity to guide me.
The place was empty, save for one who snored,
A slumbering soul, laid flat upon a couch, oh so bored.

I took a peek, and saw their wares displayed,
Drip tips and batteries, a sight most arrayed.
And liquids too, of brands I had not known,
A treasure trove, for one who's oft alone.

But alas, no one was there to answer my queries,
So I took some cards, and made note of their merchandise,
And left, with plans to return anon,
When perhaps, someone might be more awake, and not so gone.

A small shop, yet full of flavors, a delight,
But testers, none, to sample, a slight.
Still, two caught my eye, and thus, I say,
This place, not bad, but not the best, nay, 2/5 stars, alackaday!"

"Went to the coffee shop yesterday, around six. Place was dead, just me and the cashier. She wasn't exactly friendly, just said "hold on" when I tried to order. Finally got my tea, but she left the tea bag in the cup on the counter while she made some other drinks. Not exactly sure why she couldn't just put the hot water in my cup. Maybe it's just me, but I think she could've done better. Will probably come back though, it's one of the only coffee shops near my house."

"I showed up for my appointment with Doc Meghan, but she didn't bother to show. Said she was sick. Everyone gets sick, but that ain't the point. Front desk girl Judy had a sour face, like she was doing me a favor by breathing. Unprofessional, through and through. Heard her talking trash to the techs, saying I was a pain in the ass and gave her attitude. Bullshit. Patients shouldn't be treated like this. I got to my appointment on time, waited an hour to be seen. Doc Michaels and his assistant, though, they were top-notch. Judy needs a refresher course on how to treat people with respect. The other girls there, too. They need to keep their yaps shut, 'cause we can all hear 'em."
"Sunday brunch. Western Omelet. Just okay. Others had the buffet. Seemed to like it. Quantity over quality joint. Hashbrown casserole. Tasty."

"Thou hast beheld mine visage thrice, fair sir. A plethora of mine associates doth hold this place in high esteem, 'tis a well-frequented noontide refuge. They doth serve victuals of the south, of Louisiana's style, rich and hearty fare. Alas, to mine own taste, 'twas naught but overly salted and heavy, save for the gyro, which didst please mine palate. Verily, those who do adore their soul food shall find solace within these walls, but alas, 'twas not to mine liking. The space doth fill quickly at noon, and the confines be somewhat cramped."

"Methought I did request the dish of shrimp most spicy,
But lo, it failed to stir my taste's delight.
In truth, 'twas neither fiery nor full of zest,
Yet still, a pleasant evening did ensue, despite."
"Passable, at best. Real Cajun, it ain't. But, if you're lookin' for somethin' decent, this place'll do. The Rat Toes appetizer, now that's somethin' good."

"Love this Fry's, been coming here since it reopened last year. Spend a pretty penny too. But last time, it was a bust. Got home, missing a few things. Third time this has happened. No apologies from the staff, not even from the assistant manager. Had a better experience at Safeway, bought some shrimp, it was spoiled, brought it back, they gave me double the amount and refunded my cash. That's how you do customer service. Fry's may have good deals, but you can't put a price on good service."
"Surcharge from 9pm to 5am, 25 cents on every damn thing. Open 24 hours, what a joke. They ain't payin' their employees more at night, that's for sure. Bread still tastes great, hot and fresh."

"Food, top-notch. Service, subpar. New Year's Eve, waited twenty minutes for drinks. Server, alright, but slow as hell bringing grub. Asked him, he says, 'Kitchen's backed up, pal.' Not what I expected from a joint like this. Might go back, but why bother when there's better steakhouses in Vegas?"

"O Agave, how my heart doth yearn for thee,
In vain, alas! For thy service, poor and slow,
Didst leave me in dismay, with naught to show
But empty hands and utensils, nowhere to be found.

The quesadillas, crispy though they were,
With chicken and corn, didst fail to allure,
For their fillings, bland and lacking in zest,
Didst leave me unsatisfied, and somewhat irked.

And then, the fresh fish tacos, oh how they fell,
Soggy and messy, with a flavor old and foul,
The fish, with an ocean taste, too strong to bear,
Didst make me shudder, and my appetite impair.

But, lo! The ambience, surprisingly fair,
A pleasant blend of colors, lighting, and a grand bar,
Didst make me think, 'tis a shame, such potential rare,
Wasted on food, that doth not meet my expectations square."

"Charlotte's got some lousy bartenders. Slow, rude, and can't even get a simple order right. I asked for three Two Hearted Ales, but what did I get? Three shots of Fireball. And let me tell you, that's not what I had in mind. I tried to correct the mistake, but the bartender just ignored me. Finally, a bar back came over and told her I was still waiting for my beer. But even then, it took forever to get my drinks. What a waste of time and money. I'll stick to the bottle from now on."
"No sign of employees for 10 minutes, then bumped into one. He was helpful."

"Chaos reigned at Edinburgh's Waverley Station, the city's busiest and most important transportation hub. I arrived via taxi, ready to board a train to London. The moment I descended into the underground platform, I was struck by the disarray. Perhaps it was the construction that contributed to the confusion, but the lack of organization was palpable. \n\nDespite the mayhem, the station offered all the standard amenities: a nearby pub, snack shops, and the like. But the open-roof design left me uneasy, especially given the frequent rain and chill in the Scottish climate. Additionally, the fact that the trains to London were segregated from the others raised my hackles, as did the early morning departures and alcohol-fueled revelry."

"Four stars for thee, young bear-stuffing lad,
Whose Converse shoes didst make mine eyes glad.
Thou didst try thy best to keep mine attention,
But alas, my daughter, wild and untamed,
Didst steal the show, with her ADHD ways,
And made it hard for thee to keep thy claim.

At checkout, a star doth deducted lie,
For thou, a lazy fool, didst make a scene,
Yelling loud, like one possessed of thee,
And caused my daughter's wonder and glee.
Thy actions, rude and unbecoming, were,
And made mine husband turn, to see the fray.

Twice, I told thee, quiet, and still,
To put the purse away, and avoid the thrill.
But thou, a stubborn mule, didst not heed,
And caused a scene, most unnecessary and rude.
A mother's tricks, to hide a thing from sight,
Thou shouldst not, with thy yells, ignite.
All thou hadst to do, was put it back,
When we were gone, and save the attack."
"Methinks I do enjoy the rearward space of yonder tavern, forsooth, the melodies do please mine ear. Alas, my sojourn there was brief, yet shall I endeavour to return anon."

"Lived in Vegas my whole life. Been through McCarran a million times. Security lines hellish during peak hours, Friday and Sunday afternoons. Food options decent, few high-end shops. Pray for A or B gates, empty as the Sahara. Big airport, lots of walking. Slot machines and tacky Vegas kitsch everywhere. TSA agents laid back, taxi lines lengthy. Hire a limo, worth the cost. Free Wi-Fi, blessing."

"Brunch here was top-notch, but a recent visit with a crew left me underwhelmed. We took up space at the bar, three tall tables in the middle, and the service was painfully slow. Orders took forever, drinks didn't match their descriptions, and the menu's small plates weren't shareable. Tilapia for $22? No thanks. Brunch, yes. Dinner, no."

"This joint's got me down, for two reasons. First, it used to be great, then it took a turn for the worse. Second, they won't let you take your grub to go. What kind of restaurant does that? I went with a buddy, ordered an appetizer and a main course each. The veal was decent, but I couldn't finish it. When we asked for the leftovers to go, the missus gave us a sour face and said no way. That's when I knew I wouldn't be coming back. Don't like feeling ripped off, and not getting my money's worth makes me feel plain rotten."

"Franks A Lot, a humble joint on the east side of the road, caught my eye after driving past it countless times. Tucked away behind the airport, it's easy to miss. But one day, I decided to give it a shot. And let me tell you, it's a gem. Great hot dogs, good price, and friendly folks running the show. It's a family affair, and they do it right. Cash only, but don't worry, your lunch won't break the bank. Their Chicago dog is the real deal, loaded with onions, celery salt, sports peppers, and tomatoes. Get some fresh fries on the side, and you're set. They also serve Polish sausage, cheese fries, and philly cheese steak, but I stick to my Chicago dog. If you're in the area, give it a go."

"Sunday afternoon, grandma's mind burst with ideas. Paints, glues, brushes, frames - a creative explosion. Beads, bedazzlers, candles, styrofoam, construction paper, wood shelves to stain or color. Fake flowers, glass containers. Scrapbookers, rejoice! Michael's is your dream come true."

"A pox upon that barkeep, wretched hag,
Whose visage doth resemble a malignant crab.
Yet, by the stars, her potions did delight,
So rich and full of flavor, they did ignite.
I'd return, despite her gruff demeanor,
For those elixirs, worthy of a king's plea.
But, alas, her hospitality, so poor,
Doth leave much to be desired, I do declare."

"First Fridays at Brass turn into a wild scene. I'll be back, that's for sure. Location is everything, and in this case, it's Fremont - above Hennesy's Tavern, to be exact. The joint's got a sweet balcony for all you smokers out there, and it's a great spot to people-watch on Fremont. When you're ready to move on, Beauty Bar, Vanguard, and Insert Coins are just a stone's throw away. \

Music-wise, KidFunk killed it on the decks. He played a solid stream of good tracks, mostly house and tech house, with some electro and dubstep thrown in. The dance floor's decent-sized, and there's another room with a different DJ spinning tunes. Word is, they keep it up, and I'll be making this a regular First Friday stop. \

Now, about those bathrooms - yikes. Filthy doesn't begin to describe 'em. Drinks and who-knows-what all over the floor, and don't even get me started on the toilet paper situation. Grab some paper towels before you do your business, just saying. \

And the gogo dancers? Sorry, guys, but they were a letdown - both in looks and moves. \

No dress code or cover when I went, fellas. Don't forget to rate and follow, eh?"

"I tried this joint despite the reviews. Decor was cool, but the bathroom was weird. Hand dryer's on one faucet, so you gotta wait your turn. Ladies, no sanitary depositories in the stalls. You gotta walk to the main trash to toss your stuff. 

Had the veggie burger. Tasty, but small, like a slider. Fries were good, but normal portion size. Water cups, tiny. Not full after the meal. Ate a medium popcorn at the movies, no problem. 

Don't think this place'll make it. Too pricey for the size. Need bigger portions or lower prices. No option to double up the veggie patty."

"Pub's alright for a beer and grub if you're stuck near the convention center. Been there twice, grad student in town for a conference. Jalapeño poppers and onion rings, good stuff. Buffalo wings, meh. Gets packed during games, but that's part of the fun. So, if you're stranded and hankerin' for a cold one and some snacks, give it a shot."

"Sakana fan for years, until my son came along. Sushi nights weren't easy with a little one. After three years, my husband and I decided to give Sakana another try. Date night, just the two of us. Hoped it'd be like old times. It wasn't. Sat at the sushi bar, but the chefs didn't have the same spark. Less chatty, fewer recommendations. Scallop dynamite still top-notch, though. And those oranges for dessert? Missed 'em. Maybe my expectations were too high after three years."

"Hark! 'Tis a place I oft visit, twixt home and river's flow, To grab a sub, and thus I shall bestow My favor upon this humble abode, For Subway and Blimpie's, I do not hold.

A market vast and full of wonders doth lie Within these walls, where olive oil doth flow free, And pasta, a whole aisle doth take its pride, And wooden tools for gnocchi, they doth provide.

The counter, long and full of treats doth run Along the back, where cheeses, meats, and sweets are shown, And sandwiches, ordered with great haste and speed, Doth please the palate, though the man doth seem to need A bit of cheer, for he doth wear a frown, And woos the customer with his gruff tone.

But fear not, for the lady at the till Doth make amends with her sweet, gentle will, And thus, I shall continue to support this place, Though sandwiches, just average, doth leave me in disgrace. But still, the products here, they doth excel, And thus, my rating, so-so, doth tell."

"This place doth please me moderately well, fair sir. The eatery boasts a pleasant atmosphere, good service, and merry diversions. The victuals, though not of the highest quality, do satisfy my hunger. Alas, the steaks, a mite too aged for mine own liking, yet the potatoes, au gratin, didst delight mine taste. A worthy cellar of wines, they do possess, with choices for all purses. 'Tis a suitable option, should thou find thyself at GVR, seeking a hearty meal. Yet, I do confess, most steakhouses upon the Strip, do surpass this place, in my humble opinion."

"OPI on the cheap, read Carina's review. Didn't wanna shell out eight fifty at Ulta. Geez, what a steal. Colors already separated, heat or age, who knows. Choose price over quality, that's my motto. Four bucks, I'm a cool cat. Same plaza as Lee Lee's, next to China Magic Noodle."

Hark! Went in for an early dinner, and thus did order
The Pot Roast Sandwich, with much anticipation.
The veggies came, and lo! They were not cooked,
Raw, they were, and I did eat the meat, with great relish.
I told the waitress, and she did say,
"Tis normal, indeed," and offered me another side dish.
I was glad, yet somewhat subdued,
For this, it seemed, was their usual way.
My husband, he did enjoy his chili burger much,
And our drinks, they were quite strong, with no small touch.
This place, it doth bustle with activity,
Yet, mayhap, we did choose the wrong victuality.

"Carne assada torta, not bad. Price, real good. But, jeez, comically unorganized. No process. Got my food, but should've been sooner. Grill, dirty. Meat, fatty, chewy. Dining area, not clean. Not a 3, not a 2. Gave 'em the benefit."

"Perched upon a stool, I sipped my brew,
Asked twice, and still no melody did break,
The silence, like a shroud, did cloak the room,
Until a distant beat, a reggae tune did creep,
Soft whispers, barely heard, did reach mine ear,
As bartender, with a smile, did turn it clear.
No victuals on the board, to claim my share,
But Cuba Libra's, three, my thirst did slake,
I savored each, and pondered on the fare,
If worth a visit, back again, I shall partake."
"Far from the French Quarter, my gut don't often crave Cajun. Few choices in this one-horse town. This place becomes the go-to for a gumbo fix. Above-average grub, good service, prices a bit steep."

"Two weeks past, I chanced upon this spread,
Whose decor did my eyes most pleasantly greet.
And though the victuals were of quality fine,
The choices offered left much to be desired, I do confess.
In individual portions, they were served with care,
But variety, alas, was scarce and far between.
A three-star affair, I would pronounce it, fair and square.
I shunned the weekend feast, of price quite steep,
And opted for the brunch, a Monday treat.
$22, a sum not small, yet worth the cost, I thought,
For an all-you-can-eat place, in Sin City brought.
My hunger sated, I did feel, ere long,
Yet boredom crept in, and my stay did not prolong."

"Hark, what news is this? In Las Vegas, there be many lesbians, fair sir! They doth wear their hair in mullets, and their attire doth resemble jean vests with ripped sleeves. By my troth, 'tis a sight to behold! \n\nBut soft, what light through yonder window breaks? A sushi bar, perchance? Alas, the prices be too steep, good sir! For $15-17, a roll of fish doth seem a dear price to pay. Methinks 'tis wiser to journey to Oakland, where such delights may be had at a lower cost."

"Burgers looked killer, but portions were doable. Shared sashimi won-tacos, triple T fries, original ringer, bacon mac-n-cheese. Could've handled another dish. Faves were fries and original. Crisp, truffle-flavored fries, especially aioi. Original had my preferred flavs, though bacon mac-n-cheese is unique. Not my go-to burger joint, but decent. Tacos were a disappointment - tiny tuna portion, uninteresting. Beer and fries, maybe."

"Desserts, good. Service, bad. Prices, steep. Staff, couldn't care less. We ordered the trio, asked for a replacement since the first was damaged. She told another worker instead of doing it herself. Didn't notice till we paid and sat down. Had to bring it back. Shouldn't have had to deal with that."

"Hark! A tale of woe doth unfold,
Of updates, searches, and bitter cold.
At BuyBack$, near Galleria Mall,
We sought a movie, but found none at all.

Decatur, thou art our next hope,
A call we made, a query to cope.
They had the film, in blue ray,
Our hearts did sing, our spirits play.

A hold they placed, upon our request,
For us, they would it keep, at their behest.
Across the town, we hastened fast,
To claim our prize, our treasure vast.

But lo! A sorry tale, they told,
A hold for another, our hopes foiled.
Despite our words, our pleas, they stood,
Their decision, final, as they could.

A review, we left, with stars fewer,
A warning, to others, we did infer.
Not that we won't return, someday,
But faith and devotion, they did slay."

"Been here a few times. It's a chain, so I don't usually eat here. But my husband wanted to go, thought it was BJ's. He was disappointed, they only have lager. Last night was different. Server Paul was great, knew his beer, gave my kids extra fruit. Food was good, fish and chips were decent, garlic fries were better. Cheeseburger with blue cheese was nothing special. Had some bad experiences here before, but last night was a 5-star night. Hope it's a sign of things to come."

"Saturday night, warm and sunny. Envied those on the patio, twinkling lights above, as I sat in the dark interior. Salad, pear and arugula, good but not filling. Eight bucks. Others drank, maybe a better choice."

"Happy hour at its finest. Good drink specials, half-priced apps and rolls. Perfect for a quick bite and a cold beer with friends. Not the best choice for a romantic dinner, but great for a casual night out. A-OK from me."

"Prices good, this store doth have,
On many things, some cheaper than Safeway,
And others, equal to Fry's, by my troth.
'Tis true, what thou art seeking, doth depend,
But Fry's, in my town, doth be my choice,
For Albertson's, by my home, doth reek,
Of rotten fish, and stinketh mightily,
Enough to make one vomit, in truth.

This place, near my friend's abode, doth lie,
So, when we need, a quick purchase,
We dash in, and grab what we require,
With ease, in and out, and service most fair.
A pleasant shopping experience, indeed."

"We tried the buffet, first timers. Forty bucks a head, not bad. Variety's limited, but what they got tasted great. Na'an, specifically. Husband liked the brisket. Clean, bright joint, but cafeteria vibes. Not worth going out of your way for, but if it's close, it'll do."

"Sunday lunch at this joint, busy spot. Food's alright, not amazing but decent. Service good, place clean. Plenty of options. Waited a while for grub. Prices ain't too steep. Might give 'em another shot for dinner."

"Waitin' at the drive-thru, ain't no picnic. Today, it was a real bust. Two cars ahead, and I'm sittin' there for damn near 15 minutes. Just for a sandwich and a smoothie, nothin' fancy. Service is gettin' slower each time I go. Makes me think twice 'bout comin' back."

"Methinks I was surprised at how much I didst enjoy Kahunaville, forsooth! The sandwiches, priced at a mere 11 crowns, were of generous proportion, indeed. The drinks, alack, were costly, as is the wont of Las Vegas, but the server, a friendly and courteous lass, didst pour them with a generous hand. I do recommend, with great enthusiasm, a yard of Bombay and tonic, 'twill quench thy thirst most thoroughly! Our server, despite one of our company's uncouth behavior, didst attend to us with diligence and grace, her station well-maintained."

"Panda Express with a twist - a drive-thru for convenience. Service is meh, but let's be real, it's not like we're there for the small talk. Food's solid, portions are decent, and it's close to some shopping spots. That's all that matters."

"Date and I hit The Lodge for Happy Hour. Prices were right, service was good. Deep fried cheese curds? Hell yeah. But the bar stools? Brutal. Didn't stick around long, but might give it another shot at a table. P.S. Saw a server working hard for tips, but damn, she was almost too scantily clad. Made us check out the rest of the joint."

"Edinburgh's oldest Chinese restaurant, or so they claim. Fifty years young, and still going strong. Locals have been coming here for decades. Name's a bit sketchy, but the grub's top-notch. Cantonese and Peking cuisine, plenty to choose from. Dessert menu's limited, but hey, bananas are always a good idea. Real Chinese folks eat here too, that's a good sign. Tough to please the locals, but they seem to be doing alright."

"Hark! A traveler, I didst not tarry
At yonder inn, yet still didst play
A game of craps, most wondrous fair,
That paid but double for a pair.
Yet, 'twas a bargain, I didst swear,
For odds of hundredfold didst lie therein.
A veritable steal, I didst declare,
In this, the city of sin and glee.
The lodging, old and low of ceiling,
Didst reek of smoke, an odor most unseemly.
But locals, friendly, and drinks, passable,
Didst make my sojourn most agreeable."

"I felt a certain impatience as I gazed upon this restaurant... a bit too much perhaps. We shared some 'croquettes' with foie gras: nothing extraordinary. Next, I was tempted by the happy pig's ribeye: tender meat, but the sauce wasn't quite to my taste. My friend had the duck breast, clearly disappointing. Excellent pecan tart, but is it worth coming here for? Really content to have eaten here, but several other restaurants in the same price range make me happier."

"These digs, like the Teepee, take us back to a time when our Mexican grub was straightforward, our expectations low. But hey, it's still good eats. This joint's got some stories to tell, just ask Marty Robbins."

"A penny saved is a penny earned, they say,
But here, thou dost not get what thou pay.
No fridge, no kettle, nor coffee maker,
Nor microwave, to warm thy meager supper.
The carpets, old and stinky, do offend,
And faucet, broken, did our patience end.
But silently, the night did pass,
And close to all, the inn did stand.
Methinks, another time, I shall explore,
Other options, before coming once more."

This sushi place, middling at best, doth serve
Rolls o'erflowing with rice, and scarce a bit
Of fish within. I'd pay more, and have it worth,
If only they didst provide more substance, not just earth.
A seat, a bench, a stool, nay, not a one,
Have they for weary souls to rest upon.
Yet still, I come hither, when work doth call,
For quick lunch, naught else. 'Tis on a par,
With sushi, pre-made, from market's shelf.

"This place, aight it was, fair sirs,
Four dollar beer, a goodly deal, no doubt.
But mark thee well, the victuals here,
Didst leave much to be desired, I do declare.
Overpriced and underwhelming, alas!
The atmosphere, quite pleasant, I must say,
Yet, for seafood, nearer to the coast, thou shouldst stray."

"I went there after Fry's gave me the runaround. Nice to see the minis, e-readers, and Kindle up front. Glad I didn't have to trek to the back, heels killing my feet. Just wanted the Kindle and outta there. Couldn't resist a snazzy blue case, though. Employees actually helpful, unlike Fry's where it was like pulling teeth. Cashier asked about their rewards card, but I wasn't feeling it after a bad experience with gift rewards going to some random Illinois address. Three stars, tops. Can't fully trust 'em."

"The club itself was naught but ordinary, yet the view from its lofty perch on the 53rd floor did stir the soul. Alas, the distance from the bustling Strip did make one feel quite remote, and the threat of foul weather did dampen our spirits somewhat. But, methinks, the Palms hath done well to create a place of merriment, despite its lack of grandeur."
"Ate here a week back. Food was good, not great. Gnocchi and ravioli, both decent. Marinara sauce, top-notch. Caprese, just okay. Service, good. Prices, steep."

"Gordon Ramsay fan here. Love the guy's shows, his passion for excellence. Reminds me of my college days, grilling up a storm at Buffalo Wild Wings. Had to try this place, what with being a fan and all. Ordering was tough, like solving the ACT. Wanted a burger, but thought I'd branch out, try something British. Went with the pie sampler. Good idea, I thought. Sample all of Gordon's flavors. But it backfired. Still hungry after. Meat pies were decent, but that's not saying much. Should've gotten a whole pie or a burger. Maybe both. My friend had a burger, looked great. Swiped some fries when he wasn't looking. Very good. Be back to try the burger."

"Alack, not th' best computer science program doth lie,
In this fair school of Arizona's burning sky.
A place of learning, large and full of life,
Yet, alas, the heat doth oft become a strife.
My classmates, friendly souls, didst make me feel,
At home, in this strange land, so far from my zeal.
But, lo, the teachers, strict and stern of mood,
Didst often dampen my spirits, as they could.
A quirk of this place, a curious sight to see,
Were bicycles, stolen and reassembled with glee.
A hodgepodge of parts, in colors bright and bold,
Didst make me laugh, and think the thieves quite bold.
And, verily, I saw, upon the streets,
People holding signs, of faith and beliefs unique.
A diversity of folk, in this place doth dwell,
Which doth make it interesting, and worth the spell.
But, alack, my teachers, left me underwhelmed,
For they, the ones I sought, didst not fulfill my zeal."

"Ay, this hotel had its fair share of woe,
Our room, assigned late, was not what we know.
Non-smoking, we requested, yet they gave,
A smoking room, our plans to grave.

They said, "Come forth, between twelve and three,"
To change rooms, as they'd given our key.
But alas, five hours we didst wait,
And our day, was lost, in frustration's bate.

At last, they gave us a non-smoking abode,
But the wait, didst leave us quite irked and annoyed.
Yet still, the hotel, had its charm,
In the heart of the Strip, a prime disarm.

Across from Cosmo and Bellagio, we didst stray,
And shopped, and dined, at Gordon Ramsey's play.
So three stars, I give, despite the strife,
For the hotel, though flawed, didst show some life."

"Alas, I wish I had more pleasant words to say,  
But truth be told, this place should've stayed away.  
In my youthful days, perhaps, it may have suited,  
But now, alas, 'tis but a poor excuse for food, ill-fitted.  
  
The place, though clean, doth lack a certain charm,  
And though the sushi chef did greet us with a disarming smile,  
The fare he served, alack, did leave much to be desired,  
The tonkatsu, dry, and batter, scarce, like a poor maiden's blushes fired.  
  
And so, good friends, I say, avoid this place,  
For though the miso soup did warm my soul's dark space,  
'Tis not worth the cost, the price too steep,  
For sushi, fresh, doth require a greater keep.
